[SHK] And rock the ground whereon these sleepers be
[SHK] Now thou and I are new in amity
[SHK] And will to-morrow midnight solemnly
[SHK] Dance in Duke Theseus house triumphantly
[SHK] And bless it to all fair prosperity
[SHK] There shall the pairs of faithful lovers be
[SHK] Wedded with Theseus all in jollity
[SHK] Fairy king attend and mark
[SHK] I do hear the morning lark
[SHK] Then my queen in silence sad
[SHK] Trip we after the night 's shade
[SHK] We the globe can compass soon
[SHK] Swifter than the wandering moon
[SHK] Come my lord and in our flight
[SHK] Tell me how it came this night
[SHK] That I sleeping here was found
[SHK] With these mortals on the ground
[SHK] Go one of you find out the forester
[SHK] For now our observation is perform 'd
[SHK] And since we have the vaward of the day
[SHK] My love shall hear the music of my hounds
[SHK] Uncouple in the western valley let them go
[SHK] Dispatch I say and find the forester
[SHK] We will fair queen up to the mountain 's top
[SHK] And mark the musical confusion
[SHK] Of hounds and echo in conjunction
[SHK] I was with Hercules and Cadmus once
[SHK] When in a wood of Crete they bay 'd the bear
[SHK] With hounds of Sparta never did I hear
[SHK] Such gallant chiding for besides the groves
[SHK] The skies the fountains every region near
[SHK] Seem 'd all one mutual cry I never heard
[SHK] So musical a discord such sweet thunder
[SHK] My hounds are bred out of the Spartan kind
[SHK] So flew 'd so sanded and their heads are hung
[SHK] With ears that sweep away the morning dew
[SHK] Crook-knee 'd and dew-lapp 'd like Thessalian bulls
[SHK] Slow in pursuit but match 'd in mouth like bells
[SHK] Each under each A cry more tuneable
[SHK] Was never holla 'd to nor cheer 'd with horn
[SHK] In Crete in Sparta nor in Thessaly
[SHK] Judge when you hear But soft what nymphs are these
[SHK] My lord this is my daughter here asleep
[SHK] And this Lysander this Demetrius is
[SHK] This Helena old Nedar 's Helena
[SHK] I wonder of their being here together
[SHK] No doubt they rose up early to observe
[SHK] The rite of May and hearing our intent
[SHK] Came here in grace our solemnity
[SHK] But speak Egeus is not this the day
[SHK] That Hermia should give answer of her choice
[SHK] It is my lord
[SHK] Go bid the huntsmen wake them with their horns
[SHK] Good morrow friends Saint Valentine is past
[SHK] Begin these wood-birds but to couple now
[SHK] Pardon my lord
[SHK] I pray you all stand up
[SHK] I know you two are rival enemies
[SHK] How comes this gentle concord in the world
[SHK] That hatred is so far from jealousy
[SHK] To sleep by hate and fear no enmity
[SHK] My lord I shall reply amazedly
[SHK] Half sleep half waking but as yet I swear
[SHK] I can not truly say how I came here
[SHK] But as I think -- for truly would I speak
[SHK] And now do I bethink me so it is --
[SHK] I came with Hermia hither our intent
[SHK] Was to be gone from Athens where we might
[SHK] Without the peril of the Athenian law
[SHK] Enough enough my lord you have enough
[SHK] I beg the law the law upon his head
[SHK] They would have stolen away they would Demetrius
[SHK] Thereby to have defeated you and me
[SHK] You of your wife and me of my consent
[SHK] Of my consent that she should be your wife
[SHK] My lord fair Helen told me of their stealth
[SHK] Of this their purpose hither to this wood
[SHK] And I in fury hither follow 'd them
[SHK] Fair Helena in fancy following me
[SHK] But my good lord I wot not by what power --
[SHK] But by some power it is -- my love to Hermia
[SHK] Melted as the snow seems to me now
[SHK] As the remembrance of an idle gaud
[SHK] Which in my childhood I did dote upon
[SHK] And all the faith the virtue of my heart
[SHK] The object and the pleasure of mine eye
[SHK] Is only Helena To her my lord
[SHK] Was I betroth 'd ere I saw Hermia
[SHK] But like in sickness did I loathe this food
[SHK] But as in health come to my natural taste
[SHK] Now I do wish it love it long for it
[SHK] And will for evermore be true to it
[SHK] Fair lovers you are fortunately met
[SHK] Of this discourse we more will hear anon
[SHK] Egeus I will overbear your will
[SHK] For in the temple by and by with us
[SHK] These couples shall eternally be knit
[SHK] And for the morning now is something worn
[SHK] Our purposed hunting shall be set aside
[SHK] Away with us to Athens three and three
[SHK] We 'll hold a feast in great solemnity
[SHK] Come Hippolyta
[SHK] These things seem small and undistinguishable
[SHK] Methinks I see these things with parted eye
[SHK] When every thing seems double
[SHK] So methinks
[SHK] And I have found Demetrius like a jewel
[SHK] Mine own and not mine own
[SHK] Are you sure
[SHK] That we are awake It seems to me
[SHK] That yet we sleep we dream Do not you think
[SHK] The duke was here and bid us follow him
[SHK] Yea and my father
[SHK] And Hippolyta
[SHK] And he did bid us follow to the temple
[SHK] Why then we are awake let 's follow him
[SHK] And by the way let us recount our dreams
[SHK] answer my next is 'Most fair Pyramus Heigh-ho
[SHK] Peter Quince Flute the bellows-mender Snout
[SHK] the tinker Starveling God 's my life stolen
[SHK] hence and left me asleep I have had a most rare
[SHK] vision I have had a dream past the wit of man to
[SHK] say what dream it was man is but an ass if he go
[SHK] about to expound this dream Methought I was -- there
[SHK] is no man can tell what Methought I was -- and
[SHK] methought I had -- but man is but a patched fool if
[SHK] he will offer to say what methought I had The eye
[SHK] of man hath not heard the ear of man hath not
[SHK] seen man 's hand is not able to taste his tongue
[SHK] to conceive nor his heart to report what my dream
[SHK] was I will get Peter Quince to write a ballad of
[SHK] this dream it shall be called Bottom 's Dream
[SHK] because it hath no bottom and I will sing it in the
[SHK] latter end of a play before the duke
[SHK] peradventure to make it the more gracious I shall
[SHK] sing it at her death
[SHK] Have you sent to Bottom 's house is he come home yet
[SHK] He can not be heard of Out of doubt he is
[SHK] transported
[SHK] If he come not then the play is marred it goes
[SHK] not forward doth it
[SHK] It is not possible you have not a man in all
[SHK] Athens able to discharge Pyramus but he
[SHK] No he hath simply the best wit of any handicraft
[SHK] man in Athens
[SHK] Yea and the best person too and he is a very
[SHK] paramour for a sweet voice
[SHK] You must say 'paragon a paramour is God bless us
[SHK] a thing of naught
[SHK] Masters the duke is coming from the temple and
[SHK] there is two or three lords and ladies more married
[SHK] if our sport had gone forward we had all been made
[SHK] men
[SHK] O sweet bully Bottom Thus hath he lost sixpence a
[SHK] day during his life he could not have 'scaped
[SHK] sixpence a day an the duke had not given him
[SHK] sixpence a day for playing Pyramus I 'll be hanged
[SHK] he would have deserved it sixpence a day in
[SHK] Pyramus or nothing
[SHK] Where are these lads where are these hearts
[SHK] Bottom O most courageous day O most happy hour
[SHK] Masters I am to discourse wonders but ask me not
[SHK] what for if I tell you I am no true Athenian I
[SHK] will tell you every thing right as it fell out
[SHK] Let us hear sweet Bottom
[SHK] Not a word of me All that I will tell you is that
[SHK] the duke hath dined Get your apparel together
[SHK] good strings to your beards new ribbons to your
[SHK] pumps meet presently at the palace every man look
[SHK] o'er his part for the short and the long is our
[SHK] play is preferred In any case let Thisby have
[SHK] clean linen and let not him that plays the lion
[SHK] pair his nails for they shall hang out for the
[SHK] lion 's claws And most dear actors eat no onions
[SHK] nor garlic for we are to utter sweet breath and I
[SHK] do not doubt but to hear them say it is a sweet
[SHK] comedy No more words away go away
[SHK] 'T is strange my Theseus that these
[SHK] lovers speak of
[SHK] More strange than true I never may believe
[SHK] These antique fables nor these fairy toys
[SHK] Lovers and madmen have such seething brains
[SHK] Such shaping fantasies that apprehend
[SHK] More than cool reason ever comprehends
[SHK] The lunatic the lover and the poet
[SHK] Are of imagination all compact
[SHK] One sees more devils than vast hell can hold
[SHK] That is the madman the lover all as frantic
[SHK] Sees Helen 's beauty in a brow of Egypt
[SHK] The poet 's eye in fine frenzy rolling
[SHK] Doth glance from heaven to earth from earth to heaven
[SHK] And as imagination bodies forth
[SHK] The forms of things unknown the poet 's pen
[SHK] Turns them to shapes and gives to airy nothing
[SHK] A local habitation and a name
[SHK] Such tricks hath strong imagination
[SHK] That if it would but apprehend some joy
[SHK] It comprehends some bringer of that joy
[SHK] Or in the night imagining some fear
[SHK] How easy is a bush supposed a bear
[SHK] But all the story of the night told over
[SHK] And all their minds transfigured so together
[SHK] More witnesseth than fancy 's images
[SHK] And grows to something of great constancy
[SHK] But howsoever strange and admirable
[SHK] Here come the lovers full of joy and mirth
[SHK] Joy gentle friends joy and fresh days of love
[SHK] Accompany your hearts
[SHK] More than to us
[SHK] Wait in your royal walks your board your bed
[SHK] Come now what masques what dances shall we have
[SHK] To wear away this long age of three hours
[SHK] Between our after-supper and bed-time
[SHK] Where is our usual manager of mirth
[SHK] What revels are in hand Is there no play
[SHK] To ease the anguish of a torturing hour
[SHK] Call Philostrate
[SHK] Here mighty Theseus
[SHK] Say what abridgement have you for this evening
[SHK] What masque what music How shall we beguile
[SHK] The lazy time if not with some delight
[SHK] There is a brief how many sports are ripe
[SHK] Make choice of which your highness will see first
[SHK] By an Athenian eunuch to the harp
[SHK] We 'll none of that that have I told my love
[SHK] In glory of my kinsman Hercules
[SHK] 'The riot of the tipsy Bacchanals
[SHK] Tearing the Thracian singer in their rage
[SHK] That is an old device and it was play 'd
[SHK] When I from Thebes came last a conqueror
[SHK] 'The thrice three Muses mourning for the death
[SHK] Of Learning late deceased in beggary
[SHK] That is some satire keen and critical
[SHK] Not sorting with a nuptial ceremony
[SHK] A tedious brief scene of young Pyramus
[SHK] And his love Thisbe very tragical mirth
[SHK] Merry and tragical tedious and brief
[SHK] That is hot ice and wondrous strange snow
[SHK] How shall we find the concord of this discord
[SHK] A play there is my lord some ten words long
[SHK] Which is as brief as I have known a play
[SHK] But by ten words my lord it is too long
[SHK] Which makes it tedious for in all the play
[SHK] There is not one word apt one player fitted
[SHK] And tragical my noble lord it is
[SHK] For Pyramus therein doth kill himself
[SHK] Which when I saw rehearsed I must confess
[SHK] Made mine eyes water but more merry tears
[SHK] The passion of loud laughter never shed
[SHK] What are they that do play it
[SHK] Hard-handed men that work in Athens here
[SHK] Which never labour 'd in their minds till now
[SHK] And now have toil 'd their unbreathed memories
[SHK] With this same play against your nuptial
[SHK] And we will hear it
[SHK] No my noble lord
[SHK] It is not for you I have heard it over
[SHK] And it is nothing nothing in the world
[SHK] Unless you can find sport in their intents
[SHK] Extremely stretch 'd and conn 'd with cruel pain
[SHK] To do you service
[SHK] I will hear that play
[SHK] For never anything can be amiss
[SHK] When simpleness and duty tender it
[SHK] Go bring them in and take your places ladies
[SHK] I love not to see wretchedness o'er charged
[SHK] And duty in his service perishing
[SHK] Why gentle sweet you shall see no such thing
[SHK] He says they can do nothing in this kind
[SHK] The kinder we to give them thanks for nothing
[SHK] Our sport shall be to take what they mistake
[SHK] And what poor duty can not do noble respect
[SHK] Takes it in might not merit
[SHK] Where I have come great clerks have purposed
[SHK] To greet me with premeditated welcomes
[SHK] Where I have seen them shiver and look pale
[SHK] Make periods in the midst of sentences
[SHK] Throttle their practised accent in their fears
[SHK] And in conclusion dumbly have broke off
[SHK] Not paying me a welcome Trust me sweet
[SHK] Out of this silence yet I pick 'd a welcome
[SHK] And in the modesty of fearful duty
[SHK] I read as much as from the rattling tongue
[SHK] Of saucy and audacious eloquence
[SHK] Love therefore and tongue-tied simplicity
[SHK] In least speak most to my capacity
[SHK] So please your grace the Prologue is address 'd
[SHK] Let him approach
[SHK] If we offend it is with our good will
[SHK] That you should think we come not to offend
[SHK] But with good will To show our simple skill
[SHK] That is the true beginning of our end
[SHK] Consider then we come but in despite
[SHK] We do not come as minding to contest you
[SHK] Our true intent is All for your delight
[SHK] We are not here That you should here repent you
[SHK] The actors are at hand and by their show
[SHK] You shall know all that you are like to know
[SHK] This fellow doth not stand upon points
[SHK] He hath rid his prologue like a rough colt he knows
[SHK] not the stop A good moral my lord it is not
[SHK] enough to speak but to speak true
[SHK] Indeed he hath played on his prologue like a child
[SHK] on a recorder a sound but not in government
[SHK] His speech was like a tangled chain nothing
[SHK] impaired but all disordered Who is next
[SHK] Gentles perchance you wonder at this show
[SHK] But wonder on till truth make all things plain
[SHK] This man is Pyramus if you would know
[SHK] This beauteous lady Thisby is certain
[SHK] This man with lime and rough-cast doth present
[SHK] Wall that vile Wall which did these lovers sunder
[SHK] And through Wall 's chink poor souls they are content
[SHK] To whisper At the which let no man wonder
[SHK] This man with lanthorn dog and bush of thorn
[SHK] Presenteth Moonshine for if you will know
[SHK] By moonshine did these lovers think no scorn
[SHK] To meet at Ninus tomb there there to woo
[SHK] This grisly beast which Lion hight by name
[SHK] The trusty Thisby coming first by night
[SHK] Did scare away or rather did affright
[SHK] And as she fled her mantle she did fall
[SHK] Which Lion vile with bloody mouth did stain
[SHK] Anon comes Pyramus sweet youth and tall
[SHK] And finds his trusty Thisby 's mantle slain
[SHK] Whereat with blade with bloody blameful blade
[SHK] He bravely broach 'd is boiling bloody breast
[SHK] And Thisby tarrying in mulberry shade
[SHK] His dagger drew and died For all the rest
[SHK] Let Lion Moonshine Wall and lovers twain
[SHK] At large discourse while here they do remain
[SHK] I wonder if the lion be to speak
[SHK] No wonder my lord one lion may when many asses do
[SHK] In this same interlude it doth befall
[SHK] That I one Snout by name present a wall
[SHK] And such a wall as I would have you think
[SHK] That had in it a crannied hole or chink
[SHK] Through which the lovers Pyramus and Thisby
[SHK] Did whisper often very secretly
[SHK] This loam this rough-cast and this stone doth show
[SHK] That I am that same wall the truth is so
[SHK] And this the cranny is right and sinister
[SHK] Through which the fearful lovers are to whisper
[SHK] Would you desire lime and hair to speak better
[SHK] It is the wittiest partition that ever I heard
[SHK] discourse my lord
[SHK] Pyramus draws near the wall silence
[SHK] O grim-look 'd night O night with hue so black
[SHK] O night which ever art when day is not
[SHK] O night O night alack alack alack
[SHK] I fear my Thisby 's promise is forgot
[SHK] And thou O wall O sweet O lovely wall
[SHK] That stand'st between her father 's ground and mine
[SHK] Thou wall O wall O sweet and lovely wall
[SHK] Show me thy chink to blink through with mine eyne
[SHK] Thanks courteous wall Jove shield thee well for this
[SHK] But what see I No Thisby do I see
[SHK] O wicked wall through whom I see no bliss
[SHK] Cursed be thy stones for thus deceiving me
[SHK] The wall methinks being sensible should curse again
[SHK] No in truth sir he should not 'Deceiving me
[SHK] is Thisby 's cue she is to enter now and I am to
[SHK] spy her through the wall You shall see it will
[SHK] fall pat as I told you Yonder she comes
[SHK] O wall full often hast thou heard my moans
[SHK] For parting my fair Pyramus and me
[SHK] My cherry lips have often kiss 'd thy stones
[SHK] Thy stones with lime and hair knit up in thee
[SHK] I see a voice now will I to the chink
[SHK] To spy an I can hear my Thisby 's face Thisby
[SHK] My love thou art my love I think
[SHK] Think what thou wilt I am thy lover 's grace
[SHK] And like Limander am I trusty still
[SHK] And I like Helen till the Fates me kill
[SHK] Not Shafalus to Procrus was so true
[SHK] As Shafalus to Procrus I to you
[SHK] O kiss me through the hole of this vile wall
[SHK] I kiss the wall 's hole not your lips at all
[SHK] Wilt thou at Ninny 's tomb meet me straightway
[SHK] 'Tide life 'tide death I come without delay
[SHK] Thus have I Wall my part discharged so
[SHK] And being done thus Wall away doth go
[SHK] Now is the mural down between the two neighbours
[SHK] No remedy my lord when walls are so wilful to hear
[SHK] without warning
[SHK] This is the silliest stuff that ever I heard
[SHK] The best in this kind are but shadows and the worst
[SHK] are no worse if imagination amend them
[SHK] It must be your imagination then and not theirs
[SHK] If we imagine no worse of them than they of
[SHK] themselves they may pass for excellent men Here
[SHK] come two noble beasts in a man and a lion
[SHK] You ladies you whose gentle hearts do fear
[SHK] The smallest monstrous mouse that creeps on floor
[SHK] May now perchance both quake and tremble here
[SHK] When lion rough in wildest rage doth roar
[SHK] Then know that I one Snug the joiner am
[SHK] A lion-fell nor else no lion 's dam
[SHK] For if I should as lion come in strife
[SHK] Into this place 'twere pity on my life
[SHK] A very gentle beast of a good conscience
[SHK] The very best at a beast my lord that e'er I saw
[SHK] This lion is a very fox for his valour
[SHK] True and a goose for his discretion
[SHK] Not so my lord for his valour can not carry his
[SHK] discretion and the fox carries the goose
[SHK] His discretion I am sure can not carry his valour
[SHK] for the goose carries not the fox It is well
[SHK] leave it to his discretion and let us listen to the moon
[SHK] This lanthorn doth the horned moon present --
[SHK] He should have worn the horns on his head
[SHK] He is no crescent and his horns are
[SHK] invisible within the circumference
[SHK] This lanthorn doth the horned moon present
[SHK] Myself the man i the moon do seem to be
[SHK] This is the greatest error of all the rest the man
[SHK] should be put into the lanthorn How is it else the
[SHK] man i the moon
[SHK] He dares not come there for the candle for you
[SHK] see it is already in snuff
[SHK] I am aweary of this moon would he would change
[SHK] It appears by his small light of discretion that
[SHK] he is in the wane but yet in courtesy in all
[SHK] reason we must stay the time
[SHK] Proceed Moon
[SHK] All that I have to say is to tell you that the
[SHK] lanthorn is the moon I the man in the moon this
[SHK] thorn-bush my thorn-bush and this dog my dog
[SHK] Why all these should be in the lanthorn for all
[SHK] these are in the moon But silence here comes Thisbe
[SHK] This is old Ninny 's tomb Where is my love
[SHK] Well roared Lion
[SHK] Well run Thisbe
[SHK] Well shone Moon Truly the moon shines with a
[SHK] good grace
[SHK] Well moused Lion
[SHK] And so the lion vanished
[SHK] And then came Pyramus
[SHK] Sweet Moon I thank thee for thy sunny beams
[SHK] I thank thee Moon for shining now so bright
[SHK] For by thy gracious golden glittering gleams
[SHK] I trust to take of truest Thisby sight
[SHK] But stay O spite
[SHK] But mark poor knight
[SHK] What dreadful dole is here
[SHK] Eyes do you see
[SHK] How can it be
[SHK] O dainty duck O dear
[SHK] Thy mantle good
[SHK] What stain 'd with blood
[SHK] Approach ye Furies fell
[SHK] O Fates come come
[SHK] Cut thread and thrum
[SHK] Quail crush conclude and quell
[SHK] This passion and the death of a dear friend would
[SHK] go near to make a man look sad
[SHK] Beshrew my heart but I pity the man
[SHK] O wherefore Nature didst thou lions frame
[SHK] Since lion vile hath here deflower 'd my dear
[SHK] Which is -- no no -- which was the fairest dame
[SHK] That lived that loved that liked that look 'd
[SHK] with cheer
[SHK] Come tears confound
[SHK] Out sword and wound
[SHK] The pap of Pyramus
[SHK] Ay that left pap
[SHK] Where heart doth hop
[SHK] Thus die I thus thus thus
[SHK] Now am I dead
[SHK] Now am I fled
[SHK] My soul is in the sky
[SHK] Tongue lose thy light
[SHK] Moon take thy flight
[SHK] Now die die die die die
[SHK] No die but an ace for him for he is but one
[SHK] Less than an ace man for he is dead he is nothing
[SHK] With the help of a surgeon he might yet recover and
[SHK] prove an ass
[SHK] How chance Moonshine is gone before Thisbe comes
[SHK] back and finds her lover
[SHK] She will find him by starlight Here she comes and
[SHK] her passion ends the play
[SHK] Methinks she should not use a long one for such a
[SHK] Pyramus I hope she will be brief
[SHK] A mote will turn the balance which Pyramus which
[SHK] Thisbe is the better he for a man God warrant us
[SHK] she for a woman God bless us
[SHK] She hath spied him already with those sweet eyes
[SHK] And thus she means videlicet --
[SHK] Asleep my love
[SHK] What dead my dove
[SHK] O Pyramus arise
[SHK] Speak speak Quite dumb
[SHK] Dead dead A tomb
[SHK] Must cover thy sweet eyes
[SHK] These My lips
[SHK] This cherry nose
[SHK] These yellow cowslip cheeks
[SHK] Are gone are gone
[SHK] Lovers make moan
[SHK] His eyes were green as leeks
[SHK] O Sisters Three
[SHK] Come come to me
[SHK] With hands as pale as milk
[SHK] Lay them in gore
[SHK] Since you have shore
[SHK] With shears his thread of silk
[SHK] Tongue not a word
[SHK] Come trusty sword
[SHK] Come blade my breast imbrue
[SHK] And farewell friends
[SHK] Thus Thisby ends
[SHK] Adieu adieu adieu
[SHK] Moonshine and Lion are left to bury the dead
[SHK] Ay and Wall too
[SHK] parted their fathers Will it please you to see the
[SHK] epilogue or to hear a Bergomask dance between two
[SHK] of our company
[SHK] No epilogue I pray you for your play needs no
[SHK] excuse Never excuse for when the players are all
[SHK] dead there needs none to be blamed Marry if he
[SHK] that writ it had played Pyramus and hanged himself
[SHK] in Thisbe 's garter it would have been a fine
[SHK] tragedy and so it is truly and very notably
[SHK] discharged But come your Bergomask let your
[SHK] epilogue alone
[SHK] The iron tongue of midnight hath told twelve
[SHK] Lovers to bed 't is almost fairy time
[SHK] I fear we shall out-sleep the coming morn
[SHK] As much as we this night have overwatch 'd
[SHK] This palpable-gross play hath well beguiled
[SHK] The heavy gait of night Sweet friends to bed
[SHK] A fortnight hold we this solemnity
[SHK] In nightly revels and new jollity
[SHK] Now the hungry lion roars
[SHK] And the wolf behowls the moon
[SHK] Whilst the heavy ploughman snores
[SHK] All with weary task fordone
[SHK] Now the wasted brands do glow
[SHK] Whilst the screech-owl screeching loud
[SHK] Puts the wretch that lies in woe
[SHK] In remembrance of a shroud
[SHK] Now it is the time of night
[SHK] That the graves all gaping wide
[SHK] Every one lets forth his sprite
[SHK] In the church-way paths to glide
[SHK] And we fairies that do run
[SHK] By the triple Hecate 's team
[SHK] From the presence of the sun
[SHK] Following darkness like a dream
[SHK] Now are frolic not a mouse
[SHK] Shall disturb this hallow 'd house
[SHK] I am sent with broom before
[SHK] To sweep the dust behind the door
[SHK] Through the house give gathering light
[SHK] By the dead and drowsy fire
[SHK] Every elf and fairy sprite
[SHK] Hop as light as bird from brier
[SHK] And this ditty after me
[SHK] Sing and dance it trippingly
[SHK] First rehearse your song by rote
[SHK] To each word a warbling note
[SHK] Hand in hand with fairy grace
[SHK] Will we sing and bless this place
[SHK] Now until the break of day
[SHK] Through this house each fairy stray
[SHK] To the best bride-bed will we
[SHK] Which by us shall blessed be
[SHK] And the issue there create
[SHK] Ever shall be fortunate
[SHK] So shall all the couples three
[SHK] Ever true in loving be
[SHK] And the blots of Nature 's hand
[SHK] Shall not in their issue stand
[SHK] Never mole hare lip nor scar
[SHK] Nor mark prodigious such as are
[SHK] Despised in nativity
[SHK] Shall upon their children be
[SHK] With this field-dew consecrate
[SHK] Every fairy take his gait
[SHK] And each several chamber bless
[SHK] Through this palace with sweet peace
[SHK] And the owner of it blest
[SHK] Ever shall in safety rest
[SHK] Trip away make no stay
[SHK] Meet me all by break of day
[SHK] If we shadows have offended
[SHK] Think but this and all is mended
[SHK] That you have but slumber 'd here
[SHK] While these visions did appear
[SHK] And this weak and idle theme
[SHK] No more yielding but a dream
[SHK] Gentles do not reprehend
[SHK] if you pardon we will mend
[SHK] And as I am an honest Puck
[SHK] If we have unearned luck
[SHK] Now to 'scape the serpent 's tongue
[SHK] We will make amends ere long
[SHK] Else the Puck a liar call
[SHK] So good night unto you all
[SHK] Give me your hands if we be friends
[SHK] And Robin shall restore amends
[SHK] Who 's there
[SHK] Nay answer me stand and unfold yourself
[SHK] Long live the king
[SHK] Bernardo
[SHK] He
[SHK] You come most carefully upon your hour
[SHK] 'T is now struck twelve get thee to bed Francisco
[SHK] For this relief much thanks 't is bitter cold
[SHK] And I am sick at heart
[SHK] Have you had quiet guard
[SHK] Not a mouse stirring
[SHK] Well good night
[SHK] If you do meet Horatio and Marcellus
[SHK] The rivals of my watch bid them make haste
[SHK] I think I hear them Stand ho Who 's there
[SHK] Friends to this ground

[SHK] Bernardo has my place
[SHK] Give you good night
[SHK] Holla Bernardo
[SHK] Say
[SHK] What is Horatio there
[SHK] A piece of him
[SHK] Welcome Horatio welcome good Marcellus
[SHK] What has this thing appear 'd again to-night
[SHK] I have seen nothing
[SHK] Horatio says 't is but our fantasy
[SHK] And will not let belief take hold of him
[SHK] Touching this dreaded sight twice seen of us
[SHK] Therefore I have entreated him along
[SHK] With us to watch the minutes of this night
[SHK] That if again this apparition come
[SHK] He may approve our eyes and speak to it
[SHK] Tush tush 'twill not appear
[SHK] Sit down awhile
[SHK] And let us once again assail your ears
[SHK] That are so fortified against our story
[SHK] What we have two nights seen
[SHK] Well sit we down
[SHK] And let us hear Bernardo speak of this
[SHK] Last night of all
[SHK] When yond same star that 's westward from the pole
[SHK] Had made his course to illume that part of heaven
[SHK] Where now it burns Marcellus and myself
[SHK] The bell then beating one --
[SHK] Peace break thee off look where it comes again
[SHK] In the same figure like the king that 's dead
[SHK] Thou art a scholar speak to it Horatio
[SHK] Looks it not like the king mark it Horatio
[SHK] Most like it harrows me with fear and wonder
[SHK] It would be spoke to
[SHK] Question it Horatio
[SHK] What art thou that usurp'st this time of night
[SHK] Together with that fair and warlike form
[SHK] In which the majesty of buried Denmark
[SHK] Did sometimes march by heaven I charge thee speak
[SHK] It is offended
[SHK] See it stalks away
[SHK] Stay speak speak I charge thee speak
[SHK] 'T is gone and will not answer
[SHK] How now Horatio you tremble and look pale
[SHK] Is not this something more than fantasy
[SHK] What think you o n't
[SHK] Before my God I might not this believe
[SHK] Without the sensible and true avouch
[SHK] Of mine own eyes
[SHK] Is it not like the king
[SHK] As thou art to thyself
[SHK] Such was the very armour he had on
[SHK] When he the ambitious Norway combated
[SHK] So frown 'd he once when in an angry parle
[SHK] He smote the sledded Polacks on the ice
[SHK] 'T is strange
[SHK] Thus twice before and jump at this dead hour
[SHK] With martial stalk hath he gone by our watch
[SHK] In what particular thought to work I know not
[SHK] But in the gross and scope of my opinion
[SHK] This bodes some strange eruption to our state
[SHK] Good now sit down and tell me he that knows
[SHK] Why this same strict and most observant watch
[SHK] So nightly toils the subject of the land
[SHK] And why such daily cast of brazen cannon
[SHK] And foreign mart for implements of war
[SHK] Why such impress of shipwrights whose sore task
[SHK] Does not divide the Sunday from the week
[SHK] What might be toward that this sweaty haste
[SHK] Doth make the night joint-labourer with the day
[SHK] Who is't that can inform me
[SHK] That can I
[SHK] At least the whisper goes so Our last king
[SHK] Whose image even but now appear 'd to us
[SHK] Was as you know by Fortinbras of Norway
[SHK] Thereto prick 'd on by a most emulate pride
[SHK] Dared to the combat in which our valiant Hamlet --
[SHK] For so this side of our known world esteem 'd him --
[SHK] Did slay this Fortinbras who by a seal 'd compact
[SHK] Well ratified by law and heraldry
[SHK] Did forfeit with his life all those his lands
[SHK] Which he stood seized of to the conqueror
[SHK] Against the which a moiety competent
[SHK] Was gaged by our king which had return 'd
[SHK] To the inheritance of Fortinbras
[SHK] Had he been vanquisher as by the same covenant
[SHK] And carriage of the article design 'd
[SHK] His fell to Hamlet Now sir young Fortinbras
[SHK] Of unimproved mettle hot and full
[SHK] Hath in the skirts of Norway here and there
[SHK] Shark 'd up a list of lawless resolutes
[SHK] For food and diet to some enterprise
[SHK] That hath a stomach i n't which is no other --
[SHK] As it doth well appear unto our state --
[SHK] But to recover of us by strong hand
[SHK] And terms compulsatory those foresaid lands
[SHK] So by his father lost and this I take it
[SHK] Is the main motive of our preparations
[SHK] The source of this our watch and the chief head
[SHK] Of this post-haste and romage in the land
[SHK] I think it be no other but e'en so
[SHK] Well may it sort that this portentous figure
[SHK] Comes armed through our watch so like the king
[SHK] That was and is the question of these wars
[SHK] A mote it is to trouble the mind 's eye
[SHK] In the most high and palmy state of Rome
[SHK] A little ere the mightiest Julius fell
[SHK] The graves stood tenantless and the sheeted dead
[SHK] Did squeak and gibber in the Roman streets
[SHK] As stars with trains of fire and dews of blood
[SHK] Disasters in the sun and the moist star
[SHK] Upon whose influence Neptune 's empire stands
[SHK] Was sick almost to doomsday with eclipse
[SHK] And even the like precurse of fierce events
[SHK] As harbingers preceding still the fates
[SHK] And prologue to the omen coming on
[SHK] Have heaven and earth together demonstrated
[SHK] Unto our climatures and countrymen. --
[SHK] But soft behold lo where it comes again
[SHK] I 'll cross it though it blast me Stay illusion
[SHK] If thou hast any sound or use of voice
[SHK] Speak to me
[SHK] If there be any good thing to be done
[SHK] That may to thee do ease and grace to me
[SHK] Speak to me
[SHK] If thou art privy to thy country 's fate
[SHK] Which happily foreknowing may avoid O speak
[SHK] Or if thou hast uphoarded in thy life
[SHK] Extorted treasure in the womb of earth
[SHK] For which they say you spirits oft walk in death
[SHK] Speak of it stay and speak Stop it Marcellus
[SHK] Shall I strike at it with my partisan
[SHK] Do if it will not stand
[SHK] 'T is here
[SHK] 'T is here
[SHK] 'T is gone
[SHK] We do it wrong being so majestical
[SHK] To offer it the show of violence
[SHK] For it is as the air invulnerable
[SHK] And our vain blows malicious mockery
[SHK] It was about to speak when the cock crew
[SHK] And then it started like a guilty thing
[SHK] Upon a fearful summons I have heard
[SHK] The cock that is the trumpet to the morn
[SHK] Doth with his lofty and shrill-sounding throat
[SHK] Awake the god of day and at his warning
[SHK] Whether in sea or fire in earth or air
[SHK] The extravagant and erring spirit hies
[SHK] To his confine and of the truth herein
[SHK] This present object made probation
[SHK] It faded on the crowing of the cock
[SHK] Some say that ever 'gainst that season comes
[SHK] Wherein our Saviour 's birth is celebrated
[SHK] The bird of dawning singeth all night long
[SHK] And then they say no spirit dares stir abroad
[SHK] The nights are wholesome then no planets strike
[SHK] No fairy takes nor witch hath power to charm
[SHK] So hallow 'd and so gracious is the time
[SHK] So have I heard and do in part believe it
[SHK] But look the morn in russet mantle clad
[SHK] Walks o'er the dew of yon high eastward hill
[SHK] Break we our watch up and by my advice
[SHK] Let us impart what we have seen to-night
[SHK] Unto young Hamlet for upon my life
[SHK] This spirit dumb to us will speak to him
[SHK] Do you consent we shall acquaint him with it
[SHK] As needful in our loves fitting our duty
[SHK] Let 's do't I pray and I this morning know
[SHK] Where we shall find him most conveniently
[SHK] Though yet of Hamlet our dear brother 's death
[SHK] The memory be green and that it us befitted
[SHK] To bear our hearts in grief and our whole kingdom
[SHK] To be contracted in one brow of woe
[SHK] Yet so far hath discretion fought with nature
[SHK] That we with wisest sorrow think on him
[SHK] Together with remembrance of ourselves
[SHK] Therefore our sometime sister now our queen
[SHK] The imperial jointress to this warlike state
[SHK] Have we as 'twere with a defeated joy --
[SHK] With an auspicious and a dropping eye
[SHK] With mirth in funeral and with dirge in marriage
[SHK] In equal scale weighing delight and dole --
[SHK] Taken to wife nor have we herein barr 'd
[SHK] Your better wisdoms which have freely gone
[SHK] With this affair along For all our thanks
[SHK] Now follows that you know young Fortinbras
[SHK] Holding a weak supposal of our worth
[SHK] Or thinking by our late dear brother 's death
[SHK] Our state to be disjoint and out of frame
[SHK] Colleagued with the dream of his advantage
[SHK] He hath not fail 'd to pester us with message
[SHK] Importing the surrender of those lands
[SHK] Lost by his father with all bonds of law
[SHK] To our most valiant brother So much for him
[SHK] Now for ourself and for this time of meeting
[SHK] Thus much the business is we have here writ
[SHK] To Norway uncle of young Fortinbras --
[SHK] Who impotent and bed-rid scarcely hears
[SHK] Of this his nephew 's purpose -- to suppress
[SHK] His further gait herein in that the levies
[SHK] The lists and full proportions are all made
[SHK] Out of his subject and we here dispatch
[SHK] You good Cornelius and you Voltimand
[SHK] For bearers of this greeting to old Norway
[SHK] Giving to you no further personal power
[SHK] To business with the king more than the scope
[SHK] Of these delated articles allow
[SHK] Farewell and let your haste commend your duty
[SHK] In that and all things will we show our duty
[SHK] We doubt it nothing heartily farewell
[SHK] And now Laertes what 's the news with you
[SHK] You told us of some suit what is't Laertes
[SHK] You can not speak of reason to the Dane
[SHK] And loose your voice what wouldst thou beg Laertes
[SHK] That shall not be my offer not thy asking
[SHK] The head is not more native to the heart
[SHK] The hand more instrumental to the mouth
[SHK] Than is the throne of Denmark to thy father
[SHK] What wouldst thou have Laertes
[SHK] My dread lord
[SHK] Your leave and favour to return to France
[SHK] From whence though willingly I came to Denmark
[SHK] To show my duty in your coronation
[SHK] Yet now I must confess that duty done
[SHK] My thoughts and wishes bend again toward France
[SHK] And bow them to your gracious leave and pardon
[SHK] Have you your father 's leave What says Polonius
[SHK] He hath my lord wrung from me my slow leave
[SHK] By laboursome petition and at last
[SHK] Upon his will I seal 'd my hard consent
[SHK] I do beseech you give him leave to go
[SHK] Take thy fair hour Laertes time be thine
[SHK] And thy best graces spend it at thy will
[SHK] But now my cousin Hamlet and my son --
[SHK] How is it that the clouds still hang on you
[SHK] Not so my lord I am too much i the sun
[SHK] Good Hamlet cast thy nighted colour off
[SHK] And let thine eye look like a friend on Denmark
[SHK] Do not for ever with thy vailed lids
[SHK] Seek for thy noble father in the dust
[SHK] Thou know'st 't is common all that lives must die
[SHK] Passing through nature to eternity
[SHK] Ay madam it is common
[SHK] If it be
[SHK] Why seems it so particular with thee
[SHK] Seems madam nay it is I know not 'seems
[SHK] 'T is not alone my inky cloak good mother
[SHK] Nor customary suits of solemn black
[SHK] Nor windy suspiration of forced breath
[SHK] No nor the fruitful river in the eye
[SHK] Nor the dejected 'havior of the visage
[SHK] Together with all forms moods shapes of grief
[SHK] That can denote me truly these indeed seem
[SHK] For they are actions that a man might play
[SHK] But I have that within which passeth show
[SHK] These but the trappings and the suits of woe
[SHK] 'T is sweet and commendable in your nature Hamlet
[SHK] To give these mourning duties to your father
[SHK] But you must know your father lost a father
[SHK] That father lost lost his and the survivor bound
[SHK] In filial obligation for some term
[SHK] To do obsequious sorrow but to persever
[SHK] In obstinate condolement is a course
[SHK] Of impious stubbornness 't is unmanly grief
[SHK] It shows a will most incorrect to heaven
[SHK] A heart unfortified a mind impatient
[SHK] An understanding simple and unschool 'd
[SHK] For what we know must be and is as common
[SHK] As any the most vulgar thing to sense
[SHK] Why should we in our peevish opposition
[SHK] Take it to heart Fie 't is a fault to heaven
[SHK] A fault against the dead a fault to nature
[SHK] To reason most absurd whose common theme
[SHK] Is death of fathers and who still hath cried
[SHK] From the first corse till he that died to-day
[SHK] 'This must be so We pray you throw to earth
[SHK] This unprevailing woe and think of us
[SHK] As of a father for let the world take note
[SHK] You are the most immediate to our throne
[SHK] And with no less nobility of love
[SHK] Than that which dearest father bears his son
[SHK] Do I impart toward you For your intent
[SHK] In going back to school in Wittenberg
[SHK] It is most retrograde to our desire
[SHK] And we beseech you bend you to remain
[SHK] Here in the cheer and comfort of our eye
[SHK] Our chiefest courtier cousin and our son
[SHK] Let not thy mother lose her prayers Hamlet
[SHK] I pray thee stay with us go not to Wittenberg
[SHK] I shall in all my best obey you madam
[SHK] Why 't is a loving and a fair reply
[SHK] Be as ourself in Denmark Madam come
[SHK] This gentle and unforced accord of Hamlet
[SHK] Sits smiling to my heart in grace whereof
[SHK] No jocund health that Denmark drinks to-day
[SHK] But the great cannon to the clouds shall tell
[SHK] And the king 's rouse the heavens all bruit again
[SHK] Re-speaking earthly thunder Come away
[SHK] O that this too too solid flesh would melt
[SHK] Thaw and resolve itself into a dew
[SHK] Or that the Everlasting had not fix 'd
[SHK] His canon 'gainst self-slaughter O God God
[SHK] How weary stale flat and unprofitable
[SHK] Seem to me all the uses of this world
[SHK] Fie o n't ah fie 't is an unweeded garden
[SHK] That grows to seed things rank and gross in nature
[SHK] Possess it merely That it should come to this
[SHK] But two months dead nay not so much not two
[SHK] So excellent a king that was to this
[SHK] Hyperion to a satyr so loving to my mother
[SHK] That he might not beteem the winds of heaven
[SHK] Visit her face too roughly Heaven and earth
[SHK] Must I remember why she would hang on him
[SHK] As if increase of appetite had grown
[SHK] By what it fed on and yet within a month --
[SHK] Let me not think o n't -- Frailty thy name is woman --
[SHK] A little month or ere those shoes were old
[SHK] With which she follow 'd my poor father 's body
[SHK] Like Niobe all tears -- why she even she --
[SHK] O God a beast that wants discourse of reason
[SHK] Would have mourn 'd longer -- married with my uncle
[SHK] My father 's brother but no more like my father
[SHK] Than I to Hercules within a month
[SHK] Ere yet the salt of most unrighteous tears
[SHK] Had left the flushing in her galled eyes
[SHK] She married O most wicked speed to post
[SHK] With such dexterity to incestuous sheets
[SHK] It is not nor it can not come to good
[SHK] But break my heart for I must hold my tongue
[SHK] Hail to your lordship
[SHK] I am glad to see you well
[SHK] Horatio -- or I do forget myself
[SHK] The same my lord and your poor servant ever

[SHK] My good lord --
[SHK] I am very glad to see you Good even sir
[SHK] But what in faith make you from Wittenberg
[SHK] A truant disposition good my lord
[SHK] I would not hear your enemy say so

[SHK] To make it truster of your own report
[SHK] Against yourself I know you are no truant
[SHK] But what is your affair in Elsinore
[SHK] We 'll teach you to drink deep ere you depart
[SHK] My lord I came to see your father 's funeral
[SHK] I pray thee do not mock me fellow-student
[SHK] I think it was to see my mother 's wedding
[SHK] Indeed my lord it follow 'd hard upon
[SHK] Thrift thrift Horatio the funeral baked meats
[SHK] Did coldly furnish forth the marriage tables
[SHK] Would I had met my dearest foe in heaven
[SHK] Or ever I had seen that day Horatio

[SHK] Where my lord
[SHK] In my mind 's eye Horatio
[SHK] I saw him once he was a goodly king

[SHK] My lord I think I saw him yesternight
[SHK] Saw who

[SHK] The king my father
[SHK] Season your admiration for awhile
[SHK] With an attent ear till I may deliver
[SHK] Upon the witness of these gentlemen
[SHK] This marvel to you
[SHK] For God 's love let me hear
[SHK] Two nights together had these gentlemen
[SHK] Marcellus and Bernardo on their watch
[SHK] In the dead vast and middle of the night
[SHK] Been thus encounter 'd A figure like your father
[SHK] Armed at point exactly cap-a-pe
[SHK] Appears before them and with solemn march
[SHK] Goes slow and stately by them thrice he walk 'd
[SHK] By their oppress 'd and fear-surprised eyes
[SHK] Within his truncheon 's length whilst they distilled
[SHK] Almost to jelly with the act of fear
[SHK] Stand dumb and speak not to him This to me
[SHK] In dreadful secrecy impart they did
[SHK] And I with them the third night kept the watch
[SHK] Where as they had deliver 'd both in time
[SHK] Form of the thing each word made true and good
[SHK] The apparition comes I knew your father
[SHK] These hands are not more like

[SHK] My lord upon the platform where we watch 'd
[SHK] Did you not speak to it

[SHK] But even then the morning cock crew loud
[SHK] And at the sound it shrunk in haste away
[SHK] And vanish 'd from our sight
[SHK] 'T is very strange
[SHK] As I do live my honour 'd lord 't is true

[SHK] To let you know of it
[SHK] Indeed indeed sirs but this troubles me

[SHK] We do my lord
[SHK] Arm 'd say you
[SHK] Arm 'd my lord

[SHK] Then saw you not his face

[SHK] Pale or red
[SHK] Nay very pale
[SHK] And fix 'd his eyes upon you
[SHK] Most constantly

[SHK] A sable silver 'd

[SHK] Upon the platform 'twixt eleven and twelve

[SHK] Your loves as mine to you farewell
[SHK] My father 's spirit in arms all is not well
[SHK] I doubt some foul play would the night were come
[SHK] Till then sit still my soul foul deeds will rise
[SHK] Though all the earth o'erwhelm them to men 's eyes
[SHK] My necessaries are embark 'd farewell
[SHK] And sister as the winds give benefit
[SHK] And convoy is assistant do not sleep
[SHK] But let me hear from you
[SHK] Do you doubt that
[SHK] For Hamlet and the trifling of his favour
[SHK] Hold it a fashion and a toy in blood
[SHK] A violet in the youth of primy nature
[SHK] Forward not permanent sweet not lasting
[SHK] The perfume and suppliance of a minute No more
[SHK] No more but so
[SHK] Think it no more
[SHK] For nature crescent does not grow alone
[SHK] In thews and bulk but as this temple waxes
[SHK] The inward service of the mind and soul
[SHK] Grows wide withal Perhaps he loves you now
[SHK] And now no soil nor cautel doth besmirch
[SHK] The virtue of his will but you must fear
[SHK] His greatness weigh 'd his will is not his own
[SHK] For he himself is subject to his birth
[SHK] He may not as unvalued persons do
[SHK] Carve for himself for on his choice depends
[SHK] The safety and health of this whole state
[SHK] And therefore must his choice be circumscribed
[SHK] Unto the voice and yielding of that body
[SHK] Whereof he is the head Then if he says he loves you
[SHK] It fits your wisdom so far to believe it
[SHK] As he in his particular act and place
[SHK] May give his saying deed which is no further
[SHK] Than the main voice of Denmark goes withal
[SHK] Then weigh what loss your honour may sustain
[SHK] If with too credent ear you list his songs
[SHK] Or lose your heart or your chaste treasure open
[SHK] To his unmaster 'd importunity
[SHK] Fear it Ophelia fear it my dear sister
[SHK] And keep you in the rear of your affection
[SHK] Out of the shot and danger of desire
[SHK] The chariest maid is prodigal enough
[SHK] If she unmask her beauty to the moon
[SHK] Virtue itself 'scapes not calumnious strokes
[SHK] The canker galls the infants of the spring
[SHK] Too oft before their buttons be disclosed
[SHK] And in the morn and liquid dew of youth
[SHK] Contagious blastments are most imminent
[SHK] Be wary then best safety lies in fear
[SHK] Youth to itself rebels though none else near
[SHK] I shall the effect of this good lesson keep
[SHK] As watchman to my heart But good my brother
[SHK] Do not as some ungracious pastors do
[SHK] Show me the steep and thorny way to heaven
[SHK] Whiles like a puff 'd and reckless libertine
[SHK] Himself the primrose path of dalliance treads
[SHK] And recks not his own rede
[SHK] O fear me not
[SHK] I stay too long but here my father comes
[SHK] A double blessing is a double grace
[SHK] Occasion smiles upon a second leave
[SHK] Yet here Laertes aboard aboard for shame
[SHK] The wind sits in the shoulder of your sail
[SHK] And you are stay 'd for There my blessing with thee
[SHK] And these few precepts in thy memory
[SHK] See thou character Give thy thoughts no tongue
[SHK] Nor any unproportioned thought his act
[SHK] Be thou familiar but by no means vulgar
[SHK] Those friends thou hast and their adoption tried
[SHK] Grapple them to thy soul with hoops of steel
[SHK] But do not dull thy palm with entertainment
[SHK] Of each new-hatch 'd unfledged comrade Beware
[SHK] Of entrance to a quarrel but being in
[SHK] Bear't that the opposed may beware of thee
[SHK] Give every man thy ear but few thy voice
[SHK] Take each man 's censure but reserve thy judgment
[SHK] Costly thy habit as thy purse can buy
[SHK] But not express 'd in fancy rich not gaudy
[SHK] For the apparel oft proclaims the man
[SHK] And they in France of the best rank and station
[SHK] Are of a most select and generous chief in that
[SHK] Neither a borrower nor a lender be
[SHK] For loan oft loses both itself and friend
[SHK] And borrowing dulls the edge of husbandry
[SHK] This above all to thine ownself be true
[SHK] And it must follow as the night the day
[SHK] Thou canst not then be false to any man
[SHK] Farewell my blessing season this in thee
[SHK] Most humbly do I take my leave my lord

[SHK] This heavy-headed revel east and west
[SHK] Makes us traduced and tax 'd of other nations
[SHK] They clepe us drunkards and with swinish phrase
[SHK] Soil our addition and indeed it takes
[SHK] From our achievements though perform 'd at height
[SHK] The pith and marrow of our attribute
[SHK] So oft it chances in particular men

[SHK] As in their birth -- wherein they are not guilty

[SHK] By the o'ergrowth of some complexion
[SHK] Oft breaking down the pales and forts of reason
[SHK] Or by some habit that too much o'er-leavens

[SHK] As infinite as man may undergo --

[SHK] Gives him three thousand crowns in annual fee
[SHK] And his commission to employ those soldiers
[SHK] So levied as before against the Polack

[SHK] That it might please you to give quiet pass
[SHK] Through your dominions for this enterprise
[SHK] On such regards of safety and allowance
[SHK] As therein are set down
[SHK] It likes us well
[SHK] And at our more consider 'd time well read
[SHK] Answer and think upon this business
[SHK] Meantime we thank you for your well-took labour
[SHK] Go to your rest at night we 'll feast together

[SHK] This business is well ended

[SHK] Were nothing but to waste night day and time

[SHK] And tediousness the limbs and outward flourishes
[SHK] I will be brief your noble son is mad

[SHK] What is't but to be nothing else but mad

[SHK] More matter with less art

[SHK] Seeming to feel this blow with flaming top

[SHK] For murder though it have no tongue will speak

[SHK] To assume a pleasing shape yea and perhaps
[SHK] Out of my weakness and my melancholy
[SHK] As he is very potent with such spirits

[SHK] More relative than this the play 's the thing
[SHK] Wherein I 'll catch the conscience of the king
[SHK] And can you by no drift of circumstance
[SHK] Get from him why he puts on this confusion
[SHK] Grating so harshly all his days of quiet
[SHK] With turbulent and dangerous lunacy
[SHK] He does confess he feels himself distracted
[SHK] But from what cause he will by no means speak
[SHK] Nor do we find him forward to be sounded
[SHK] But with a crafty madness keeps aloof
[SHK] When we would bring him on to some confession
[SHK] Of his true state
[SHK] Did he receive you well
[SHK] Most like a gentleman
[SHK] But with much forcing of his disposition
[SHK] Niggard of question but of our demands
[SHK] Most free in his reply
[SHK] Did you assay him
[SHK] To any pastime
[SHK] Madam it so fell out that certain players
[SHK] We o'er-raught on the way of these we told him
[SHK] And there did seem in him a kind of joy
[SHK] To hear of it they are about the court
[SHK] And as I think they have already order
[SHK] This night to play before him
[SHK] 'T is most true
[SHK] And he beseech 'd me to entreat your majesties
[SHK] To hear and see the matter
[SHK] With all my heart and it doth much content me
[SHK] To hear him so inclined
[SHK] Good gentlemen give him a further edge
[SHK] And drive his purpose on to these delights
[SHK] We shall my lord
[SHK] Sweet Gertrude leave us too
[SHK] For we have closely sent for Hamlet hither
[SHK] That he as 'twere by accident may here
[SHK] Affront Ophelia
[SHK] Her father and myself lawful espials
[SHK] Will so bestow ourselves that seeing unseen
[SHK] We may of their encounter frankly judge
[SHK] And gather by him as he is behaved

[SHK] That thus he suffers for

[SHK] Of Hamlet 's wildness so shall I hope your virtues
[SHK] Will bring him to his wonted way again

[SHK] Madam I wish it may

[SHK] We will bestow ourselves
[SHK] Read on this book
[SHK] That show of such an exercise may colour
[SHK] Your loneliness We are oft to blame in this --
[SHK] 'T is too much proved -- that with devotion 's visage
[SHK] And pious action we do sugar o'er
[SHK] The devil himself
[SHK] How smart a lash that speech doth give my conscience
[SHK] The harlot 's cheek beautied with plastering art
[SHK] Is not more ugly to the thing that helps it
[SHK] Than is my deed to my most painted word
[SHK] O heavy burthen
[SHK] I hear him coming let 's withdraw my lord
[SHK] To be or not to be that is the question
[SHK] Whether 't is nobler in the mind to suffer
[SHK] The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune
[SHK] Or to take arms against a sea of troubles
[SHK] And by opposing end them To die to sleep
[SHK] No more and by a sleep to say we end
[SHK] The heart-ache and the thousand natural shocks
[SHK] That flesh is heir to 't is a consummation
[SHK] Devoutly to be wish 'd To die to sleep
[SHK] To sleep perchance to dream ay there 's the rub
[SHK] For in that sleep of death what dreams may come
[SHK] When we have shuffled off this mortal coil
[SHK] Must give us pause there 's the respect
[SHK] That makes calamity of so long life
[SHK] For who would bear the whips and scorns of time
[SHK] The oppressor 's wrong the proud man 's contumely
[SHK] The pangs of despised love the law 's delay
[SHK] The insolence of office and the spurns
[SHK] That patient merit of the unworthy takes
[SHK] When he himself might his quietus make
[SHK] With a bare bodkin who would fardels bear
[SHK] To grunt and sweat under a weary life
[SHK] But that the dread of something after death
[SHK] The undiscover 'd country from whose bourn
[SHK] No traveller returns puzzles the will
[SHK] And makes us rather bear those ills we have
[SHK] Than fly to others that we know not of
[SHK] Thus conscience does make cowards of us all
[SHK] And thus the native hue of resolution
[SHK] Is sicklied o'er with the pale cast of thought
[SHK] And enterprises of great pith and moment
[SHK] With this regard their currents turn awry
[SHK] And lose the name of action. -- Soft you now
[SHK] The fair Ophelia Nymph in thy orisons
[SHK] Be all my sins remember 'd

[SHK] transform honesty from what it is to a bawd than the

[SHK] very rags to split the ears of the groundlings who
[SHK] for the most part are capable of nothing but
[SHK] inexplicable dumbshows and noise I would have such

[SHK] Where little fears grow great great love grows there

[SHK] Are base respects of thrift but none of love
[SHK] A second time I kill my husband dead
[SHK] When second husband kisses me in bed
[SHK] I do believe you think what now you speak
[SHK] But what we do determine oft we break
[SHK] Purpose is but the slave to memory
[SHK] Of violent birth but poor validity
[SHK] Which now like fruit unripe sticks on the tree
[SHK] But fall unshaken when they mellow be
[SHK] Most necessary 't is that we forget
[SHK] To pay ourselves what to ourselves is debt
[SHK] What to ourselves in passion we propose
[SHK] The passion ending doth the purpose lose
[SHK] The violence of either grief or joy
[SHK] Their own enactures with themselves destroy
[SHK] Where joy most revels grief doth most lament
[SHK] Grief joys joy grieves on slender accident
[SHK] This world is not for aye nor 't is not strange
[SHK] That even our loves should with our fortunes change
[SHK] For 't is a question left us yet to prove
[SHK] Whether love lead fortune or else fortune love
[SHK] The great man down you mark his favourite flies
[SHK] The poor advanced makes friends of enemies
[SHK] And hitherto doth love on fortune tend
[SHK] For who not needs shall never lack a friend
[SHK] And who in want a hollow friend doth try
[SHK] Directly seasons him his enemy
[SHK] But orderly to end where I begun
[SHK] Our wills and fates do so contrary run
[SHK] That our devices still are overthrown
[SHK] Our thoughts are ours their ends none of our own
[SHK] So think thou wilt no second husband wed

[SHK] Nor earth to me give food nor heaven light

[SHK] To desperation turn my trust and hope

[SHK] And do such bitter business as the day

[SHK] The terms of our estate may not endure
[SHK] Hazard so dangerous as doth hourly grow
[SHK] Out of his lunacies
[SHK] We will ourselves provide
[SHK] Most holy and religious fear it is
[SHK] To keep those many many bodies safe
[SHK] That live and feed upon your majesty
[SHK] The single and peculiar life is bound
[SHK] With all the strength and armour of the mind
[SHK] To keep itself from noyance but much more
[SHK] That spirit upon whose weal depend and rest
[SHK] The lives of many The cease of majesty
[SHK] Dies not alone but like a gulf doth draw
[SHK] What 's near it with it it is a massy wheel
[SHK] Fix 'd on the summit of the highest mount
[SHK] To whose huge spokes ten thousand lesser things
[SHK] Are mortised and adjoin 'd which when it falls
[SHK] Each small annexment petty consequence
[SHK] Attends the boisterous ruin Never alone
[SHK] Did the king sigh but with a general groan

[SHK] Which now goes too free-footed

[SHK] O my offence is rank it smells to heaven

[SHK] And like a man to double business bound

[SHK] Were thicker than itself with brother 's blood

[SHK] To wash it white as snow Whereto serves mercy

[SHK] To be forestalled ere we come to fall

[SHK] Can serve my turn 'Forgive me my foul murder

[SHK] My crown mine own ambition and my queen

[SHK] Even to the teeth and forehead of our faults

[SHK] All may be well

[SHK] Be but to sleep and feed a beast no more
[SHK] Sure he that made us with such large discourse
[SHK] Looking before and after gave us not
[SHK] That capability and god-like reason
[SHK] To fust in us unused Now whether it be
[SHK] Bestial oblivion or some craven scruple
[SHK] Of thinking too precisely on the event
[SHK] A thought which quarter 'd hath but one part wisdom
[SHK] And ever three parts coward I do not know
[SHK] Why yet I live to say 'This thing 's to do
[SHK] Sith I have cause and will and strength and means
[SHK] To do't Examples gross as earth exhort me
[SHK] Witness this army of such mass and charge
[SHK] Led by a delicate and tender prince
[SHK] Whose spirit with divine ambition puff 'd
[SHK] Makes mouths at the invisible event
[SHK] Exposing what is mortal and unsure
[SHK] To all that fortune death and danger dare
[SHK] Even for an egg-shell Rightly to be great
[SHK] Is not to stir without great argument
[SHK] But greatly to find quarrel in a straw
[SHK] When honour 's at the stake How stand I then
[SHK] That have a father kill 'd a mother stain 'd
[SHK] Excitements of my reason and my blood
[SHK] And let all sleep while to my shame I see
[SHK] The imminent death of twenty thousand men
[SHK] That for a fantasy and trick of fame
[SHK] Go to their graves like beds fight for a plot
[SHK] Whereon the numbers can not try the cause
[SHK] Which is not tomb enough and continent
[SHK] To hide the slain O from this time forth
[SHK] My thoughts be bloody or be nothing worth

[SHK] There 's tricks i the world and hems and beats her heart
[SHK] Spurns enviously at straws speaks things in doubt
[SHK] That carry but half sense her speech is nothing
[SHK] Yet the unshaped use of it doth move
[SHK] The hearers to collection they aim at it
[SHK] And botch the words up fit to their own thoughts
[SHK] Which as her winks and nods and gestures
[SHK] yield them
[SHK] Indeed would make one think there might be thought
[SHK] Though nothing sure yet much unhappily

[SHK] Dangerous conjectures in ill-breeding minds

[SHK] 'T is e'en so the hand of little employment hath
[SHK] the daintier sense

[SHK] Hath claw 'd me in his clutch
[SHK] And hath shipped me intil the land
[SHK] As if I had never been such

[SHK] Cain 's jaw-bone that did the first murder It

[SHK] lawyer Where be his quiddities now his quillets

[SHK] his action of battery Hum This fellow might be

[SHK] gaffs his kibe How long hast thou been a
[SHK] grave-maker

[SHK] that our last king Hamlet overcame Fortinbras

[SHK] was the very day that young Hamlet was born he that

[SHK] there or if he do not it 's no great matter there

[SHK] are as mad as he

[SHK] have many pocky corses now-a-days that will scarce
[SHK] hold the laying in -- he will last you some eight year
[SHK] or nine year a tanner will last you nine year
[SHK] Why he more than another

[SHK] he will keep out water a great while and your water
[SHK] is a sore decayer of your whoreson dead body

[SHK] three and twenty years
