[SHK] Nothing neither way
[SHK] Have at you now
[SHK] Part them they are incensed
[SHK] Nay come again
[SHK] Look to the queen there ho
[SHK] They bleed on both sides How is it my lord
[SHK] How is't Laertes
[SHK] Why as a woodcock to mine own springe Osric
[SHK] I am justly kill 'd with mine own treachery
[SHK] How does the queen
[SHK] She swounds to see them bleed
[SHK] No no the drink the drink -- O my dear Hamlet --
[SHK] The drink the drink I am poison 'd
[SHK] O villany Ho let the door be lock 'd
[SHK] Treachery Seek it out
[SHK] It is here Hamlet Hamlet thou art slain
[SHK] No medicine in the world can do thee good
[SHK] In thee there is not half an hour of life
[SHK] The treacherous instrument is in thy hand
[SHK] Unbated and envenom 'd the foul practise
[SHK] Hath turn 'd itself on me lo here I lie
[SHK] Never to rise again thy mother 's poison 'd
[SHK] I can no more the king the king 's to blame
[SHK] The point -- envenom 'd too
[SHK] Then venom to thy work
[SHK] Treason treason
[SHK] O yet defend me friends I am but hurt
[SHK] Here thou incestuous murderous damned Dane
[SHK] Drink off this potion Is thy union here
[SHK] Follow my mother
[SHK] He is justly served
[SHK] It is a poison temper 'd by himself
[SHK] Exchange forgiveness with me noble Hamlet
[SHK] Mine and my father 's death come not upon thee
[SHK] Nor thine on me
[SHK] Heaven make thee free of it I follow thee
[SHK] I am dead Horatio Wretched queen adieu
[SHK] You that look pale and tremble at this chance
[SHK] That are but mutes or audience to this act
[SHK] Had I but time -- as this fell sergeant death
[SHK] Is strict in his arrest -- O I could tell you --
[SHK] But let it be Horatio I am dead
[SHK] Thou livest report me and my cause aright
[SHK] To the unsatisfied
[SHK] Never believe it
[SHK] I am more an antique Roman than a Dane
[SHK] Here 's yet some liquor left
[SHK] As thou'rt a man
[SHK] Give me the cup let go by heaven I 'll have't
[SHK] O good Horatio what a wounded name
[SHK] Things standing thus unknown shall live behind me
[SHK] If thou didst ever hold me in thy heart
[SHK] Absent thee from felicity awhile
[SHK] And in this harsh world draw thy breath in pain
[SHK] To tell my story
[SHK] What warlike noise is this
[SHK] Young Fortinbras with conquest come from Poland
[SHK] To the ambassadors of England gives
[SHK] This warlike volley
[SHK] O I die Horatio
[SHK] The potent poison quite o'er-crows my spirit
[SHK] I can not live to hear the news from England
[SHK] But I do prophesy the election lights
[SHK] On Fortinbras he has my dying voice
[SHK] So tell him with the occurrents more and less
[SHK] Which have solicited The rest is silence
[SHK] Now cracks a noble heart Good night sweet prince
[SHK] And flights of angels sing thee to thy rest
[SHK] Why does the drum come hither
[SHK] Where is this sight
[SHK] What is it ye would see
[SHK] If aught of woe or wonder cease your search
[SHK] This quarry cries on havoc O proud death
[SHK] What feast is toward in thine eternal cell
[SHK] That thou so many princes at a shot
[SHK] So bloodily hast struck
[SHK] The sight is dismal
[SHK] And our affairs from England come too late
[SHK] The ears are senseless that should give us hearing
[SHK] To tell him his commandment is fulfill 'd
[SHK] That Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead
[SHK] Where should we have our thanks
[SHK] Not from his mouth
[SHK] Had it the ability of life to thank you
[SHK] He never gave commandment for their death
[SHK] But since so jump upon this bloody question
[SHK] You from the Polack wars and you from England
[SHK] Are here arrived give order that these bodies
[SHK] High on a stage be placed to the view
[SHK] And let me speak to the yet unknowing world
[SHK] How these things came about so shall you hear
[SHK] Of carnal bloody and unnatural acts
[SHK] Of accidental judgments casual slaughters
[SHK] Of deaths put on by cunning and forced cause
[SHK] And in this upshot purposes mistook
[SHK] Fall'n on the inventors reads all this can I
[SHK] Truly deliver
[SHK] Let us haste to hear it
[SHK] And call the noblest to the audience
[SHK] For me with sorrow I embrace my fortune
[SHK] I have some rights of memory in this kingdom
[SHK] Which now to claim my vantage doth invite me
[SHK] Of that I shall have also cause to speak
[SHK] And from his mouth whose voice will draw on more
[SHK] But let this same be presently perform 'd
[SHK] Even while men 's minds are wild lest more mischance
[SHK] On plots and errors happen
[SHK] Let four captains
[SHK] Bear Hamlet like a soldier to the stage
[SHK] For he was likely had he been put on
[SHK] To have proved most royally and for his passage
[SHK] The soldiers music and the rites of war
[SHK] Speak loudly for him
[SHK] Take up the bodies such a sight as this
[SHK] Becomes the field but here shows much amiss
[SHK] Go bid the soldiers shoot
[SHK] Hence home you idle creatures get you home
[SHK] Is this a holiday what know you not
[SHK] Being mechanical you ought not walk
[SHK] Upon a labouring day without the sign
[SHK] Of your profession Speak what trade art thou
[SHK] Why sir a carpenter
[SHK] Where is thy leather apron and thy rule
[SHK] What dost thou with thy best apparel on
[SHK] You sir what trade are you
[SHK] Truly sir in respect of a fine workman I am but
[SHK] as you would say a cobbler
[SHK] But what trade art thou answer me directly
[SHK] A trade sir that I hope I may use with a safe
[SHK] conscience which is indeed sir a mender of bad soles
[SHK] What trade thou knave thou naughty knave what trade
[SHK] Nay I beseech you sir be not out with me yet
[SHK] if you be out sir I can mend you
[SHK] What meanest thou by that mend me thou saucy fellow
[SHK] Why sir cobble you
[SHK] Thou art a cobbler art thou
[SHK] Truly sir all that I live by is with the awl I
[SHK] meddle with no tradesman 's matters nor women 's
[SHK] matters but with awl I am indeed sir a surgeon
[SHK] to old shoes when they are in great danger I
[SHK] recover them As proper men as ever trod upon
[SHK] neat 's leather have gone upon my handiwork
[SHK] But wherefore art not in thy shop today
[SHK] Why dost thou lead these men about the streets
[SHK] Truly sir to wear out their shoes to get myself
[SHK] into more work But indeed sir we make holiday
[SHK] to see Caesar and to rejoice in his triumph
[SHK] Wherefore rejoice What conquest brings he home
[SHK] What tributaries follow him to Rome
[SHK] To grace in captive bonds his chariot-wheels
[SHK] You blocks you stones you worse than senseless things
[SHK] O you hard hearts you cruel men of Rome
[SHK] Knew you not Pompey Many a time and oft
[SHK] Have you climb 'd up to walls and battlements
[SHK] To towers and windows yea to chimney-tops
[SHK] Your infants in your arms and there have sat
[SHK] The livelong day with patient expectation
[SHK] To see great Pompey pass the streets of Rome
[SHK] And when you saw his chariot but appear
[SHK] Have you not made an universal shout
[SHK] That Tiber trembled underneath her banks
[SHK] To hear the replication of your sounds
[SHK] Made in her concave shores
[SHK] And do you now put on your best attire
[SHK] And do you now cull out a holiday
[SHK] And do you now strew flowers in his way
[SHK] That comes in triumph over Pompey 's blood Be gone
[SHK] Run to your houses fall upon your knees
[SHK] Pray to the gods to intermit the plague
[SHK] That needs must light on this ingratitude
[SHK] Go go good countrymen and for this fault
[SHK] Assemble all the poor men of your sort
[SHK] Draw them to Tiber banks and weep your tears
[SHK] Into the channel till the lowest stream
[SHK] Do kiss the most exalted shores of all
[SHK] See whether their basest metal be not moved
[SHK] They vanish tongue-tied in their guiltiness
[SHK] Go you down that way towards the Capitol
[SHK] This way will I disrobe the images
[SHK] If you do find them deck 'd with ceremonies
[SHK] May we do so
[SHK] You know it is the feast of Lupercal
[SHK] It is no matter let no images
[SHK] Be hung with Caesar 's trophies I 'll about
[SHK] And drive away the vulgar from the streets
[SHK] So do you too where you perceive them thick
[SHK] These growing feathers pluck 'd from Caesar 's wing
[SHK] Will make him fly an ordinary pitch
[SHK] Who else would soar above the view of men
[SHK] And keep us all in servile fearfulness
[SHK] Calpurnia
[SHK] Peace ho Caesar speaks
[SHK] Calpurnia
[SHK] Here my lord
[SHK] Stand you directly in Antonius way
[SHK] When he doth run his course Antonius
[SHK] Caesar my lord
[SHK] Forget not in your speed Antonius
[SHK] To touch Calpurnia for our elders say
[SHK] The barren touched in this holy chase
[SHK] Shake off their sterile curse
[SHK] I shall remember
[SHK] When Caesar says 'do this it is perform 'd
[SHK] Set on and leave no ceremony out
[SHK] Caesar
[SHK] Ha who calls
[SHK] Bid every noise be still peace yet again
[SHK] Who is it in the press that calls on me
[SHK] I hear a tongue shriller than all the music
[SHK] Cry 'Caesar Speak Caesar is turn 'd to hear
[SHK] Beware the ides of March
[SHK] What man is that
[SHK] A soothsayer bids you beware the ides of March
[SHK] Set him before me let me see his face
[SHK] Fellow come from the throng look upon Caesar
[SHK] What say'st thou to me now speak once again
[SHK] Beware the ides of March
[SHK] He is a dreamer let us leave him pass
[SHK] Will you go see the order of the course
[SHK] Not I
[SHK] I pray you do
[SHK] I am not gamesome I do lack some part
[SHK] Of that quick spirit that is in Antony
[SHK] Let me not hinder Cassius your desires
[SHK] I 'll leave you
[SHK] Brutus I do observe you now of late
[SHK] I have not from your eyes that gentleness
[SHK] And show of love as I was wont to have
[SHK] You bear too stubborn and too strange a hand
[SHK] Over your friend that loves you
[SHK] Cassius
[SHK] Be not deceived if I have veil 'd my look
[SHK] I turn the trouble of my countenance
[SHK] Merely upon myself Vexed I am
[SHK] Of late with passions of some difference
[SHK] Conceptions only proper to myself
[SHK] Which give some soil perhaps to my behaviors
[SHK] But let not therefore my good friends be grieved --
[SHK] Among which number Cassius be you one --
[SHK] Nor construe any further my neglect
[SHK] Than that poor Brutus with himself at war
[SHK] Forgets the shows of love to other men
[SHK] Then Brutus I have much mistook your passion
[SHK] By means whereof this breast of mine hath buried
[SHK] Thoughts of great value worthy cogitations
[SHK] Tell me good Brutus can you see your face
[SHK] No Cassius for the eye sees not itself
[SHK] But by reflection by some other things
[SHK] 'T is just
[SHK] And it is very much lamented Brutus
[SHK] That you have no such mirrors as will turn
[SHK] Your hidden worthiness into your eye
[SHK] That you might see your shadow I have heard
[SHK] Where many of the best respect in Rome
[SHK] Except immortal Caesar speaking of Brutus
[SHK] And groaning underneath this age 's yoke
[SHK] Have wish 'd that noble Brutus had his eyes
[SHK] Into what dangers would you lead me Cassius
[SHK] That you would have me seek into myself
[SHK] For that which is not in me
[SHK] Therefore good Brutus be prepared to hear
[SHK] And since you know you can not see yourself
[SHK] So well as by reflection I your glass
[SHK] Will modestly discover to yourself
[SHK] That of yourself which you yet know not of
[SHK] And be not jealous on me gentle Brutus
[SHK] Were I a common laugher or did use
[SHK] To stale with ordinary oaths my love
[SHK] To every new protester if you know
[SHK] That I do fawn on men and hug them hard
[SHK] And after scandal them or if you know
[SHK] That I profess myself in banqueting
[SHK] To all the rout then hold me dangerous
[SHK] What means this shouting I do fear the people
[SHK] Choose Caesar for their king
[SHK] Ay do you fear it
[SHK] Then must I think you would not have it so
[SHK] I would not Cassius yet I love him well
[SHK] But wherefore do you hold me here so long
[SHK] What is it that you would impart to me
[SHK] If it be aught toward the general good
[SHK] Set honour in one eye and death i the other
[SHK] And I will look on both indifferently
[SHK] For let the gods so speed me as I love
[SHK] The name of honour more than I fear death
[SHK] I know that virtue to be in you Brutus
[SHK] As well as I do know your outward favour
[SHK] Well honour is the subject of my story
[SHK] I can not tell what you and other men
[SHK] Think of this life but for my single self
[SHK] I had as lief not be as live to be
[SHK] In awe of such a thing as I myself
[SHK] I was born free as Caesar so were you
[SHK] We both have fed as well and we can both
[SHK] Endure the winter 's cold as well as he
[SHK] For once upon a raw and gusty day
[SHK] The troubled Tiber chafing with her shores
[SHK] Caesar said to me 'Darest thou Cassius now
[SHK] Leap in with me into this angry flood
[SHK] And swim to yonder point Upon the word
[SHK] Accoutred as I was I plunged in
[SHK] And bade him follow so indeed he did
[SHK] The torrent roar 'd and we did buffet it
[SHK] With lusty sinews throwing it aside
[SHK] And stemming it with hearts of controversy
[SHK] But ere we could arrive the point proposed
[SHK] Caesar cried 'Help me Cassius or I sink
[SHK] I as Aeneas our great ancestor
[SHK] Did from the flames of Troy upon his shoulder
[SHK] The old Anchises bear so from the waves of Tiber
[SHK] Did I the tired Caesar And this man
[SHK] Is now become a god and Cassius is
[SHK] A wretched creature and must bend his body
[SHK] If Caesar carelessly but nod on him
[SHK] He had a fever when he was in Spain
[SHK] And when the fit was on him I did mark
[SHK] How he did shake 't is true this god did shake
[SHK] His coward lips did from their colour fly
[SHK] And that same eye whose bend doth awe the world
[SHK] Did lose his lustre I did hear him groan
[SHK] Ay and that tongue of his that bade the Romans
[SHK] Mark him and write his speeches in their books
[SHK] Alas it cried 'Give me some drink Titinius
[SHK] As a sick girl Ye gods it doth amaze me
[SHK] A man of such a feeble temper should
[SHK] So get the start of the majestic world
[SHK] And bear the palm alone
[SHK] Another general shout
[SHK] I do believe that these applauses are
[SHK] For some new honours that are heap 'd on Caesar
[SHK] Why man he doth bestride the narrow world
[SHK] Like a Colossus and we petty men
[SHK] Walk under his huge legs and peep about
[SHK] To find ourselves dishonourable graves
[SHK] Men at some time are masters of their fates
[SHK] The fault dear Brutus is not in our stars
[SHK] But in ourselves that we are underlings
[SHK] Brutus and Caesar what should be in that 'Caesar
[SHK] Why should that name be sounded more than yours
[SHK] Write them together yours is as fair a name
[SHK] Sound them it doth become the mouth as well
[SHK] Weigh them it is as heavy conjure with 'em
[SHK] Brutus will start a spirit as soon as Caesar
[SHK] Now in the names of all the gods at once
[SHK] Upon what meat doth this our Caesar feed
[SHK] That he is grown so great Age thou art shamed
[SHK] Rome thou hast lost the breed of noble bloods
[SHK] When went there by an age since the great flood
[SHK] But it was famed with more than with one man
[SHK] When could they say till now that talk 'd of Rome
[SHK] That her wide walls encompass 'd but one man
[SHK] Now is it Rome indeed and room enough
[SHK] When there is in it but one only man
[SHK] O you and I have heard our fathers say
[SHK] There was a Brutus once that would have brook 'd
[SHK] The eternal devil to keep his state in Rome
[SHK] As easily as a king
[SHK] That you do love me I am nothing jealous
[SHK] What you would work me to I have some aim
[SHK] How I have thought of this and of these times
[SHK] I shall recount hereafter for this present
[SHK] I would not so with love I might entreat you
[SHK] Be any further moved What you have said
[SHK] I will consider what you have to say
[SHK] I will with patience hear and find a time
[SHK] Both meet to hear and answer such high things
[SHK] Till then my noble friend chew upon this
[SHK] Brutus had rather be a villager
[SHK] Than to repute himself a son of Rome
[SHK] Under these hard conditions as this time
[SHK] Is like to lay upon us
[SHK] I am glad that my weak words
[SHK] Have struck but thus much show of fire from Brutus
[SHK] The games are done and Caesar is returning
[SHK] As they pass by pluck Casca by the sleeve
[SHK] And he will after his sour fashion tell you
[SHK] What hath proceeded worthy note to-day
[SHK] I will do so But look you Cassius
[SHK] The angry spot doth glow on Caesar 's brow
[SHK] And all the rest look like a chidden train
[SHK] Calpurnia 's cheek is pale and Cicero
[SHK] Looks with such ferret and such fiery eyes
[SHK] As we have seen him in the Capitol
[SHK] Being cross 'd in conference by some senators
[SHK] Casca will tell us what the matter is
[SHK] Antonius
[SHK] Caesar
[SHK] Let me have men about me that are fat
[SHK] Sleek-headed men and such as sleep o nights
[SHK] Yond Cassius has a lean and hungry look
[SHK] He thinks too much such men are dangerous
[SHK] Fear him not Caesar he 's not dangerous
[SHK] He is a noble Roman and well given
[SHK] Would he were fatter But I fear him not
[SHK] Yet if my name were liable to fear
[SHK] I do not know the man I should avoid
[SHK] So soon as that spare Cassius He reads much
[SHK] He is a great observer and he looks
[SHK] Quite through the deeds of men he loves no plays
[SHK] As thou dost Antony he hears no music
[SHK] Seldom he smiles and smiles in such a sort
[SHK] As if he mock 'd himself and scorn 'd his spirit
[SHK] That could be moved to smile at any thing
[SHK] Such men as he be never at heart 's ease
[SHK] Whiles they behold a greater than themselves
[SHK] And therefore are they very dangerous
[SHK] I rather tell thee what is to be fear 'd
[SHK] Than what I fear for always I am Caesar
[SHK] Come on my right hand for this ear is deaf
[SHK] And tell me truly what thou think'st of him
[SHK] You pull 'd me by the cloak would you speak with me
[SHK] Ay Casca tell us what hath chanced to-day
[SHK] That Caesar looks so sad
[SHK] Why you were with him were you not
[SHK] I should not then ask Casca what had chanced
[SHK] Why there was a crown offered him and being
[SHK] offered him he put it by with the back of his hand
[SHK] thus and then the people fell a-shouting
[SHK] What was the second noise for
[SHK] Why for that too
[SHK] They shouted thrice what was the last cry for
[SHK] Why for that too
[SHK] Was the crown offered him thrice
[SHK] Ay marry was't and he put it by thrice every
[SHK] time gentler than other and at every putting-by
[SHK] mine honest neighbours shouted
[SHK] Who offered him the crown
[SHK] Why Antony
[SHK] Tell us the manner of it gentle Casca
[SHK] I can as well be hanged as tell the manner of it
[SHK] it was mere foolery I did not mark it I saw Mark
[SHK] Antony offer him a crown -- yet 't was not a crown
[SHK] neither 't was one of these coronets -- and as I told
[SHK] you he put it by once but for all that to my
[SHK] thinking he would fain have had it Then he
[SHK] offered it to him again then he put it by again
[SHK] but to my thinking he was very loath to lay his
[SHK] fingers off it And then he offered it the third
[SHK] time he put it the third time by and still as he
[SHK] refused it the rabblement hooted and clapped their
[SHK] chapped hands and threw up their sweaty night-caps
[SHK] and uttered such a deal of stinking breath because
[SHK] Caesar refused the crown that it had almost choked
[SHK] Caesar for he swounded and fell down at it and
[SHK] for mine own part I durst not laugh for fear of
[SHK] opening my lips and receiving the bad air
[SHK] But soft I pray you what did Caesar swound
[SHK] He fell down in the market-place and foamed at
[SHK] mouth and was speechless
[SHK] 'T is very like he hath the failing sickness
[SHK] No Caesar hath it not but you and I
[SHK] And honest Casca we have the falling sickness
[SHK] I know not what you mean by that but I am sure
[SHK] Caesar fell down If the tag-rag people did not
[SHK] clap him and hiss him according as he pleased and
[SHK] displeased them as they use to do the players in
[SHK] the theatre I am no true man
[SHK] What said he when he came unto himself
[SHK] Marry before he fell down when he perceived the
[SHK] common herd was glad he refused the crown he
[SHK] plucked me ope his doublet and offered them his
[SHK] throat to cut An I had been a man of any
[SHK] occupation if I would not have taken him at a word
[SHK] I would I might go to hell among the rogues And so
[SHK] he fell When he came to himself again he said
[SHK] If he had done or said any thing amiss he desired
[SHK] their worships to think it was his infirmity Three
[SHK] or four wenches where I stood cried 'Alas good
[SHK] soul and forgave him with all their hearts but
[SHK] there 's no heed to be taken of them if Caesar had
[SHK] stabbed their mothers they would have done no less
[SHK] And after that he came thus sad away
[SHK] Ay
[SHK] Did Cicero say any thing
[SHK] Ay he spoke Greek
[SHK] To what effect
[SHK] Nay an I tell you that Ill ne'er look you i the
[SHK] face again but those that understood him smiled at
[SHK] one another and shook their heads but for mine own
[SHK] part it was Greek to me I could tell you more
[SHK] news too Marullus and Flavius for pulling scarfs
[SHK] off Caesar 's images are put to silence Fare you
[SHK] well There was more foolery yet if I could
[SHK] remember it
[SHK] Will you sup with me to-night Casca
[SHK] No I am promised forth
[SHK] Will you dine with me to-morrow
[SHK] Ay if I be alive and your mind hold and your dinner
[SHK] worth the eating
[SHK] Good I will expect you
[SHK] Do so Farewell both
[SHK] What a blunt fellow is this grown to be
[SHK] He was quick mettle when he went to school
[SHK] So is he now in execution
[SHK] Of any bold or noble enterprise
[SHK] However he puts on this tardy form
[SHK] This rudeness is a sauce to his good wit
[SHK] Which gives men stomach to digest his words
[SHK] With better appetite
[SHK] And so it is For this time I will leave you
[SHK] To-morrow if you please to speak with me
[SHK] I will come home to you or if you will
[SHK] Come home to me and I will wait for you
[SHK] I will do so till then think of the world
[SHK] Well Brutus thou art noble yet I see
[SHK] Thy honourable metal may be wrought
[SHK] From that it is disposed therefore it is meet
[SHK] That noble minds keep ever with their likes
[SHK] For who so firm that can not be seduced
[SHK] Caesar doth bear me hard but he loves Brutus
[SHK] If I were Brutus now and he were Cassius
[SHK] He should not humour me I will this night
[SHK] In several hands in at his windows throw
[SHK] As if they came from several citizens
[SHK] Writings all tending to the great opinion
[SHK] That Rome holds of his name wherein obscurely
[SHK] Caesar 's ambition shall be glanced at
[SHK] And after this let Caesar seat him sure
[SHK] For we will shake him or worse days endure
[SHK] Good even Casca brought you Caesar home
[SHK] Why are you breathless and why stare you so
[SHK] Are not you moved when all the sway of earth
[SHK] Shakes like a thing unfirm O Cicero
[SHK] I have seen tempests when the scolding winds
[SHK] Have rived the knotty oaks and I have seen
[SHK] The ambitious ocean swell and rage and foam
[SHK] To be exalted with the threatening clouds
[SHK] But never till to-night never till now
[SHK] Did I go through a tempest dropping fire
[SHK] Either there is a civil strife in heaven
[SHK] Or else the world too saucy with the gods
[SHK] Incenses them to send destruction
[SHK] Why saw you any thing more wonderful
[SHK] A common slave -- you know him well by sight --
[SHK] Held up his left hand which did flame and burn
[SHK] Like twenty torches join 'd and yet his hand
[SHK] Not sensible of fire remain 'd unscorch 'd
[SHK] Besides -- I ha not since put up my sword --
[SHK] Against the Capitol I met a lion
[SHK] Who glared upon me and went surly by
[SHK] Without annoying me and there were drawn
[SHK] Upon a heap a hundred ghastly women
[SHK] Transformed with their fear who swore they saw
[SHK] Men all in fire walk up and down the streets
[SHK] And yesterday the bird of night did sit
[SHK] Even at noon-day upon the market-place
[SHK] Hooting and shrieking When these prodigies
[SHK] Do so conjointly meet let not men say
[SHK] 'These are their reasons they are natural
[SHK] For I believe they are portentous things
[SHK] Unto the climate that they point upon
[SHK] Indeed it is a strange-disposed time
[SHK] But men may construe things after their fashion
[SHK] Clean from the purpose of the things themselves
[SHK] Come Caesar to the Capitol to-morrow
[SHK] He doth for he did bid Antonius
[SHK] Send word to you he would be there to-morrow
[SHK] Good night then Casca this disturbed sky
[SHK] Is not to walk in
[SHK] Farewell Cicero
[SHK] Who 's there
[SHK] A Roman
[SHK] Casca by your voice
[SHK] Your ear is good Cassius what night is this
[SHK] A very pleasing night to honest men
[SHK] Who ever knew the heavens menace so
[SHK] Those that have known the earth so full of faults
[SHK] For my part I have walk 'd about the streets
[SHK] Submitting me unto the perilous night
[SHK] And thus unbraced Casca as you see
[SHK] Have bared my bosom to the thunder-stone
[SHK] And when the cross blue lightning seem 'd to open
[SHK] The breast of heaven I did present myself
[SHK] Even in the aim and very flash of it
[SHK] But wherefore did you so much tempt the heavens
[SHK] It is the part of men to fear and tremble
[SHK] When the most mighty gods by tokens send
[SHK] Such dreadful heralds to astonish us
[SHK] You are dull Casca and those sparks of life
[SHK] That should be in a Roman you do want
[SHK] Or else you use not You look pale and gaze
[SHK] And put on fear and cast yourself in wonder
[SHK] To see the strange impatience of the heavens
[SHK] But if you would consider the true cause
[SHK] Why all these fires why all these gliding ghosts
[SHK] Why birds and beasts from quality and kind
[SHK] Why old men fool and children calculate
[SHK] Why all these things change from their ordinance
[SHK] Their natures and preformed faculties
[SHK] To monstrous quality -- why you shall find
[SHK] That heaven hath infused them with these spirits
[SHK] To make them instruments of fear and warning
[SHK] Unto some monstrous state
[SHK] Now could I Casca name to thee a man
[SHK] Most like this dreadful night
[SHK] That thunders lightens opens graves and roars
[SHK] As doth the lion in the Capitol
[SHK] A man no mightier than thyself or me
[SHK] In personal action yet prodigious grown
[SHK] And fearful as these strange eruptions are
[SHK] 'T is Caesar that you mean is it not Cassius
[SHK] Let it be who it is for Romans now
[SHK] Have thews and limbs like to their ancestors
[SHK] But woe the while our fathers minds are dead
[SHK] And we are govern 'd with our mothers spirits
[SHK] Our yoke and sufferance show us womanish
[SHK] Indeed they say the senators tomorrow
[SHK] Mean to establish Caesar as a king
[SHK] And he shall wear his crown by sea and land
[SHK] In every place save here in Italy
[SHK] I know where I will wear this dagger then
[SHK] Cassius from bondage will deliver Cassius
[SHK] Therein ye gods you make the weak most strong
[SHK] Therein ye gods you tyrants do defeat
[SHK] Nor stony tower nor walls of beaten brass
[SHK] Nor airless dungeon nor strong links of iron
[SHK] Can be retentive to the strength of spirit
[SHK] But life being weary of these worldly bars
[SHK] Never lacks power to dismiss itself
[SHK] If I know this know all the world besides
[SHK] That part of tyranny that I do bear
[SHK] I can shake off at pleasure
[SHK] So can I
[SHK] So every bondman in his own hand bears
[SHK] The power to cancel his captivity
[SHK] And why should Caesar be a tyrant then
[SHK] Poor man I know he would not be a wolf
[SHK] But that he sees the Romans are but sheep
[SHK] He were no lion were not Romans hinds
[SHK] Those that with haste will make a mighty fire
[SHK] Begin it with weak straws what trash is Rome
[SHK] What rubbish and what offal when it serves
[SHK] For the base matter to illuminate
[SHK] So vile a thing as Caesar But O grief
[SHK] Where hast thou led me I perhaps speak this
[SHK] Before a willing bondman then I know
[SHK] My answer must be made But I am arm 'd
[SHK] And dangers are to me indifferent
[SHK] You speak to Casca and to such a man
[SHK] That is no fleering tell-tale Hold my hand
[SHK] Be factious for redress of all these griefs
[SHK] And I will set this foot of mine as far
[SHK] As who goes farthest
[SHK] There 's a bargain made
[SHK] Now know you Casca I have moved already
[SHK] Some certain of the noblest-minded Romans
[SHK] To undergo with me an enterprise
[SHK] Of honourable-dangerous consequence
[SHK] And I do know by this they stay for me
[SHK] In Pompey 's porch for now this fearful night
[SHK] There is no stir or walking in the streets
[SHK] And the complexion of the element
[SHK] In favour 's like the work we have in hand
[SHK] Most bloody fiery and most terrible
[SHK] Stand close awhile for here comes one in haste
[SHK] 'T is Cinna I do know him by his gait
[SHK] He is a friend
[SHK] Cinna where haste you so
[SHK] To find out you Who 's that Metellus Cimber
[SHK] No it is Casca one incorporate
[SHK] To our attempts Am I not stay 'd for Cinna
[SHK] I am glad on 't What a fearful night is this
[SHK] There 's two or three of us have seen strange sights
[SHK] Am I not stay 'd for tell me
[SHK] Yes you are
[SHK] O Cassius if you could
[SHK] But win the noble Brutus to our party --
[SHK] Be you content good Cinna take this paper
[SHK] And look you lay it in the praetor 's chair
[SHK] Where Brutus may but find it and throw this
[SHK] In at his window set this up with wax
[SHK] Upon old Brutus statue all this done
[SHK] Repair to Pompey 's porch where you shall find us
[SHK] Is Decius Brutus and Trebonius there
[SHK] All but Metellus Cimber and he 's gone
[SHK] To seek you at your house Well I will hie
[SHK] And so bestow these papers as you bade me
[SHK] That done repair to Pompey 's theatre
[SHK] Come Casca you and I will yet ere day
[SHK] See Brutus at his house three parts of him
[SHK] Is ours already and the man entire
[SHK] Upon the next encounter yields him ours
[SHK] O he sits high in all the people 's hearts
[SHK] And that which would appear offence in us
[SHK] His countenance like richest alchemy
[SHK] Will change to virtue and to worthiness
[SHK] Him and his worth and our great need of him
[SHK] You have right well conceited Let us go
[SHK] For it is after midnight and ere day
[SHK] We will awake him and be sure of him
[SHK] What Lucius ho
[SHK] I can not by the progress of the stars
[SHK] Give guess how near to day Lucius I say
[SHK] I would it were my fault to sleep so soundly
[SHK] When Lucius when awake I say what Lucius
[SHK] Call 'd you my lord
[SHK] Get me a taper in my study Lucius
[SHK] When it is lighted come and call me here
[SHK] I will my lord
[SHK] It must be by his death and for my part
[SHK] I know no personal cause to spurn at him
[SHK] But for the general He would be crown 'd
[SHK] How that might change his nature there 's the question
[SHK] It is the bright day that brings forth the adder
[SHK] And that craves wary walking Crown him -- that --
[SHK] And then I grant we put a sting in him
[SHK] That at his will he may do danger with
[SHK] The abuse of greatness is when it disjoins
[SHK] Remorse from power and to speak truth of Caesar
[SHK] I have not known when his affections sway 'd
[SHK] More than his reason But 't is a common proof
[SHK] That lowliness is young ambition 's ladder
[SHK] Whereto the climber-upward turns his face
[SHK] But when he once attains the upmost round
[SHK] He then unto the ladder turns his back
[SHK] Looks in the clouds scorning the base degrees
[SHK] By which he did ascend So Caesar may
[SHK] Then lest he may prevent And since the quarrel
[SHK] Will bear no colour for the thing he is
[SHK] Fashion it thus that what he is augmented
[SHK] Would run to these and these extremities
[SHK] And therefore think him as a serpent 's egg
[SHK] Which hatch 'd would as his kind grow mischievous
[SHK] And kill him in the shell
[SHK] The taper burneth in your closet sir
[SHK] Searching the window for a flint I found
[SHK] This paper thus seal 'd up and I am sure
[SHK] It did not lie there when I went to bed
[SHK] Get you to bed again it is not day
[SHK] Is not to-morrow boy the ides of March
[SHK] I know not sir
[SHK] Look in the calendar and bring me word
[SHK] I will sir
[SHK] The exhalations whizzing in the air
[SHK] Give so much light that I may read by them
[SHK] 'Brutus thou sleep'st awake and see thyself
[SHK] Shall Rome c. Speak strike redress
[SHK] Brutus thou sleep'st awake
[SHK] Such instigations have been often dropp 'd
[SHK] Where I have took them up
[SHK] 'Shall Rome c. Thus must I piece it out
[SHK] Shall Rome stand under one man 's awe What Rome
[SHK] My ancestors did from the streets of Rome
[SHK] The Tarquin drive when he was call 'd a king
[SHK] 'Speak strike redress Am I entreated
[SHK] To speak and strike O Rome I make thee promise
[SHK] If the redress will follow thou receivest
[SHK] Thy full petition at the hand of Brutus
[SHK] Sir March is wasted fourteen days
[SHK] 'T is good Go to the gate somebody knocks
[SHK] Since Cassius first did whet me against Caesar
[SHK] I have not slept
[SHK] Between the acting of a dreadful thing
[SHK] And the first motion all the interim is
[SHK] Like a phantasma or a hideous dream
[SHK] The Genius and the mortal instruments
[SHK] Are then in council and the state of man
[SHK] Like to a little kingdom suffers then
[SHK] The nature of an insurrection
[SHK] Sir 't is your brother Cassius at the door
[SHK] Who doth desire to see you
[SHK] Is he alone
[SHK] No sir there are moe with him
[SHK] Do you know them
[SHK] No sir their hats are pluck 'd about their ears
[SHK] And half their faces buried in their cloaks
[SHK] That by no means I may discover them
[SHK] By any mark of favour
[SHK] Let 'em enter
[SHK] They are the faction O conspiracy
[SHK] Shamest thou to show thy dangerous brow by night
[SHK] When evils are most free O then by day
[SHK] Where wilt thou find a cavern dark enough
[SHK] To mask thy monstrous visage Seek none conspiracy
[SHK] Hide it in smiles and affability
[SHK] For if thou path thy native semblance on
[SHK] Not Erebus itself were dim enough
[SHK] To hide thee from prevention
[SHK] I think we are too bold upon your rest
[SHK] Good morrow Brutus do we trouble you
[SHK] I have been up this hour awake all night
[SHK] Know I these men that come along with you
[SHK] Yes every man of them and no man here
[SHK] But honours you and every one doth wish
[SHK] You had but that opinion of yourself
[SHK] Which every noble Roman bears of you
[SHK] This is Trebonius
[SHK] He is welcome hither
[SHK] This Decius Brutus
[SHK] He is welcome too
[SHK] This Casca this Cinna and this Metellus Cimber
[SHK] They are all welcome
[SHK] What watchful cares do interpose themselves
[SHK] Betwixt your eyes and night
[SHK] Shall I entreat a word
[SHK] Here lies the east doth not the day break here
[SHK] No
[SHK] O pardon sir it doth and yon gray lines
[SHK] That fret the clouds are messengers of day
[SHK] You shall confess that you are both deceived
[SHK] Here as I point my sword the sun arises
[SHK] Which is a great way growing on the south
[SHK] Weighing the youthful season of the year
[SHK] Some two months hence up higher toward the north
[SHK] He first presents his fire and the high east
[SHK] Stands as the Capitol directly here
[SHK] Give me your hands all over one by one
[SHK] And let us swear our resolution
[SHK] No not an oath if not the face of men
[SHK] The sufferance of our souls the time 's abuse --
[SHK] If these be motives weak break off betimes
[SHK] And every man hence to his idle bed
[SHK] So let high-sighted tyranny range on
[SHK] Till each man drop by lottery But if these
[SHK] As I am sure they do bear fire enough
[SHK] To kindle cowards and to steel with valour
[SHK] The melting spirits of women then countrymen
[SHK] What need we any spur but our own cause
[SHK] To prick us to redress what other bond
[SHK] Than secret Romans that have spoke the word
[SHK] And will not palter and what other oath
[SHK] Than honesty to honesty engaged
[SHK] That this shall be or we will fall for it
[SHK] Swear priests and cowards and men cautelous
[SHK] Old feeble carrions and such suffering souls
[SHK] That welcome wrongs unto bad causes swear
[SHK] Such creatures as men doubt but do not stain
[SHK] The even virtue of our enterprise
[SHK] Nor the insuppressive mettle of our spirits
[SHK] To think that or our cause or our performance
[SHK] Did need an oath when every drop of blood
[SHK] That every Roman bears and nobly bears
[SHK] Is guilty of a several bastardy
[SHK] If he do break the smallest particle
[SHK] Of any promise that hath pass 'd from him
[SHK] But what of Cicero shall we sound him
[SHK] I think he will stand very strong with us
[SHK] Let us not leave him out
[SHK] No by no means
[SHK] O let us have him for his silver hairs
[SHK] Will purchase us a good opinion
[SHK] And buy men 's voices to commend our deeds
[SHK] It shall be said his judgment ruled our hands
[SHK] Our youths and wildness shall no whit appear
[SHK] But all be buried in his gravity
[SHK] O name him not let us not break with him
[SHK] For he will never follow any thing
[SHK] That other men begin
[SHK] Then leave him out
[SHK] Indeed he is not fit
[SHK] Shall no man else be touch 'd but only Caesar
[SHK] Decius well urged I think it is not meet
[SHK] Mark Antony so well beloved of Caesar
[SHK] Should outlive Caesar we shall find of him
[SHK] A shrewd contriver and you know his means
[SHK] If he improve them may well stretch so far
[SHK] As to annoy us all which to prevent
[SHK] Let Antony and Caesar fall together
[SHK] Our course will seem too bloody Caius Cassius
[SHK] To cut the head off and then hack the limbs
[SHK] Like wrath in death and envy afterwards
[SHK] For Antony is but a limb of Caesar
[SHK] Let us be sacrificers but not butchers Caius
[SHK] We all stand up against the spirit of Caesar
[SHK] And in the spirit of men there is no blood
[SHK] O that we then could come by Caesar 's spirit
[SHK] And not dismember Caesar But alas
[SHK] Caesar must bleed for it And gentle friends
[SHK] Let 's kill him boldly but not wrathfully
[SHK] Let 's carve him as a dish fit for the gods
[SHK] Not hew him as a carcass fit for hounds
[SHK] And let our hearts as subtle masters do
[SHK] Stir up their servants to an act of rage
[SHK] And after seem to chide 'em This shall make
[SHK] Our purpose necessary and not envious
[SHK] Which so appearing to the common eyes
[SHK] We shall be call 'd purgers not murderers
[SHK] And for Mark Antony think not of him
[SHK] For he can do no more than Caesar 's arm
[SHK] When Caesar 's head is off
[SHK] Yet I fear him
[SHK] For in the ingrafted love he bears to Caesar --
[SHK] Alas good Cassius do not think of him
[SHK] If he love Caesar all that he can do
[SHK] Is to himself take thought and die for Caesar
[SHK] And that were much he should for he is given
[SHK] To sports to wildness and much company
[SHK] There is no fear in him let him not die
[SHK] For he will live and laugh at this hereafter
[SHK] Peace count the clock
[SHK] The clock hath stricken three
[SHK] 'T is time to part
[SHK] But it is doubtful yet
[SHK] Whether Caesar will come forth to-day or no
[SHK] For he is superstitious grown of late
[SHK] Quite from the main opinion he held once
[SHK] Of fantasy of dreams and ceremonies
[SHK] It may be these apparent prodigies
[SHK] The unaccustom 'd terror of this night
[SHK] And the persuasion of his augurers
[SHK] May hold him from the Capitol to-day
[SHK] Never fear that if he be so resolved
[SHK] I can o'ersway him for he loves to hear
[SHK] That unicorns may be betray 'd with trees
[SHK] And bears with glasses elephants with holes
[SHK] Lions with toils and men with flatterers
[SHK] But when I tell him he hates flatterers
[SHK] He says he does being then most flattered
[SHK] Let me work
[SHK] For I can give his humour the true bent
[SHK] And I will bring him to the Capitol
[SHK] Nay we will all of us be there to fetch him
[SHK] By the eighth hour is that the uttermost
[SHK] Be that the uttermost and fail not then
[SHK] Caius Ligarius doth bear Caesar hard
[SHK] Who rated him for speaking well of Pompey
[SHK] I wonder none of you have thought of him
[SHK] Now good Metellus go along by him
[SHK] He loves me well and I have given him reasons
[SHK] Send him but hither and I 'll fashion him
[SHK] The morning comes upon 's we 'll leave you Brutus
[SHK] And friends disperse yourselves but all remember
[SHK] What you have said and show yourselves true Romans
[SHK] Good gentlemen look fresh and merrily
[SHK] Let not our looks put on our purposes
[SHK] But bear it as our Roman actors do
[SHK] With untired spirits and formal constancy
[SHK] And so good morrow to you every one
[SHK] Boy Lucius Fast asleep It is no matter
[SHK] Enjoy the honey-heavy dew of slumber
[SHK] Thou hast no figures nor no fantasies
[SHK] Which busy care draws in the brains of men
[SHK] Therefore thou sleep'st so sound
[SHK] Brutus my lord
[SHK] Portia what mean you wherefore rise you now
[SHK] It is not for your health thus to commit
[SHK] Your weak condition to the raw cold morning
[SHK] Nor for yours neither You 've ungently Brutus
[SHK] Stole from my bed and yesternight at supper
[SHK] You suddenly arose and walk 'd about
[SHK] Musing and sighing with your arms across
[SHK] And when I ask 'd you what the matter was
[SHK] You stared upon me with ungentle looks
[SHK] I urged you further then you scratch 'd your head
[SHK] And too impatiently stamp 'd with your foot
[SHK] Yet I insisted yet you answer 'd not
[SHK] But with an angry wafture of your hand
[SHK] Gave sign for me to leave you so I did
[SHK] Fearing to strengthen that impatience
[SHK] Which seem 'd too much enkindled and withal
[SHK] Hoping it was but an effect of humour
[SHK] Which sometime hath his hour with every man
[SHK] It will not let you eat nor talk nor sleep
[SHK] And could it work so much upon your shape
[SHK] As it hath much prevail 'd on your condition
[SHK] I should not know you Brutus Dear my lord
[SHK] Make me acquainted with your cause of grief
[SHK] I am not well in health and that is all
[SHK] Brutus is wise and were he not in health
[SHK] He would embrace the means to come by it
[SHK] Why so I do Good Portia go to bed
[SHK] Is Brutus sick and is it physical
[SHK] To walk unbraced and suck up the humours
[SHK] Of the dank morning What is Brutus sick
[SHK] And will he steal out of his wholesome bed
[SHK] To dare the vile contagion of the night
[SHK] And tempt the rheumy and unpurged air
[SHK] To add unto his sickness No my Brutus
[SHK] You have some sick offence within your mind
[SHK] Which by the right and virtue of my place
[SHK] I ought to know of and upon my knees
[SHK] I charm you by my once-commended beauty
[SHK] By all your vows of love and that great vow
[SHK] Which did incorporate and make us one
[SHK] That you unfold to me yourself your half
[SHK] Why you are heavy and what men to-night
[SHK] Have had to resort to you for here have been
[SHK] Some six or seven who did hide their faces
[SHK] Even from darkness
[SHK] Kneel not gentle Portia
[SHK] I should not need if you were gentle Brutus
[SHK] Within the bond of marriage tell me Brutus
[SHK] Is it excepted I should know no secrets
[SHK] That appertain to you Am I yourself
[SHK] But as it were in sort or limitation
[SHK] To keep with you at meals comfort your bed
[SHK] And talk to you sometimes Dwell I but in the suburbs
[SHK] Of your good pleasure If it be no more
[SHK] Portia is Brutus harlot not his wife
[SHK] You are my true and honourable wife
[SHK] As dear to me as are the ruddy drops
[SHK] That visit my sad heart
[SHK] If this were true then should I know this secret
[SHK] I grant I am a woman but withal
[SHK] A woman that Lord Brutus took to wife
[SHK] I grant I am a woman but withal
[SHK] A woman well-reputed Cato 's daughter
[SHK] Think you I am no stronger than my sex
[SHK] Being so father 'd and so husbanded
[SHK] Tell me your counsels I will not disclose 'em
[SHK] I have made strong proof of my constancy
[SHK] Giving myself a voluntary wound
[SHK] Here in the thigh can I bear that with patience
[SHK] And not my husband 's secrets
[SHK] O ye gods
[SHK] Render me worthy of this noble wife
[SHK] Hark hark one knocks Portia go in awhile
[SHK] And by and by thy bosom shall partake
[SHK] The secrets of my heart
[SHK] All my engagements I will construe to thee
[SHK] All the charactery of my sad brows
[SHK] Leave me with haste
[SHK] Lucius who 's that knocks
[SHK] He is a sick man that would speak with you
[SHK] Caius Ligarius that Metellus spake of
[SHK] Boy stand aside Caius Ligarius how
[SHK] Vouchsafe good morrow from a feeble tongue
[SHK] O what a time have you chose out brave Caius
[SHK] To wear a kerchief Would you were not sick
[SHK] I am not sick if Brutus have in hand
[SHK] Any exploit worthy the name of honour
[SHK] Such an exploit have I in hand Ligarius
[SHK] Had you a healthful ear to hear of it
[SHK] By all the gods that Romans bow before
[SHK] I here discard my sickness Soul of Rome
[SHK] Brave son derived from honourable loins
[SHK] Thou like an exorcist hast conjured up
[SHK] My mortified spirit Now bid me run
[SHK] And I will strive with things impossible
[SHK] Yea get the better of them What 's to do
[SHK] A piece of work that will make sick men whole
[SHK] But are not some whole that we must make sick
[SHK] That must we also What it is my Caius
[SHK] I shall unfold to thee as we are going
[SHK] To whom it must be done
[SHK] Set on your foot
[SHK] And with a heart new-fired I follow you
[SHK] To do I know not what but it sufficeth
[SHK] That Brutus leads me on
[SHK] Follow me then
[SHK] Nor heaven nor earth have been at peace to-night
[SHK] Thrice hath Calpurnia in her sleep cried out
[SHK] 'Help ho they murder Caesar Who 's within
[SHK] My lord
[SHK] Go bid the priests do present sacrifice
[SHK] And bring me their opinions of success
[SHK] I will my lord
[SHK] What mean you Caesar think you to walk forth
[SHK] You shall not stir out of your house to-day
[SHK] Caesar shall forth the things that threaten 'd me
[SHK] Ne'er look 'd but on my back when they shall see
[SHK] The face of Caesar they are vanished
[SHK] Caesar I never stood on ceremonies
[SHK] Yet now they fright me There is one within
[SHK] Besides the things that we have heard and seen
[SHK] Recounts most horrid sights seen by the watch
[SHK] A lioness hath whelped in the streets
[SHK] And graves have yawn 'd and yielded up their dead
[SHK] Fierce fiery warriors fought upon the clouds
[SHK] In ranks and squadrons and right form of war
[SHK] Which drizzled blood upon the Capitol
[SHK] The noise of battle hurtled in the air
[SHK] Horses did neigh and dying men did groan
[SHK] And ghosts did shriek and squeal about the streets
[SHK] O Caesar these things are beyond all use
[SHK] And I do fear them
[SHK] What can be avoided
[SHK] Whose end is purposed by the mighty gods
[SHK] Yet Caesar shall go forth for these predictions
[SHK] Are to the world in general as to Caesar
[SHK] When beggars die there are no comets seen
[SHK] The heavens themselves blaze forth the death of princes
[SHK] Cowards die many times before their deaths
[SHK] The valiant never taste of death but once
[SHK] Of all the wonders that I yet have heard
[SHK] It seems to me most strange that men should fear
[SHK] Seeing that death a necessary end
[SHK] Will come when it will come
[SHK] What say the augurers
[SHK] They would not have you to stir forth to-day
[SHK] Plucking the entrails of an offering forth
[SHK] They could not find a heart within the beast
[SHK] The gods do this in shame of cowardice
[SHK] Caesar should be a beast without a heart
[SHK] If he should stay at home to-day for fear
[SHK] No Caesar shall not danger knows full well
[SHK] That Caesar is more dangerous than he
[SHK] We are two lions litter 'd in one day
[SHK] And I the elder and more terrible
[SHK] And Caesar shall go forth
[SHK] Alas my lord
[SHK] Your wisdom is consumed in confidence
[SHK] Do not go forth to-day call it my fear
[SHK] That keeps you in the house and not your own
[SHK] We 'll send Mark Antony to the senate-house
[SHK] And he shall say you are not well to-day
[SHK] Let me upon my knee prevail in this
[SHK] Mark Antony shall say I am not well
[SHK] And for thy humour I will stay at home
[SHK] Here 's Decius Brutus he shall tell them so
[SHK] Caesar all hail good morrow worthy Caesar
[SHK] I come to fetch you to the senate-house
[SHK] And you are come in very happy time
[SHK] To bear my greeting to the senators
[SHK] And tell them that I will not come to-day
[SHK] Can not is false and that I dare not falser
[SHK] I will not come to-day tell them so Decius
[SHK] Say he is sick
[SHK] Shall Caesar send a lie
[SHK] Have I in conquest stretch 'd mine arm so far
[SHK] To be afraid to tell graybeards the truth
[SHK] Decius go tell them Caesar will not come
[SHK] Most mighty Caesar let me know some cause
[SHK] Lest I be laugh 'd at when I tell them so
[SHK] The cause is in my will I will not come
[SHK] That is enough to satisfy the senate
[SHK] But for your private satisfaction
[SHK] Because I love you I will let you know
[SHK] Calpurnia here my wife stays me at home
[SHK] She dreamt to-night she saw my statua
[SHK] Which like a fountain with an hundred spouts
[SHK] Did run pure blood and many lusty Romans
[SHK] Came smiling and did bathe their hands in it
[SHK] And these does she apply for warnings and portents
[SHK] And evils imminent and on her knee
[SHK] Hath begg 'd that I will stay at home to-day
[SHK] This dream is all amiss interpreted
[SHK] It was a vision fair and fortunate
[SHK] Your statue spouting blood in many pipes
[SHK] In which so many smiling Romans bathed
[SHK] Signifies that from you great Rome shall suck
[SHK] Reviving blood and that great men shall press
[SHK] For tinctures stains relics and cognizance
[SHK] This by Calpurnia 's dream is signified
[SHK] And this way have you well expounded it
[SHK] I have when you have heard what I can say
[SHK] And know it now the senate have concluded
[SHK] To give this day a crown to mighty Caesar
[SHK] If you shall send them word you will not come
[SHK] Their minds may change Besides it were a mock
[SHK] Apt to be render 'd for some one to say
[SHK] 'Break up the senate till another time
[SHK] When Caesar 's wife shall meet with better dreams
[SHK] If Caesar hide himself shall they not whisper
[SHK] 'Lo Caesar is afraid
[SHK] Pardon me Caesar for my dear dear love
[SHK] To our proceeding bids me tell you this
[SHK] And reason to my love is liable
[SHK] How foolish do your fears seem now Calpurnia
[SHK] I am ashamed I did yield to them
[SHK] Give me my robe for I will go
[SHK] And look where Publius is come to fetch me
[SHK] Good morrow Caesar
[SHK] Welcome Publius
[SHK] What Brutus are you stirr 'd so early too
[SHK] Good morrow Casca Caius Ligarius
[SHK] Caesar was ne'er so much your enemy
[SHK] As that same ague which hath made you lean
[SHK] What is 't o'clock
[SHK] Caesar 't is strucken eight
[SHK] I thank you for your pains and courtesy
[SHK] See Antony that revels long o nights
[SHK] Is notwithstanding up Good morrow Antony
[SHK] So to most noble Caesar
[SHK] Bid them prepare within
[SHK] I am to blame to be thus waited for
[SHK] Now Cinna now Metellus what Trebonius
[SHK] I have an hour 's talk in store for you
[SHK] Remember that you call on me to-day
[SHK] Be near me that I may remember you
[SHK] Caesar I will
[SHK] and so near will I be
[SHK] That your best friends shall wish I had been further
[SHK] Good friends go in and taste some wine with me
[SHK] And we like friends will straightway go together
[SHK] The heart of Brutus yearns to think upon
[SHK] 'Caesar beware of Brutus take heed of Cassius
[SHK] come not near Casca have an eye to Cinna trust not
[SHK] Trebonius mark well Metellus Cimber Decius Brutus
[SHK] loves thee not thou hast wronged Caius Ligarius
[SHK] There is but one mind in all these men and it is
[SHK] bent against Caesar If thou beest not immortal
[SHK] look about you security gives way to conspiracy
[SHK] The mighty gods defend thee Thy lover
[SHK] 'ARTEMIDORUS
[SHK] Here will I stand till Caesar pass along
[SHK] And as a suitor will I give him this
[SHK] My heart laments that virtue can not live
[SHK] Out of the teeth of emulation
[SHK] If thou read this O Caesar thou mayst live
[SHK] If not the Fates with traitors do contrive
[SHK] I prithee boy run to the senate-house
[SHK] Stay not to answer me but get thee gone
[SHK] Why dost thou stay
[SHK] To know my errand madam
[SHK] I would have had thee there and here again
[SHK] Ere I can tell thee what thou shouldst do there
[SHK] O constancy be strong upon my side
[SHK] Set a huge mountain 'tween my heart and tongue
[SHK] I have a man 's mind but a woman 's might
[SHK] How hard it is for women to keep counsel
[SHK] Art thou here yet
[SHK] Madam what should I do
[SHK] Run to the Capitol and nothing else
[SHK] And so return to you and nothing else
[SHK] Yes bring me word boy if thy lord look well
[SHK] For he went sickly forth and take good note
[SHK] What Caesar doth what suitors press to him
[SHK] Hark boy what noise is that
[SHK] I hear none madam
[SHK] Prithee listen well
[SHK] I heard a bustling rumour like a fray
[SHK] And the wind brings it from the Capitol
[SHK] Sooth madam I hear nothing
[SHK] Come hither fellow which way hast thou been
[SHK] At mine own house good lady
[SHK] What is't o'clock
[SHK] About the ninth hour lady
[SHK] Is Caesar yet gone to the Capitol
[SHK] Madam not yet I go to take my stand
[SHK] To see him pass on to the Capitol
[SHK] Thou hast some suit to Caesar hast thou not
[SHK] That I have lady if it will please Caesar
[SHK] To be so good to Caesar as to hear me
[SHK] I shall beseech him to befriend himself
[SHK] Why know'st thou any harm 's intended towards him
[SHK] None that I know will be much that I fear may chance
[SHK] Good morrow to you Here the street is narrow
[SHK] The throng that follows Caesar at the heels
[SHK] Of senators of praetors common suitors
[SHK] Will crowd a feeble man almost to death
[SHK] I 'll get me to a place more void and there
[SHK] Speak to great Caesar as he comes along
[SHK] I must go in Ay me how weak a thing
[SHK] The heart of woman is O Brutus
[SHK] The heavens speed thee in thine enterprise
[SHK] Sure the boy heard me Brutus hath a suit
[SHK] That Caesar will not grant O I grow faint
[SHK] Run Lucius and commend me to my lord
[SHK] Say I am merry come to me again
[SHK] And bring me word what he doth say to thee
[SHK] Ay Caesar but not gone
[SHK] Hail Caesar read this schedule
[SHK] Trebonius doth desire you to o'erread
[SHK] At your best leisure this his humble suit
[SHK] O Caesar read mine first for mine 's a suit
[SHK] That touches Caesar nearer read it great Caesar
[SHK] What touches us ourself shall be last served
[SHK] Delay not Caesar read it instantly
[SHK] What is the fellow mad
[SHK] Sirrah give place
[SHK] What urge you your petitions in the street
[SHK] Come to the Capitol
[SHK] I wish your enterprise to-day may thrive
[SHK] What enterprise Popilius
[SHK] Fare you well
[SHK] What said Popilius Lena
[SHK] He wish 'd to-day our enterprise might thrive
[SHK] I fear our purpose is discovered
[SHK] Look how he makes to Caesar mark him
[SHK] Casca be sudden for we fear prevention
[SHK] Brutus what shall be done If this be known
[SHK] Cassius or Caesar never shall turn back
[SHK] For I will slay myself
[SHK] Cassius be constant
[SHK] Popilius Lena speaks not of our purposes
[SHK] For look he smiles and Caesar doth not change
[SHK] Trebonius knows his time for look you Brutus
[SHK] He draws Mark Antony out of the way
[SHK] Where is Metellus Cimber Let him go
[SHK] And presently prefer his suit to Caesar
[SHK] He is address 'd press near and second him
[SHK] Casca you are the first that rears your hand
[SHK] Are we all ready What is now amiss
[SHK] That Caesar and his senate must redress
[SHK] Most high most mighty and most puissant Caesar
[SHK] Metellus Cimber throws before thy seat
[SHK] An humble heart --
[SHK] I must prevent thee Cimber
[SHK] These couchings and these lowly courtesies
[SHK] Might fire the blood of ordinary men
[SHK] And turn pre-ordinance and first decree
[SHK] Into the law of children Be not fond
[SHK] To think that Caesar bears such rebel blood
[SHK] That will be thaw 'd from the true quality
[SHK] With that which melteth fools I mean sweet words
[SHK] Low-crooked court'sies and base spaniel-fawning
[SHK] Thy brother by decree is banished
[SHK] If thou dost bend and pray and fawn for him
[SHK] I spurn thee like a cur out of my way
[SHK] Know Caesar doth not wrong nor without cause
[SHK] Will he be satisfied
[SHK] Is there no voice more worthy than my own
[SHK] To sound more sweetly in great Caesar 's ear
[SHK] For the repealing of my banish 'd brother
[SHK] I kiss thy hand but not in flattery Caesar
[SHK] Desiring thee that Publius Cimber may
[SHK] Have an immediate freedom of repeal
[SHK] What Brutus
[SHK] Pardon Caesar Caesar pardon
[SHK] As low as to thy foot doth Cassius fall
[SHK] To beg enfranchisement for Publius Cimber
[SHK] I could be well moved if I were as you
[SHK] If I could pray to move prayers would move me
[SHK] But I am constant as the northern star
[SHK] Of whose true-fix 'd and resting quality
[SHK] There is no fellow in the firmament
[SHK] The skies are painted with unnumber 'd sparks
[SHK] They are all fire and every one doth shine
[SHK] But there 's but one in all doth hold his place
[SHK] So in the world 't is furnish 'd well with men
[SHK] And men are flesh and blood and apprehensive
[SHK] Yet in the number I do know but one
[SHK] That unassailable holds on his rank
[SHK] Unshaked of motion and that I am he
[SHK] Let me a little show it even in this
[SHK] That I was constant Cimber should be banish 'd
[SHK] And constant do remain to keep him so
[SHK] O Caesar --
[SHK] Hence wilt thou lift up Olympus
[SHK] Great Caesar --
[SHK] Doth not Brutus bootless kneel
[SHK] Speak hands for me
[SHK] Et tu Brute Then fall Caesar
[SHK] Liberty Freedom Tyranny is dead
[SHK] Run hence proclaim cry it about the streets
[SHK] Some to the common pulpits and cry out
[SHK] 'Liberty freedom and enfranchisement
[SHK] People and senators be not affrighted
[SHK] Fly not stand stiff ambition 's debt is paid
[SHK] Go to the pulpit Brutus
[SHK] And Cassius too
[SHK] Where 's Publius
[SHK] Here quite confounded with this mutiny
[SHK] Stand fast together lest some friend of Caesar 's
[SHK] Should chance --
[SHK] Talk not of standing Publius good cheer
[SHK] There is no harm intended to your person
[SHK] Nor to no Roman else so tell them Publius
[SHK] And leave us Publius lest that the people
[SHK] Rushing on us should do your age some mischief
[SHK] Do so and let no man abide this deed
[SHK] But we the doers
[SHK] Where is Antony
[SHK] Fled to his house amazed
[SHK] Men wives and children stare cry out and run
[SHK] As it were doomsday
[SHK] Fates we will know your pleasures
[SHK] That we shall die we know 't is but the time
[SHK] And drawing days out that men stand upon
[SHK] Why he that cuts off twenty years of life
[SHK] Cuts off so many years of fearing death
[SHK] Grant that and then is death a benefit
[SHK] So are we Caesar 's friends that have abridged
[SHK] His time of fearing death Stoop Romans stoop
[SHK] And let us bathe our hands in Caesar 's blood
[SHK] Up to the elbows and besmear our swords
[SHK] Then walk we forth even to the market-place
[SHK] And waving our red weapons o'er our heads
[SHK] Let 's all cry 'Peace freedom and liberty
[SHK] Stoop then and wash. How many ages hence
[SHK] Shall this our lofty scene be acted over
[SHK] In states unborn and accents yet unknown
[SHK] How many times shall Caesar bleed in sport
[SHK] That now on Pompey 's basis lies along
[SHK] No worthier than the dust
[SHK] So oft as that shall be
[SHK] So often shall the knot of us be call 'd
[SHK] The men that gave their country liberty
[SHK] What shall we forth
[SHK] Ay every man away
[SHK] Brutus shall lead and we will grace his heels
[SHK] With the most boldest and best hearts of Rome
[SHK] Soft who comes here A friend of Antony 's
[SHK] Thus Brutus did my master bid me kneel
[SHK] Thus did Mark Antony bid me fall down
[SHK] And being prostrate thus he bade me say
[SHK] Brutus is noble wise valiant and honest
[SHK] Caesar was mighty bold royal and loving
[SHK] Say I love Brutus and I honour him
[SHK] Say I fear 'd Caesar honour 'd him and loved him
[SHK] If Brutus will vouchsafe that Antony
[SHK] May safely come to him and be resolved
[SHK] How Caesar hath deserved to lie in death
[SHK] Mark Antony shall not love Caesar dead
[SHK] So well as Brutus living but will follow
[SHK] The fortunes and affairs of noble Brutus
[SHK] Thorough the hazards of this untrod state
[SHK] With all true faith So says my master Antony
[SHK] Thy master is a wise and valiant Roman
[SHK] I never thought him worse
[SHK] Tell him so please him come unto this place
[SHK] He shall be satisfied and by my honour
[SHK] Depart untouch 'd
[SHK] I 'll fetch him presently
[SHK] I know that we shall have him well to friend
[SHK] I wish we may but yet have I a mind
[SHK] That fears him much and my misgiving still
[SHK] Falls shrewdly to the purpose
[SHK] But here comes Antony
[SHK] Welcome Mark Antony
[SHK] O mighty Caesar dost thou lie so low
[SHK] Are all thy conquests glories triumphs spoils
[SHK] Shrunk to this little measure Fare thee well
[SHK] I know not gentlemen what you intend
[SHK] Who else must be let blood who else is rank
[SHK] If I myself there is no hour so fit
[SHK] As Caesar 's death hour nor no instrument
[SHK] Of half that worth as those your swords made rich
[SHK] With the most noble blood of all this world
[SHK] I do beseech ye if you bear me hard
[SHK] Now whilst your purpled hands do reek and smoke
[SHK] Fulfil your pleasure Live a thousand years
[SHK] I shall not find myself so apt to die
[SHK] No place will please me so no mean of death
[SHK] As here by Caesar and by you cut off
[SHK] The choice and master spirits of this age
[SHK] O Antony beg not your death of us
[SHK] Though now we must appear bloody and cruel
[SHK] As by our hands and this our present act
[SHK] You see we do yet see you but our hands
[SHK] And this the bleeding business they have done
[SHK] Our hearts you see not they are pitiful
[SHK] And pity to the general wrong of Rome --
[SHK] As fire drives out fire so pity pity --
[SHK] Hath done this deed on Caesar For your part
[SHK] To you our swords have leaden points Mark Antony
[SHK] Our arms in strength of malice and our hearts
[SHK] Of brothers temper do receive you in
[SHK] With all kind love good thoughts and reverence
[SHK] Your voice shall be as strong as any man 's
[SHK] In the disposing of new dignities
[SHK] Only be patient till we have appeased
[SHK] The multitude beside themselves with fear
[SHK] And then we will deliver you the cause
[SHK] Why I that did love Caesar when I struck him
[SHK] Have thus proceeded
[SHK] I doubt not of your wisdom
[SHK] Let each man render me his bloody hand
[SHK] First Marcus Brutus will I shake with you
[SHK] Next Caius Cassius do I take your hand
[SHK] Now Decius Brutus yours now yours Metellus
[SHK] Yours Cinna and my valiant Casca yours
[SHK] Though last not last in love yours good Trebonius
[SHK] Gentlemen all -- alas what shall I say
[SHK] My credit now stands on such slippery ground
[SHK] That one of two bad ways you must conceit me
[SHK] Either a coward or a flatterer
[SHK] That I did love thee Caesar O 't is true
[SHK] If then thy spirit look upon us now
[SHK] Shall it not grieve thee dearer than thy death
[SHK] To see thy thy Anthony making his peace
[SHK] Shaking the bloody fingers of thy foes
[SHK] Most noble in the presence of thy corse
[SHK] Had I as many eyes as thou hast wounds
[SHK] Weeping as fast as they stream forth thy blood
[SHK] It would become me better than to close
[SHK] In terms of friendship with thine enemies
[SHK] Pardon me Julius Here wast thou bay 'd brave hart
[SHK] Here didst thou fall and here thy hunters stand
[SHK] Sign 'd in thy spoil and crimson 'd in thy lethe
[SHK] O world thou wast the forest to this hart
[SHK] And this indeed O world the heart of thee
[SHK] How like a deer strucken by many princes
[SHK] Dost thou here lie
[SHK] Mark Antony --
[SHK] Pardon me Caius Cassius
[SHK] The enemies of Caesar shall say this
[SHK] Then in a friend it is cold modesty
[SHK] I blame you not for praising Caesar so
[SHK] But what compact mean you to have with us
[SHK] Will you be prick 'd in number of our friends
[SHK] Or shall we on and not depend on you
[SHK] Therefore I took your hands but was indeed
[SHK] Sway 'd from the point by looking down on Caesar
[SHK] Friends am I with you all and love you all
[SHK] Upon this hope that you shall give me reasons
[SHK] Why and wherein Caesar was dangerous
[SHK] Or else were this a savage spectacle
[SHK] Our reasons are so full of good regard
[SHK] That were you Antony the son of Caesar
[SHK] You should be satisfied
[SHK] That 's all I seek
[SHK] And am moreover suitor that I may
[SHK] Produce his body to the market-place
[SHK] And in the pulpit as becomes a friend
[SHK] Speak in the order of his funeral
[SHK] You shall Mark Antony
[SHK] Brutus a word with you
[SHK] You know not what you do do not consent
[SHK] That Antony speak in his funeral
[SHK] Know you how much the people may be moved
[SHK] By that which he will utter
[SHK] By your pardon
[SHK] I will myself into the pulpit first
[SHK] And show the reason of our Caesar 's death
[SHK] What Antony shall speak I will protest
[SHK] He speaks by leave and by permission
[SHK] And that we are contented Caesar shall
[SHK] Have all true rites and lawful ceremonies
[SHK] It shall advantage more than do us wrong
[SHK] I know not what may fall I like it not
[SHK] Mark Antony here take you Caesar 's body
[SHK] You shall not in your funeral speech blame us
[SHK] But speak all good you can devise of Caesar
[SHK] And say you do't by our permission
[SHK] Else shall you not have any hand at all
[SHK] About his funeral and you shall speak
[SHK] In the same pulpit whereto I am going
[SHK] After my speech is ended
[SHK] Be it so
[SHK] I do desire no more
[SHK] Prepare the body then and follow us
[SHK] O pardon me thou bleeding piece of earth
[SHK] That I am meek and gentle with these butchers
[SHK] Thou art the ruins of the noblest man
[SHK] That ever lived in the tide of times
[SHK] Woe to the hand that shed this costly blood
[SHK] Over thy wounds now do I prophesy --
[SHK] Which like dumb mouths do ope their ruby lips
[SHK] To beg the voice and utterance of my tongue --
[SHK] A curse shall light upon the limbs of men
[SHK] Domestic fury and fierce civil strife
[SHK] Shall cumber all the parts of Italy
[SHK] Blood and destruction shall be so in use
[SHK] And dreadful objects so familiar
[SHK] That mothers shall but smile when they behold
[SHK] Their infants quarter 'd with the hands of war
[SHK] All pity choked with custom of fell deeds
[SHK] And Caesar 's spirit ranging for revenge
[SHK] With Ate by his side come hot from hell
[SHK] Shall in these confines with a monarch 's voice
[SHK] Cry 'Havoc and let slip the dogs of war
[SHK] That this foul deed shall smell above the earth
[SHK] With carrion men groaning for burial
[SHK] You serve Octavius Caesar do you not
[SHK] I do Mark Antony
[SHK] Caesar did write for him to come to Rome
[SHK] He did receive his letters and is coming
[SHK] And bid me say to you by word of mouth --
[SHK] O Caesar --
[SHK] Thy heart is big get thee apart and weep
[SHK] Passion I see is catching for mine eyes
[SHK] Seeing those beads of sorrow stand in thine
[SHK] Began to water Is thy master coming
[SHK] He lies to-night within seven leagues of Rome
[SHK] Post back with speed and tell him what hath chanced
[SHK] Here is a mourning Rome a dangerous Rome
[SHK] No Rome of safety for Octavius yet
[SHK] Hie hence and tell him so Yet stay awhile
[SHK] Thou shalt not back till I have borne this corse
[SHK] Into the market-place there shall I try
[SHK] In my oration how the people take
[SHK] The cruel issue of these bloody men
[SHK] According to the which thou shalt discourse
[SHK] To young Octavius of the state of things
[SHK] Lend me your hand
[SHK] We will be satisfied let us be satisfied
[SHK] Then follow me and give me audience friends
[SHK] Cassius go you into the other street
[SHK] And part the numbers
[SHK] Those that will hear me speak let 'em stay here
[SHK] Those that will follow Cassius go with him
[SHK] And public reasons shall be rendered
[SHK] Of Caesar 's death
[SHK] I will hear Brutus speak
[SHK] I will hear Cassius and compare their reasons
[SHK] When severally we hear them rendered
[SHK] The noble Brutus is ascended silence
[SHK] Be patient till the last
[SHK] Romans countrymen and lovers hear me for my
[SHK] cause and be silent that you may hear believe me
[SHK] for mine honour and have respect to mine honour that
[SHK] you may believe censure me in your wisdom and
[SHK] awake your senses that you may the better judge
[SHK] If there be any in this assembly any dear friend of
[SHK] Caesar 's to him I say that Brutus love to Caesar
[SHK] was no less than his If then that friend demand
[SHK] why Brutus rose against Caesar this is my answer
[SHK] -- Not that I loved Caesar less but that I loved
[SHK] Rome more Had you rather Caesar were living and
[SHK] die all slaves than that Caesar were dead to live
[SHK] all free men As Caesar loved me I weep for him
[SHK] as he was fortunate I rejoice at it as he was
[SHK] valiant I honour him but as he was ambitious I
[SHK] slew him There is tears for his love joy for his
[SHK] fortune honour for his valour and death for his
[SHK] ambition Who is here so base that would be a
[SHK] bondman If any speak for him have I offended
[SHK] Who is here so rude that would not be a Roman If
[SHK] any speak for him have I offended Who is here so
[SHK] vile that will not love his country If any speak
[SHK] for him have I offended I pause for a reply
[SHK] None Brutus none
[SHK] Then none have I offended I have done no more to
[SHK] Caesar than you shall do to Brutus The question of
[SHK] his death is enrolled in the Capitol his glory not
[SHK] extenuated wherein he was worthy nor his offences
[SHK] enforced for which he suffered death
[SHK] Here comes his body mourned by Mark Antony who
[SHK] though he had no hand in his death shall receive
[SHK] the benefit of his dying a place in the
[SHK] commonwealth as which of you shall not With this
[SHK] I depart -- that as I slew my best lover for the
[SHK] good of Rome I have the same dagger for myself
[SHK] when it shall please my country to need my death
[SHK] Live Brutus live live
[SHK] Bring him with triumph home unto his house
[SHK] Give him a statue with his ancestors
[SHK] Let him be Caesar
[SHK] Caesar 's better parts
[SHK] Shall be crown 'd in Brutus
[SHK] We 'll bring him to his house
[SHK] With shouts and clamours
[SHK] My countrymen --
[SHK] Peace silence Brutus speaks
[SHK] Peace ho
[SHK] Good countrymen let me depart alone
[SHK] And for my sake stay here with Antony
[SHK] Do grace to Caesar 's corpse and grace his speech
[SHK] Tending to Caesar 's glories which Mark Antony
[SHK] By our permission is allow 'd to make
[SHK] I do entreat you not a man depart
[SHK] Save I alone till Antony have spoke
[SHK] Stay ho and let us hear Mark Antony
[SHK] Let him go up into the public chair
[SHK] We 'll hear him Noble Antony go up
[SHK] For Brutus sake I am beholding to you
[SHK] What does he say of Brutus
[SHK] He says for Brutus sake
[SHK] He finds himself beholding to us all
[SHK] 'Twere best he speak no harm of Brutus here
[SHK] This Caesar was a tyrant
[SHK] Nay that 's certain
[SHK] We are blest that Rome is rid of him
[SHK] Peace let us hear what Antony can say
[SHK] You gentle Romans --
[SHK] Peace ho let us hear him
[SHK] Friends Romans countrymen lend me your ears
[SHK] I come to bury Caesar not to praise him
[SHK] The evil that men do lives after them
[SHK] The good is oft interred with their bones
[SHK] So let it be with Caesar The noble Brutus
[SHK] Hath told you Caesar was ambitious
[SHK] If it were so it was a grievous fault
[SHK] And grievously hath Caesar answer 'd it
[SHK] Here under leave of Brutus and the rest --
[SHK] For Brutus is an honourable man
[SHK] So are they all all honourable men --
[SHK] Come I to speak in Caesar 's funeral
[SHK] He was my friend faithful and just to me
[SHK] But Brutus says he was ambitious
[SHK] And Brutus is an honourable man
[SHK] He hath brought many captives home to Rome
[SHK] Whose ransoms did the general coffers fill
[SHK] Did this in Caesar seem ambitious
[SHK] When that the poor have cried Caesar hath wept
[SHK] Ambition should be made of sterner stuff
[SHK] Yet Brutus says he was ambitious
[SHK] And Brutus is an honourable man
[SHK] You all did see that on the Lupercal
[SHK] I thrice presented him a kingly crown
[SHK] Which he did thrice refuse was this ambition
[SHK] Yet Brutus says he was ambitious
[SHK] And sure he is an honourable man
[SHK] I speak not to disprove what Brutus spoke
[SHK] But here I am to speak what I do know
[SHK] You all did love him once not without cause
[SHK] What cause withholds you then to mourn for him
[SHK] O judgment thou art fled to brutish beasts
[SHK] And men have lost their reason Bear with me
[SHK] My heart is in the coffin there with Caesar
[SHK] And I must pause till it come back to me
[SHK] Methinks there is much reason in his sayings
[SHK] If thou consider rightly of the matter

[SHK] Has he masters
[SHK] I fear there will a worse come in his place

[SHK] Have stood against the world now lies he there

[SHK] Who you all know are honourable men

[SHK] I have as much of this in art as you
[SHK] But yet my nature could not bear it so
[SHK] Well to our work alive What do you think
[SHK] Of marching to Philippi presently
[SHK] I do not think it good
[SHK] Your reason
[SHK] This it is
[SHK] 'T is better that the enemy seek us
[SHK] So shall he waste his means weary his soldiers
[SHK] Doing himself offence whilst we lying still
[SHK] Are full of rest defense and nimbleness
[SHK] Good reasons must of force give place to better
[SHK] The people 'twixt Philippi and this ground
[SHK] Do stand but in a forced affection
[SHK] For they have grudged us contribution
[SHK] The enemy marching along by them
[SHK] By them shall make a fuller number up
[SHK] Come on refresh 'd new-added and encouraged
[SHK] From which advantage shall we cut him off
[SHK] If at Philippi we do face him there
[SHK] These people at our back
[SHK] Hear me good brother
[SHK] Under your pardon You must note beside
[SHK] That we have tried the utmost of our friends
[SHK] Our legions are brim-full our cause is ripe
[SHK] The enemy increaseth every day
[SHK] We at the height are ready to decline
[SHK] There is a tide in the affairs of men
[SHK] Which taken at the flood leads on to fortune
[SHK] Omitted all the voyage of their life
[SHK] Is bound in shallows and in miseries

[SHK] And we must take the current when it serves

[SHK] Which we will niggard with a little rest

[SHK] You know that I held Epicurus strong

[SHK] Two mighty eagles fell and there they perch 'd

[SHK] Fly o'er our heads and downward look on us

[SHK] A canopy most fatal under which
[SHK] Our army lies ready to give up the ghost

[SHK] For I am fresh of spirit and resolved
[SHK] To meet all perils very constantly
[SHK] Even so Lucilius

[SHK] The gods to-day stand friendly that we may

[SHK] By which I did blame Cato for the death

[SHK] For fear of what might fall so to prevent

[SHK] The newest state
[SHK] This is the sergeant
[SHK] Who like a good and hardy soldier fought
[SHK] 'Gainst my captivity Hail brave friend
[SHK] Say to the king the knowledge of the broil
[SHK] As thou didst leave it
[SHK] Doubtful it stood
[SHK] As two spent swimmers that do cling together
[SHK] And choke their art The merciless Macdonwald --
[SHK] Worthy to be a rebel for to that
[SHK] The multiplying villanies of nature
[SHK] Do swarm upon him -- from the western isles
[SHK] Of kerns and gallowglasses is supplied
[SHK] And fortune on his damned quarrel smiling
[SHK] Show 'd like a rebel 's whore but all 's too weak
[SHK] For brave Macbeth -- well he deserves that name --
[SHK] Disdaining fortune with his brandish 'd steel
[SHK] Which smoked with bloody execution
[SHK] Like valour 's minion carved out his passage
[SHK] Till he faced the slave
[SHK] Which ne'er shook hands nor bade farewell to him
[SHK] Till he unseam 'd him from the nave to the chaps
[SHK] And fix 'd his head upon our battlements
[SHK] O valiant cousin worthy gentleman
[SHK] As whence the sun 'gins his reflection
[SHK] Shipwrecking storms and direful thunders break
[SHK] So from that spring whence comfort seem 'd to come
[SHK] Discomfort swells Mark king of Scotland mark
[SHK] No sooner justice had with valour arm 'd
[SHK] Compell 'd these skipping kerns to trust their heels
[SHK] But the Norweyan lord surveying vantage
[SHK] With furbish 'd arms and new supplies of men
[SHK] Began a fresh assault
[SHK] Dismay 'd not this
[SHK] Our captains Macbeth and Banquo
[SHK] Yes
[SHK] As sparrows eagles or the hare the lion
[SHK] If I say sooth I must report they were
[SHK] As cannons overcharged with double cracks so they
[SHK] Doubly redoubled strokes upon the foe
[SHK] Except they meant to bathe in reeking wounds
[SHK] Or memorise another Golgotha
[SHK] I can not tell
[SHK] But I am faint my gashes cry for help
[SHK] So well thy words become thee as thy wounds
[SHK] They smack of honour both Go get him surgeons
[SHK] Who comes here
[SHK] The worthy thane of Ross
[SHK] What a haste looks through his eyes So should he look
[SHK] That seems to speak things strange
[SHK] God save the king
[SHK] Whence camest thou worthy thane
[SHK] From Fife great king
[SHK] Where the Norweyan banners flout the sky
[SHK] And fan our people cold Norway himself
[SHK] With terrible numbers
[SHK] Assisted by that most disloyal traitor
[SHK] The thane of Cawdor began a dismal conflict
[SHK] Till that Bellona 's bridegroom lapp 'd in proof
[SHK] Confronted him with self-comparisons
[SHK] Point against point rebellious arm 'gainst arm
[SHK] Curbing his lavish spirit and to conclude
[SHK] The victory fell on us
[SHK] Great happiness
[SHK] That now
[SHK] Sweno the Norways king craves composition
[SHK] Nor would we deign him burial of his men
[SHK] Till he disbursed at Saint Colme 's inch
[SHK] Ten thousand dollars to our general use
[SHK] No more that thane of Cawdor shall deceive
[SHK] Our bosom interest go pronounce his present death

[SHK] Here I have a pilot 's thumb

[SHK] The weird sisters hand in hand

[SHK] And thrice again to make up nine
[SHK] Peace the charm 's wound up

[SHK] How far is't call 'd to Forres What are these

[SHK] And yet are o n't Live you or are you aught
[SHK] That man may question You seem to understand me
[SHK] By each at once her chappy finger laying
[SHK] Upon her skinny lips you should be women
[SHK] And yet your beards forbid me to interpret
[SHK] That you are so

[SHK] All hail Macbeth hail to thee thane of Glamis
[SHK] All hail Macbeth hail to thee thane of Cawdor
