[SHK] Are ye fantastical or that indeed
[SHK] Which outwardly ye show My noble partner
[SHK] You greet with present grace and great prediction
[SHK] Of noble having and of royal hope
[SHK] That he seems rapt withal to me you speak not
[SHK] If you can look into the seeds of time
[SHK] And say which grain will grow and which will not

[SHK] Your favours nor your hate

[SHK] Hail
[SHK] Hail
[SHK] Lesser than Macbeth and greater
[SHK] Not so happy yet much happier

[SHK] Stay you imperfect speakers tell me more
[SHK] By Sinel 's death I know I am thane of Glamis

[SHK] Stands not within the prospect of belief

[SHK] You shall be king

[SHK] Thanks for your pains

[SHK] And make my seated heart knock at my ribs

[SHK] Mine eyes are made the fools o the other senses

[SHK] It is the bloody business which informs

[SHK] Alarum 'd by his sentinel the wolf
[SHK] Whose howl 's his watch thus with his stealthy pace
[SHK] With Tarquin 's ravishing strides towards his design

[SHK] Thy very stones prate of my whereabout

[SHK] That summons thee to heaven or to hell

[SHK] Do mock their charge with snores I have drugg 'd
[SHK] their possets
[SHK] That death and nature do contend about them
[SHK] Whether they live or die

[SHK] And 't is not done The attempt and not the deed

[SHK] Who lies i the second chamber
[SHK] Donalbain
[SHK] This is a sorry sight

[SHK] There 's one did laugh in 's sleep and one cried
[SHK] 'Murder
[SHK] That they did wake each other I stood and heard them
[SHK] But they did say their prayers and address 'd them
[SHK] Again to sleep
[SHK] There are two lodged together
[SHK] One cried 'God bless us and 'Amen the other
[SHK] As they had seen me with these hangman 's hands
[SHK] Listening their fear I could not say 'Amen
[SHK] When they did say 'God bless us
[SHK] Consider it not so deeply
[SHK] But wherefore could not I pronounce 'Amen
[SHK] I had most need of blessing and 'Amen
[SHK] Stuck in my throat
[SHK] These deeds must not be thought
[SHK] After these ways so it will make us mad
[SHK] Methought I heard a voice cry 'Sleep no more
[SHK] Macbeth does murder sleep the innocent sleep
[SHK] Sleep that knits up the ravell 'd sleeve of care
[SHK] The death of each day 's life sore labour 's bath
[SHK] Balm of hurt minds great nature 's second course
[SHK] Chief nourisher in life 's feast --
[SHK] What do you mean

[SHK] To wear a heart so white

[SHK] provoker of three things

[SHK] Marry sir nose-painting sleep and
[SHK] urine Lechery sir it provokes and unprovokes

[SHK] away the performance therefore much drink
[SHK] may be said to be an equivocator with lechery
[SHK] it makes him and it mars him it sets
[SHK] him on and it takes him off it persuades him

[SHK] not stand to in conclusion equivocates him

[SHK] That darkness does the face of earth entomb
[SHK] When living light should kiss it
[SHK] 'T is unnatural
[SHK] Even like the deed that 's done On Tuesday last

[SHK] Than such an one to reign
[SHK] Boundless intemperance
[SHK] In nature is a tyranny it hath been
[SHK] The untimely emptying of the happy throne
[SHK] And fall of many kings But fear not yet
[SHK] To take upon you what is yours you may
[SHK] Convey your pleasures in a spacious plenty
[SHK] And yet seem cold the time you may so hoodwink
[SHK] We have willing dames enough there can not be
[SHK] That vulture in you to devour so many
[SHK] As will to greatness dedicate themselves
[SHK] Finding it so inclined
[SHK] With this there grows
[SHK] In my most ill-composed affection such
[SHK] A stanchless avarice that were I king
[SHK] I should cut off the nobles for their lands
[SHK] Desire his jewels and this other 's house
[SHK] And my more-having would be as a sauce
[SHK] To make me hunger more that I should forge
[SHK] Quarrels unjust against the good and loyal
[SHK] Destroying them for wealth
[SHK] This avarice
[SHK] Sticks deeper grows with more pernicious root
[SHK] Than summer-seeming lust and it hath been
[SHK] The sword of our slain kings yet do not fear
[SHK] Scotland hath foisons to fill up your will
[SHK] Of your mere own all these are portable
[SHK] With other graces weigh 'd
[SHK] But I have none the king-becoming graces
[SHK] As justice verity temperance stableness
[SHK] Bounty perseverance mercy lowliness
[SHK] Devotion patience courage fortitude
[SHK] I have no relish of them but abound
[SHK] In the division of each several crime
[SHK] Acting it many ways Nay had I power I should
[SHK] Pour the sweet milk of concord into hell
[SHK] Uproar the universal peace confound
[SHK] All unity on earth
[SHK] O Scotland Scotland
[SHK] If such a one be fit to govern speak
[SHK] I am as I have spoken
[SHK] Fit to govern
[SHK] No not to live O nation miserable
[SHK] With an untitled tyrant bloody-scepter 'd
[SHK] When shalt thou see thy wholesome days again
[SHK] Since that the truest issue of thy throne
[SHK] By his own interdiction stands accursed
[SHK] And does blaspheme his breed Thy royal father
[SHK] Was a most sainted king the queen that bore thee
[SHK] Oftener upon her knees than on her feet
[SHK] Died every day she lived Fare thee well
[SHK] These evils thou repeat'st upon thyself
[SHK] Have banish 'd me from Scotland O my breast
[SHK] Thy hope ends here
[SHK] Macduff this noble passion
[SHK] Child of integrity hath from my soul
[SHK] Wiped the black scruples reconciled my thoughts
[SHK] To thy good truth and honour Devilish Macbeth
[SHK] By many of these trains hath sought to win me
[SHK] Into his power and modest wisdom plucks me
[SHK] From over-credulous haste but God above
[SHK] Deal between thee and me for even now
[SHK] I put myself to thy direction and
[SHK] Unspeak mine own detraction here abjure
[SHK] The taints and blames I laid upon myself
[SHK] For strangers to my nature I am yet
[SHK] Unknown to woman never was forsworn
[SHK] Scarcely have coveted what was mine own
[SHK] At no time broke my faith would not betray
[SHK] The devil to his fellow and delight
[SHK] No less in truth than life my first false speaking
[SHK] Was this upon myself what I am truly
[SHK] Is thine and my poor country 's to command
[SHK] Whither indeed before thy here-approach
[SHK] Old Siward with ten thousand warlike men
[SHK] Already at a point was setting forth
[SHK] Now we 'll together and the chance of goodness
[SHK] Be like our warranted quarrel Why are you silent
[SHK] Such welcome and unwelcome things at once
[SHK] 'T is hard to reconcile
[SHK] Well more anon. -- Comes the king forth I pray you
[SHK] Ay sir there are a crew of wretched souls
[SHK] That stay his cure their malady convinces
[SHK] The great assay of art but at his touch --
[SHK] Such sanctity hath heaven given his hand --
[SHK] They presently amend
[SHK] I thank you doctor
[SHK] What 's the disease he means
[SHK] 'T is call 'd the evil
[SHK] A most miraculous work in this good king
[SHK] Which often since my here-remain in England
[SHK] I have seen him do How he solicits heaven
[SHK] Himself best knows but strangely-visited people
[SHK] All swoln and ulcerous pitiful to the eye
[SHK] The mere despair of surgery he cures
[SHK] Hanging a golden stamp about their necks
[SHK] Put on with holy prayers and 't is spoken
[SHK] To the succeeding royalty he leaves
[SHK] The healing benediction With this strange virtue
[SHK] He hath a heavenly gift of prophecy
[SHK] And sundry blessings hang about his throne
[SHK] That speak him full of grace
[SHK] See who comes here
[SHK] My countryman but yet I know him not
[SHK] My ever-gentle cousin welcome hither
[SHK] I know him now Good God betimes remove
[SHK] The means that makes us strangers
[SHK] Sir amen
[SHK] Stands Scotland where it did
[SHK] Alas poor country
[SHK] Almost afraid to know itself It can not
[SHK] Be call 'd our mother but our grave where nothing
[SHK] But who knows nothing is once seen to smile
[SHK] Where sighs and groans and shrieks that rend the air
[SHK] Are made not mark 'd where violent sorrow seems
[SHK] A modern ecstasy the dead man 's knell
[SHK] Is there scarce ask 'd for who and good men 's lives
[SHK] Expire before the flowers in their caps
[SHK] Dying or ere they sicken
[SHK] O relation
[SHK] Too nice and yet too true
[SHK] What 's the newest grief
[SHK] That of an hour 's age doth hiss the speaker
[SHK] Each minute teems a new one
[SHK] How does my wife
[SHK] Why well
[SHK] And all my children
[SHK] Well too
[SHK] The tyrant has not batter 'd at their peace
[SHK] No they were well at peace when I did leave 'em
[SHK] But not a niggard of your speech how goes't
[SHK] When I came hither to transport the tidings
[SHK] Which I have heavily borne there ran a rumour
[SHK] Of many worthy fellows that were out
[SHK] Which was to my belief witness 'd the rather
[SHK] For that I saw the tyrant 's power a-foot
[SHK] Now is the time of help your eye in Scotland
[SHK] Would create soldiers make our women fight

[SHK] Be't their comfort

[SHK] Lent us good Siward and ten thousand men
[SHK] An older and a better soldier none
[SHK] That Christendom gives out

[SHK] That would be howl 'd out in the desert air

[SHK] Is ripe for shaking and the powers above

[SHK] The night is long that never finds the day

[SHK] no truth in your report When was it she last walked

[SHK] her unlock her closet take forth paper fold it
[SHK] write upo n't read it afterwards seal it and again
[SHK] return to bed yet all this while in a most fast sleep

[SHK] watching In this slumbery agitation besides her
[SHK] walking and other actual performances what at any
[SHK] time have you heard her say

[SHK] confirm my speech

[SHK] continually 't is her command

[SHK] this a quarter of an hour

[SHK] In such an honour named What 's more to do
[SHK] Which would be planted newly with the time
[SHK] As calling home our exiled friends abroad
[SHK] That fled the snares of watchful tyranny
[SHK] Producing forth the cruel ministers
[SHK] Of this dead butcher and his fiend-like queen
[SHK] Who as 't is thought by self and violent hands
[SHK] Took off her life this and what needful else
[SHK] That calls upon us by the grace of Grace
[SHK] We will perform in measure time and place
[SHK] So thanks to all at once and to each one
[SHK] Whom we invite to see us crown 'd at Scone
[SHK] In sooth I know not why I am so sad
[SHK] It wearies me you say it wearies you
[SHK] But how I caught it found it or came by it
[SHK] What stuff 't is made of whereof it is born
[SHK] I am to learn
[SHK] And such a want-wit sadness makes of me
[SHK] That I have much ado to know myself
[SHK] Your mind is tossing on the ocean
[SHK] There where your argosies with portly sail
[SHK] Like signiors and rich burghers on the flood
[SHK] Or as it were the pageants of the sea
[SHK] Do overpeer the petty traffickers
[SHK] That curtsy to them do them reverence
[SHK] As they fly by them with their woven wings
[SHK] Believe me sir had I such venture forth
[SHK] The better part of my affections would
[SHK] Be with my hopes abroad I should be still
[SHK] Plucking the grass to know where sits the wind
[SHK] Peering in maps for ports and piers and roads
[SHK] And every object that might make me fear
[SHK] Misfortune to my ventures out of doubt
[SHK] Would make me sad
[SHK] My wind cooling my broth
[SHK] Would blow me to an ague when I thought
[SHK] What harm a wind too great at sea might do
[SHK] I should not see the sandy hour-glass run
[SHK] But I should think of shallows and of flats
[SHK] And see my wealthy Andrew dock 'd in sand
[SHK] Vailing her high-top lower than her ribs
[SHK] To kiss her burial Should I go to church
[SHK] And see the holy edifice of stone
[SHK] And not bethink me straight of dangerous rocks
[SHK] Which touching but my gentle vessel 's side
[SHK] Would scatter all her spices on the stream
[SHK] Enrobe the roaring waters with my silks
[SHK] And in a word but even now worth this
[SHK] And now worth nothing Shall I have the thought
[SHK] To think on this and shall I lack the thought
[SHK] That such a thing bechanced would make me sad
[SHK] But tell not me I know Antonio
[SHK] Is sad to think upon his merchandise
[SHK] Believe me no I thank my fortune for it
[SHK] My ventures are not in one bottom trusted
[SHK] Nor to one place nor is my whole estate
[SHK] Upon the fortune of this present year
[SHK] Therefore my merchandise makes me not sad
[SHK] Why then you are in love
[SHK] Fie fie
[SHK] Not in love neither Then let us say you are sad
[SHK] Because you are not merry and 'twere as easy
[SHK] For you to laugh and leap and say you are merry
[SHK] Because you are not sad Now by two-headed Janus
[SHK] Nature hath framed strange fellows in her time
[SHK] Some that will evermore peep through their eyes
[SHK] And laugh like parrots at a bag-piper
[SHK] And other of such vinegar aspect
[SHK] That they 'll not show their teeth in way of smile
[SHK] Though Nestor swear the jest be laughable
[SHK] Here comes Bassanio your most noble kinsman
[SHK] Gratiano and Lorenzo Fare ye well
[SHK] We leave you now with better company
[SHK] I would have stay 'd till I had made you merry
[SHK] If worthier friends had not prevented me
[SHK] Your worth is very dear in my regard
[SHK] I take it your own business calls on you
[SHK] And you embrace the occasion to depart
[SHK] Good morrow my good lords
[SHK] Good signiors both when shall we laugh say when
[SHK] You grow exceeding strange must it be so
[SHK] We 'll make our leisures to attend on yours
[SHK] My Lord Bassanio since you have found Antonio
[SHK] We two will leave you but at dinner-time
[SHK] I pray you have in mind where we must meet
[SHK] I will not fail you
[SHK] You look not well Signior Antonio
[SHK] You have too much respect upon the world
[SHK] They lose it that do buy it with much care
[SHK] Believe me you are marvellously changed
[SHK] I hold the world but as the world Gratiano
[SHK] A stage where every man must play a part
[SHK] And mine a sad one
[SHK] Let me play the fool
[SHK] With mirth and laughter let old wrinkles come
[SHK] And let my liver rather heat with wine
[SHK] Than my heart cool with mortifying groans
[SHK] Why should a man whose blood is warm within
[SHK] Sit like his grandsire cut in alabaster
[SHK] Sleep when he wakes and creep into the jaundice
[SHK] By being peevish I tell thee what Antonio --
[SHK] I love thee and it is my love that speaks --
[SHK] There are a sort of men whose visages
[SHK] Do cream and mantle like a standing pond
[SHK] And do a wilful stillness entertain
[SHK] With purpose to be dress 'd in an opinion
[SHK] Of wisdom gravity profound conceit
[SHK] As who should say I am Sir Oracle
[SHK] And when I ope my lips let no dog bark
[SHK] O my Antonio I do know of these
[SHK] That therefore only are reputed wise
[SHK] For saying nothing when I am very sure
[SHK] If they should speak would almost damn those ears
[SHK] Which hearing them would call their brothers fools
[SHK] I 'll tell thee more of this another time
[SHK] But fish not with this melancholy bait
[SHK] For this fool gudgeon this opinion
[SHK] Come good Lorenzo Fare ye well awhile
[SHK] I 'll end my exhortation after dinner
[SHK] Well we will leave you then till dinner-time
[SHK] I must be one of these same dumb wise men
[SHK] For Gratiano never lets me speak
[SHK] Well keep me company but two years moe
[SHK] Thou shalt not know the sound of thine own tongue
[SHK] Farewell I 'll grow a talker for this gear
[SHK] Thanks i faith for silence is only commendable
[SHK] In a neat 's tongue dried and a maid not vendible
[SHK] Is that any thing now
[SHK] Gratiano speaks an infinite deal of nothing more
[SHK] than any man in all Venice His reasons are as two
[SHK] grains of wheat hid in two bushels of chaff you
[SHK] shall seek all day ere you find them and when you
[SHK] have them they are not worth the search
[SHK] Well tell me now what lady is the same
[SHK] To whom you swore a secret pilgrimage
[SHK] That you to-day promised to tell me of
[SHK] 'T is not unknown to you Antonio
[SHK] How much I have disabled mine estate
[SHK] By something showing a more swelling port
[SHK] Than my faint means would grant continuance
[SHK] Nor do I now make moan to be abridged
[SHK] From such a noble rate but my chief care
[SHK] Is to come fairly off from the great debts
[SHK] Wherein my time something too prodigal
[SHK] Hath left me gaged To you Antonio
[SHK] I owe the most in money and in love
[SHK] And from your love I have a warranty
[SHK] To unburden all my plots and purposes
[SHK] How to get clear of all the debts I owe
[SHK] I pray you good Bassanio let me know it
[SHK] And if it stand as you yourself still do
[SHK] Within the eye of honour be assured
[SHK] My purse my person my extremest means
[SHK] Lie all unlock 'd to your occasions
[SHK] In my school-days when I had lost one shaft
[SHK] I shot his fellow of the self-same flight
[SHK] The self-same way with more advised watch
[SHK] To find the other forth and by adventuring both
[SHK] I oft found both I urge this childhood proof
[SHK] Because what follows is pure innocence
[SHK] I owe you much and like a wilful youth
[SHK] That which I owe is lost but if you please
[SHK] To shoot another arrow that self way
[SHK] Which you did shoot the first I do not doubt
[SHK] As I will watch the aim or to find both
[SHK] Or bring your latter hazard back again
[SHK] And thankfully rest debtor for the first
[SHK] You know me well and herein spend but time
[SHK] To wind about my love with circumstance
[SHK] And out of doubt you do me now more wrong
[SHK] In making question of my uttermost
[SHK] Than if you had made waste of all I have
[SHK] Then do but say to me what I should do
[SHK] That in your knowledge may by me be done
[SHK] And I am prest unto it therefore speak
[SHK] In Belmont is a lady richly left
[SHK] And she is fair and fairer than that word
[SHK] Of wondrous virtues sometimes from her eyes
[SHK] I did receive fair speechless messages
[SHK] Her name is Portia nothing undervalued
[SHK] To Cato 's daughter Brutus Portia
[SHK] Nor is the wide world ignorant of her worth
[SHK] For the four winds blow in from every coast
[SHK] Renowned suitors and her sunny locks
[SHK] Hang on her temples like a golden fleece
[SHK] Which makes her seat of Belmont Colchos strand
[SHK] And many Jasons come in quest of her
[SHK] O my Antonio had I but the means
[SHK] To hold a rival place with one of them
[SHK] I have a mind presages me such thrift
[SHK] That I should questionless be fortunate
[SHK] Thou know'st that all my fortunes are at sea
[SHK] Neither have I money nor commodity
[SHK] To raise a present sum therefore go forth
[SHK] Try what my credit can in Venice do
[SHK] That shall be rack 'd even to the uttermost
[SHK] To furnish thee to Belmont to fair Portia
[SHK] Go presently inquire and so will I
[SHK] Where money is and I no question make
[SHK] To have it of my trust or for my sake
[SHK] By my troth Nerissa my little body is aweary of
[SHK] this great world
[SHK] You would be sweet madam if your miseries were in
[SHK] the same abundance as your good fortunes are and
[SHK] yet for aught I see they are as sick that surfeit
[SHK] with too much as they that starve with nothing It
[SHK] is no mean happiness therefore to be seated in the
[SHK] mean superfluity comes sooner by white hairs but
[SHK] competency lives longer
[SHK] Good sentences and well pronounced
[SHK] They would be better if well followed
[SHK] If to do were as easy as to know what were good to
[SHK] do chapels had been churches and poor men 's
[SHK] cottages princes palaces It is a good divine that
[SHK] follows his own instructions I can easier teach
[SHK] twenty what were good to be done than be one of the
[SHK] twenty to follow mine own teaching The brain may
[SHK] devise laws for the blood but a hot temper leaps
[SHK] o'er a cold decree such a hare is madness the
[SHK] youth to skip o'er the meshes of good counsel the
[SHK] cripple But this reasoning is not in the fashion to
[SHK] choose me a husband O me the word 'choose I may
[SHK] neither choose whom I would nor refuse whom I
[SHK] dislike so is the will of a living daughter curbed
[SHK] by the will of a dead father Is it not hard
[SHK] Nerissa that I can not choose one nor refuse none
[SHK] Your father was ever virtuous and holy men at their
[SHK] death have good inspirations therefore the lottery
[SHK] that he hath devised in these three chests of gold
[SHK] silver and lead whereof who chooses his meaning
[SHK] chooses you will no doubt never be chosen by any
[SHK] rightly but one who shall rightly love But what
[SHK] warmth is there in your affection towards any of
[SHK] these princely suitors that are already come
[SHK] I pray thee over-name them and as thou namest
[SHK] them I will describe them and according to my
[SHK] description level at my affection
[SHK] First there is the Neapolitan prince
[SHK] Ay that 's a colt indeed for he doth nothing but
[SHK] talk of his horse and he makes it a great
[SHK] appropriation to his own good parts that he can
[SHK] shoe him himself I am much afeard my lady his
[SHK] mother played false with a smith
[SHK] Then there is the County Palatine
[SHK] He doth nothing but frown as who should say 'If you
[SHK] will not have me choose he hears merry tales and
[SHK] smiles not I fear he will prove the weeping
[SHK] philosopher when he grows old being so full of
[SHK] unmannerly sadness in his youth I had rather be
[SHK] married to a death's-head with a bone in his mouth
[SHK] than to either of these God defend me from these
[SHK] two
[SHK] How say you by the French lord Monsieur Le Bon
[SHK] God made him and therefore let him pass for a man
[SHK] In truth I know it is a sin to be a mocker but
[SHK] he why he hath a horse better than the
[SHK] Neapolitan 's a better bad habit of frowning than
[SHK] the Count Palatine he is every man in no man if a
[SHK] throstle sing he falls straight a capering he will
[SHK] fence with his own shadow if I should marry him I
[SHK] should marry twenty husbands If he would despise me
[SHK] I would forgive him for if he love me to madness I
[SHK] shall never requite him
[SHK] What say you then to Falconbridge the young baron
[SHK] of England
[SHK] You know I say nothing to him for he understands
[SHK] not me nor I him he hath neither Latin French
[SHK] nor Italian and you will come into the court and
[SHK] swear that I have a poor pennyworth in the English
[SHK] He is a proper man 's picture but alas who can
[SHK] converse with a dumb-show How oddly he is suited
[SHK] I think he bought his doublet in Italy his round
[SHK] hose in France his bonnet in Germany and his
[SHK] behavior every where
[SHK] What think you of the Scottish lord his neighbour
[SHK] That he hath a neighbourly charity in him for he
[SHK] borrowed a box of the ear of the Englishman and
[SHK] swore he would pay him again when he was able I
[SHK] think the Frenchman became his surety and sealed
[SHK] under for another
[SHK] How like you the young German the Duke of Saxony 's nephew
[SHK] Very vilely in the morning when he is sober and
[SHK] most vilely in the afternoon when he is drunk when
[SHK] he is best he is a little worse than a man and
[SHK] when he is worst he is little better than a beast
[SHK] and the worst fall that ever fell I hope I shall
[SHK] make shift to go without him
[SHK] If he should offer to choose and choose the right
[SHK] casket you should refuse to perform your father 's
[SHK] will if you should refuse to accept him
[SHK] Therefore for fear of the worst I pray thee set a
[SHK] deep glass of rhenish wine on the contrary casket
[SHK] for if the devil be within and that temptation
[SHK] without I know he will choose it I will do any
[SHK] thing Nerissa ere I 'll be married to a sponge
[SHK] You need not fear lady the having any of these
[SHK] lords they have acquainted me with their
[SHK] determinations which is indeed to return to their
[SHK] home and to trouble you with no more suit unless
[SHK] you may be won by some other sort than your father 's
[SHK] imposition depending on the caskets
[SHK] If I live to be as old as Sibylla I will die as
[SHK] chaste as Diana unless I be obtained by the manner
[SHK] of my father 's will I am glad this parcel of wooers
[SHK] are so reasonable for there is not one among them
[SHK] but I dote on his very absence and I pray God grant
[SHK] them a fair departure
[SHK] Do you not remember lady in your father 's time a
[SHK] Venetian a scholar and a soldier that came hither
[SHK] in company of the Marquis of Montferrat
[SHK] Yes yes it was Bassanio as I think he was so called
[SHK] True madam he of all the men that ever my foolish
[SHK] eyes looked upon was the best deserving a fair lady
[SHK] I remember him well and I remember him worthy of
[SHK] thy praise
[SHK] How now what news
[SHK] The four strangers seek for you madam to take
[SHK] their leave and there is a forerunner come from a
[SHK] fifth the Prince of Morocco who brings word the
[SHK] prince his master will be here to-night
[SHK] If I could bid the fifth welcome with so good a
[SHK] heart as I can bid the other four farewell I should
[SHK] be glad of his approach if he have the condition
[SHK] of a saint and the complexion of a devil I had
[SHK] rather he should shrive me than wive me Come
[SHK] Nerissa Sirrah go before
[SHK] Whiles we shut the gates
[SHK] upon one wooer another knocks at the door
[SHK] Three thousand ducats well
[SHK] Ay sir for three months
[SHK] For three months well
[SHK] For the which as I told you Antonio shall be bound
[SHK] Antonio shall become bound well
[SHK] May you stead me will you pleasure me shall I
[SHK] know your answer
[SHK] Three thousand ducats for three months and Antonio bound
[SHK] Your answer to that
[SHK] Antonio is a good man
[SHK] Have you heard any imputation to the contrary
[SHK] Oh no no no no my meaning in saying he is a
[SHK] good man is to have you understand me that he is
[SHK] sufficient Yet his means are in supposition he
[SHK] hath an argosy bound to Tripolis another to the
[SHK] Indies I understand moreover upon the Rialto he
[SHK] hath a third at Mexico a fourth for England and
[SHK] other ventures he hath squandered abroad But ships
[SHK] are but boards sailors but men there be land-rats
[SHK] and water-rats water-thieves and land-thieves I
[SHK] mean pirates and then there is the peril of waters
[SHK] winds and rocks The man is notwithstanding
[SHK] sufficient Three thousand ducats I think I may
[SHK] take his bond
[SHK] Be assured you may
[SHK] I will be assured I may and that I may be assured
[SHK] I will bethink me May I speak with Antonio
[SHK] If it please you to dine with us
[SHK] Yes to smell pork to eat of the habitation which
[SHK] your prophet the Nazarite conjured the devil into I
[SHK] will buy with you sell with you talk with you
[SHK] walk with you and so following but I will not eat
[SHK] with you drink with you nor pray with you What
[SHK] news on the Rialto Who is he comes here
[SHK] This is Signior Antonio
[SHK] I hate him for he is a Christian
[SHK] But more for that in low simplicity
[SHK] He lends out money gratis and brings down
[SHK] The rate of usance here with us in Venice
[SHK] If I can catch him once upon the hip
[SHK] I will feed fat the ancient grudge I bear him
[SHK] He hates our sacred nation and he rails
[SHK] Even there where merchants most do congregate
[SHK] On me my bargains and my well-won thrift
[SHK] Which he calls interest Cursed be my tribe
[SHK] If I forgive him
[SHK] Shylock do you hear
[SHK] I am debating of my present store
[SHK] And by the near guess of my memory
[SHK] I can not instantly raise up the gross
[SHK] Of full three thousand ducats What of that
[SHK] Tubal a wealthy Hebrew of my tribe
[SHK] Will furnish me But soft how many months
[SHK] Do you desire
[SHK] Rest you fair good signior
[SHK] Your worship was the last man in our mouths
[SHK] Shylock although I neither lend nor borrow
[SHK] By taking nor by giving of excess
[SHK] Yet to supply the ripe wants of my friend
[SHK] I 'll break a custom Is he yet possess 'd
[SHK] How much ye would
[SHK] Ay ay three thousand ducats
[SHK] And for three months
[SHK] I had forgot three months you told me so
[SHK] Well then your bond and let me see but hear you
[SHK] Methought you said you neither lend nor borrow
[SHK] Upon advantage
[SHK] I do never use it
[SHK] When Jacob grazed his uncle Laban 's sheep --
[SHK] This Jacob from our holy Abram was
[SHK] As his wise mother wrought in his behalf
[SHK] The third possessor ay he was the third --
[SHK] And what of him did he take interest
[SHK] No not take interest not as you would say
[SHK] Directly interest mark what Jacob did
[SHK] When Laban and himself were compromised
[SHK] That all the eanlings which were streak 'd and pied
[SHK] Should fall as Jacob 's hire the ewes being rank
[SHK] In the end of autumn turned to the rams
[SHK] And when the work of generation was
[SHK] Between these woolly breeders in the act
[SHK] The skilful shepherd peel 'd me certain wands
[SHK] And in the doing of the deed of kind
[SHK] He stuck them up before the fulsome ewes
[SHK] Who then conceiving did in eaning time
[SHK] Fall parti-colour 'd lambs and those were Jacob 's
[SHK] This was a way to thrive and he was blest
[SHK] And thrift is blessing if men steal it not
[SHK] This was a venture sir that Jacob served for
[SHK] A thing not in his power to bring to pass
[SHK] But sway 'd and fashion 'd by the hand of heaven
[SHK] Was this inserted to make interest good
[SHK] Or is your gold and silver ewes and rams
[SHK] I can not tell I make it breed as fast
[SHK] But note me signior
[SHK] Mark you this Bassanio
[SHK] The devil can cite Scripture for his purpose
[SHK] An evil soul producing holy witness
[SHK] Is like a villain with a smiling cheek
[SHK] A goodly apple rotten at the heart
[SHK] O what a goodly outside falsehood hath
[SHK] Three thousand ducats 't is a good round sum
[SHK] Three months from twelve then let me see the rate --
[SHK] Well Shylock shall we be beholding to you
[SHK] Signior Antonio many a time and oft
[SHK] In the Rialto you have rated me
[SHK] About my moneys and my usances
[SHK] Still have I borne it with a patient shrug
[SHK] For sufferance is the badge of all our tribe
[SHK] You call me misbeliever cut-throat dog
[SHK] And spit upon my Jewish gaberdine
[SHK] And all for use of that which is mine own
[SHK] Well then it now appears you need my help
[SHK] Go to then you come to me and you say
[SHK] 'Shylock we would have moneys you say so
[SHK] You that did void your rheum upon my beard
[SHK] And foot me as you spurn a stranger cur
[SHK] Over your threshold moneys is your suit
[SHK] What should I say to you Should I not say
[SHK] 'Hath a dog money is it possible
[SHK] A cur can lend three thousand ducats Or
[SHK] Shall I bend low and in a bondman 's key
[SHK] With bated breath and whispering humbleness Say this
[SHK] 'Fair sir you spit on me on Wednesday last
[SHK] You spurn 'd me such a day another time
[SHK] You call 'd me dog and for these courtesies
[SHK] I 'll lend you thus much moneys
[SHK] I am as like to call thee so again
[SHK] To spit on thee again to spurn thee too
[SHK] If thou wilt lend this money lend it not
[SHK] As to thy friends for when did friendship take
[SHK] A breed for barren metal of his friend
[SHK] But lend it rather to thine enemy
[SHK] Who if he break thou mayst with better face
[SHK] Exact the penalty
[SHK] Why look you how you storm
[SHK] I would be friends with you and have your love
[SHK] Forget the shames that you have stain 'd me with
[SHK] Supply your present wants and take no doit
[SHK] Of usance for my moneys and you 'll not hear me
[SHK] This is kind I offer
[SHK] This were kindness
[SHK] This kindness will I show
[SHK] Go with me to a notary seal me there
[SHK] Your single bond and in a merry sport
[SHK] If you repay me not on such a day
[SHK] In such a place such sum or sums as are
[SHK] Express 'd in the condition let the forfeit
[SHK] Be nominated for an equal pound
[SHK] Of your fair flesh to be cut off and taken
[SHK] In what part of your body pleaseth me
[SHK] Content i faith I 'll seal to such a bond
[SHK] And say there is much kindness in the Jew
[SHK] You shall not seal to such a bond for me
[SHK] I 'll rather dwell in my necessity
[SHK] Why fear not man I will not forfeit it
[SHK] Within these two months that 's a month before
[SHK] This bond expires I do expect return
[SHK] Of thrice three times the value of this bond
[SHK] O father Abram what these Christians are
[SHK] Whose own hard dealings teaches them suspect
[SHK] The thoughts of others Pray you tell me this
[SHK] If he should break his day what should I gain
[SHK] By the exaction of the forfeiture
[SHK] A pound of man 's flesh taken from a man
[SHK] Is not so estimable profitable neither
[SHK] As flesh of muttons beefs or goats I say
[SHK] To buy his favour I extend this friendship
[SHK] If he will take it so if not adieu
[SHK] And for my love I pray you wrong me not
[SHK] Yes Shylock I will seal unto this bond
[SHK] Then meet me forthwith at the notary 's
[SHK] Give him direction for this merry bond
[SHK] And I will go and purse the ducats straight
[SHK] See to my house left in the fearful guard
[SHK] Of an unthrifty knave and presently
[SHK] I will be with you
[SHK] Hie thee gentle Jew
[SHK] The Hebrew will turn Christian he grows kind
[SHK] I like not fair terms and a villain 's mind
[SHK] Come on in this there can be no dismay
[SHK] My ships come home a month before the day
[SHK] Mislike me not for my complexion
[SHK] The shadow 'd livery of the burnish 'd sun
[SHK] To whom I am a neighbour and near bred
[SHK] Bring me the fairest creature northward born
[SHK] Where Phoebus fire scarce thaws the icicles
[SHK] And let us make incision for your love
[SHK] To prove whose blood is reddest his or mine
[SHK] I tell thee lady this aspect of mine
[SHK] Hath fear 'd the valiant by my love I swear
[SHK] The best-regarded virgins of our clime
[SHK] Have loved it too I would not change this hue
[SHK] Except to steal your thoughts my gentle queen
[SHK] In terms of choice I am not solely led
[SHK] By nice direction of a maiden 's eyes
[SHK] Besides the lottery of my destiny
[SHK] Bars me the right of voluntary choosing
[SHK] But if my father had not scanted me
[SHK] And hedged me by his wit to yield myself
[SHK] His wife who wins me by that means I told you
[SHK] Yourself renowned prince then stood as fair
[SHK] As any comer I have look 'd on yet
[SHK] For my affection
[SHK] Even for that I thank you
[SHK] Therefore I pray you lead me to the caskets
[SHK] To try my fortune By this scimitar
[SHK] That slew the Sophy and a Persian prince
[SHK] That won three fields of Sultan Solyman
[SHK] I would outstare the sternest eyes that look
[SHK] Outbrave the heart most daring on the earth
[SHK] Pluck the young sucking cubs from the she-bear
[SHK] Yea mock the lion when he roars for prey
[SHK] To win thee lady But alas the while
[SHK] If Hercules and Lichas play at dice
[SHK] Which is the better man the greater throw
[SHK] May turn by fortune from the weaker hand
[SHK] So is Alcides beaten by his page
[SHK] And so may I blind fortune leading me
[SHK] Miss that which one unworthier may attain
[SHK] And die with grieving
[SHK] You must take your chance
[SHK] And either not attempt to choose at all
[SHK] Or swear before you choose if you choose wrong
[SHK] Never to speak to lady afterward
[SHK] In way of marriage therefore be advised

[SHK] First forward to the temple after dinner

[SHK] To make me blest or cursed'st among men

[SHK] And weigh thy value with an even hand

[SHK] May not extend so far as to the lady

[SHK] Why that 's the lady all the world desires her
[SHK] From the four corners of the earth they come
[SHK] To kiss this shrine this mortal-breathing saint
[SHK] The Hyrcanian deserts and the vasty wilds
[SHK] Of wide Arabia are as thoroughfares now

[SHK] Spits in the face of heaven is no bar

[SHK] Let good Antonio look he keep his day
[SHK] Or he shall pay for this
[SHK] Marry well remember 'd
[SHK] I reason 'd with a Frenchman yesterday
[SHK] Who told me in the narrow seas that part
[SHK] The French and English there miscarried
[SHK] A vessel of our country richly fraught
[SHK] I thought upon Antonio when he told me
[SHK] And wish 'd in silence that it were not his
[SHK] You were best to tell Antonio what you hear
[SHK] Yet do not suddenly for it may grieve him
[SHK] A kinder gentleman treads not the earth

[SHK] Bassanio told him he would make some speed
[SHK] Of his return he answer 'd 'Do not so
[SHK] Slubber not business for my sake Bassanio
[SHK] But stay the very riping of the time
[SHK] And for the Jew 's bond which he hath of me
[SHK] Let it not enter in your mind of love
[SHK] Be merry and employ your chiefest thoughts
[SHK] To courtship and such fair ostents of love
[SHK] As shall conveniently become you there
[SHK] And even there his eye being big with tears
[SHK] Turning his face he put his hand behind him
[SHK] And with affection wondrous sensible
[SHK] He wrung Bassanio 's hand and so they parted
[SHK] I think he only loves the world for him
[SHK] I pray thee let us go and find him out
[SHK] And quicken his embraced heaviness
[SHK] With some delight or other
[SHK] Do we so
[SHK] Quick quick I pray thee draw the curtain straight
[SHK] The Prince of Arragon hath ta'en his oath
[SHK] And comes to his election presently
[SHK] Behold there stand the caskets noble prince
[SHK] If you choose that wherein I am contain 'd
[SHK] Straight shall our nuptial rites be solemnized
[SHK] But if you fail without more speech my lord
[SHK] You must be gone from hence immediately
[SHK] I am enjoin 'd by oath to observe three things
[SHK] First never to unfold to any one
[SHK] Which casket 't was I chose next if I fail
[SHK] Of the right casket never in my life
[SHK] To woo a maid in way of marriage Lastly
[SHK] If I do fail in fortune of my choice
[SHK] Immediately to leave you and be gone
[SHK] To these injunctions every one doth swear
[SHK] That comes to hazard for my worthless self
[SHK] And so have I address 'd me Fortune now
[SHK] To my heart 's hope Gold silver and base lead
[SHK] 'Who chooseth me must give and hazard all he hath
[SHK] You shall look fairer ere I give or hazard
[SHK] What says the golden chest ha let me see
[SHK] 'Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire
[SHK] What many men desire that 'many may be meant
[SHK] By the fool multitude that choose by show
[SHK] Not learning more than the fond eye doth teach
[SHK] Which pries not to the interior but like the martlet
[SHK] Builds in the weather on the outward wall
[SHK] Even in the force and road of casualty
[SHK] I will not choose what many men desire
[SHK] Because I will not jump with common spirits
[SHK] And rank me with the barbarous multitudes
[SHK] Why then to thee thou silver treasure-house
[SHK] Tell me once more what title thou dost bear
[SHK] 'Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves
[SHK] And well said too for who shall go about
[SHK] To cozen fortune and be honourable
[SHK] Without the stamp of merit Let none presume
[SHK] To wear an undeserved dignity
[SHK] O that estates degrees and offices
[SHK] Were not derived corruptly and that clear honour
[SHK] Were purchased by the merit of the wearer
[SHK] How many then should cover that stand bare
[SHK] How many be commanded that command
[SHK] How much low peasantry would then be glean 'd
[SHK] From the true seed of honour and how much honour
[SHK] Pick 'd from the chaff and ruin of the times
[SHK] To be new-varnish 'd Well but to my choice
[SHK] 'Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves
[SHK] I will assume desert Give me a key for this
[SHK] And instantly unlock my fortunes here
[SHK] Too long a pause for that which you find there
[SHK] What 's here the portrait of a blinking idiot
[SHK] Presenting me a schedule I will read it
[SHK] How much unlike art thou to Portia
[SHK] How much unlike my hopes and my deservings
[SHK] 'Who chooseth me shall have as much as he deserves
[SHK] Did I deserve no more than a fool 's head
[SHK] Is that my prize are my deserts no better
[SHK] To offend and judge are distinct offices
[SHK] And of opposed natures
[SHK] What is here
[SHK] The fire seven times tried this
[SHK] Seven times tried that judgment is
[SHK] That did never choose amiss
[SHK] Some there be that shadows kiss
[SHK] Such have but a shadow 's bliss
[SHK] There be fools alive I wis
[SHK] Silver 'd o'er and so was this
[SHK] Take what wife you will to bed
[SHK] I will ever be your head
[SHK] So be gone you are sped
[SHK] Still more fool I shall appear
[SHK] By the time I linger here
[SHK] With one fool 's head I came to woo
[SHK] But I go away with two
[SHK] Sweet adieu I 'll keep my oath
[SHK] Patiently to bear my wroth
[SHK] Thus hath the candle singed the moth
[SHK] O these deliberate fools when they do choose
[SHK] They have the wisdom by their wit to lose
[SHK] The ancient saying is no heresy
[SHK] Hanging and wiving goes by destiny
[SHK] Come draw the curtain Nerissa
[SHK] Where is my lady
[SHK] Here what would my lord
[SHK] Madam there is alighted at your gate
[SHK] A young Venetian one that comes before
[SHK] To signify the approaching of his lord
[SHK] From whom he bringeth sensible regreets
[SHK] To wit besides commends and courteous breath
[SHK] Gifts of rich value Yet I have not seen
[SHK] So likely an ambassador of love
[SHK] A day in April never came so sweet
[SHK] To show how costly summer was at hand
[SHK] As this fore-spurrer comes before his lord
[SHK] No more I pray thee I am half afeard
[SHK] Thou wilt say anon he is some kin to thee
[SHK] Thou spend'st such high-day wit in praising him
[SHK] Come come Nerissa for I long to see
[SHK] Quick Cupid 's post that comes so mannerly
[SHK] Bassanio lord Love if thy will it be

[SHK] a ship of rich lading wrecked on the narrow seas
[SHK] the Goodwins I think they call the place a very
[SHK] dangerous flat and fatal where the carcasses of many
[SHK] a tall ship lie buried as they say if my gossip
[SHK] Report be an honest woman of her word

[SHK] knapped ginger or made her neighbours believe she

[SHK] true without any slips of prolixity or crossing the

[SHK] that made the wings she flew withal

[SHK] fledged and then it is the complexion of them all
[SHK] to leave the dam

[SHK] That 's certain if the devil may be her judge
[SHK] My own flesh and blood to rebel

[SHK] than there is between red wine and rhenish But
[SHK] tell us do you hear whether Antonio have had any
[SHK] loss at sea or no

[SHK] the mart let him look to his bond he was wont to
[SHK] call me usurer let him look to his bond he was

[SHK] look to his bond
[SHK] Why I am sure if he forfeit thou wilt not take

[SHK] To bait fish withal if it will feed nothing else
[SHK] it will feed my revenge He hath disgraced me and
[SHK] hindered me half a million laughed at my losses
[SHK] mocked at my gains scorned my nation thwarted my
[SHK] bargains cooled my friends heated mine
[SHK] enemies and what 's his reason I am a Jew Hath
[SHK] not a Jew eyes hath not a Jew hands organs
[SHK] dimensions senses affections passions fed with
[SHK] the same food hurt with the same weapons subject
[SHK] to the same diseases healed by the same means
[SHK] warmed and cooled by the same winter and summer as
[SHK] a Christian is If you prick us do we not bleed
[SHK] if you tickle us do we not laugh if you poison
[SHK] us do we not die and if you wrong us shall we not
[SHK] revenge If we are like you in the rest we will
[SHK] resemble you in that If a Jew wrong a Christian
[SHK] what is his humility Revenge If a Christian
[SHK] wrong a Jew what should his sufferance be by
[SHK] Christian example Why revenge The villany you
[SHK] teach me I will execute and it shall go hard but I
[SHK] will better the instruction
[SHK] Gentlemen my master Antonio is at his house and
[SHK] desires to speak with you both

[SHK] matched unless the devil himself turn Jew

[SHK] never fell upon our nation till now I never felt it
[SHK] till now two thousand ducats in that and other

[SHK] Hate counsels not in such a quality

[SHK] And yet a maiden hath no tongue but thought --
[SHK] I would detain you here some month or two
[SHK] Before you venture for me I could teach you
[SHK] How to choose right but I am then forsworn
[SHK] So will I never be so may you miss me
[SHK] But if you do you 'll make me wish a sin
[SHK] That I had been forsworn Beshrew your eyes
[SHK] They have o'erlook 'd me and divided me
[SHK] One half of me is yours the other half yours
[SHK] Mine own I would say but if mine then yours
[SHK] And so all yours O these naughty times
[SHK] Put bars between the owners and their rights
[SHK] And so though yours not yours Prove it so
[SHK] Let fortune go to hell for it not I
[SHK] I speak too long but 't is to peize the time
[SHK] To eke it and to draw it out in length
[SHK] To stay you from election
[SHK] Let me choose
[SHK] For as I am I live upon the rack
[SHK] Upon the rack Bassanio then confess
[SHK] What treason there is mingled with your love
[SHK] None but that ugly treason of mistrust
[SHK] Which makes me fear the enjoying of my love
[SHK] There may as well be amity and life
[SHK] 'Tween snow and fire as treason and my love
[SHK] Ay but I fear you speak upon the rack
[SHK] Where men enforced do speak anything
[SHK] Promise me life and I 'll confess the truth
[SHK] Well then confess and live
[SHK] 'Confess and 'love
[SHK] Had been the very sum of my confession
[SHK] O happy torment when my torturer
[SHK] Doth teach me answers for deliverance
[SHK] But let me to my fortune and the caskets
[SHK] Away then I am lock 'd in one of them
[SHK] If you do love me you will find me out
[SHK] Nerissa and the rest stand all aloof
[SHK] Let music sound while he doth make his choice
[SHK] Then if he lose he makes a swan-like end
[SHK] Fading in music that the comparison
[SHK] May stand more proper my eye shall be the stream
[SHK] And watery death-bed for him He may win
[SHK] And what is music then Then music is
[SHK] Even as the flourish when true subjects bow
[SHK] To a new-crowned monarch such it is
[SHK] As are those dulcet sounds in break of day
[SHK] That creep into the dreaming bridegroom 's ear
[SHK] And summon him to marriage Now he goes
[SHK] With no less presence but with much more love
[SHK] Than young Alcides when he did redeem
[SHK] The virgin tribute paid by howling Troy
[SHK] To the sea-monster I stand for sacrifice
[SHK] The rest aloof are the Dardanian wives
[SHK] With bleared visages come forth to view
[SHK] The issue of the exploit Go Hercules
[SHK] Live thou I live with much much more dismay
[SHK] I view the fight than thou that makest the fray
[SHK] Tell me where is fancy bred
[SHK] Or in the heart or in the head
[SHK] How begot how nourished
[SHK] Reply reply
[SHK] It is engender 'd in the eyes
[SHK] With gazing fed and fancy dies
[SHK] In the cradle where it lies
[SHK] Let us all ring fancy 's knell
[SHK] I 'll begin it -- Ding dong bell
[SHK] Ding dong bell
[SHK] So may the outward shows be least themselves
[SHK] The world is still deceived with ornament
[SHK] In law what plea so tainted and corrupt
[SHK] But being seasoned with a gracious voice
[SHK] Obscures the show of evil In religion
[SHK] What damned error but some sober brow
[SHK] Will bless it and approve it with a text
[SHK] Hiding the grossness with fair ornament
[SHK] There is no vice so simple but assumes
[SHK] Some mark of virtue on his outward parts
[SHK] How many cowards whose hearts are all as false
[SHK] As stairs of sand wear yet upon their chins
[SHK] The beards of Hercules and frowning Mars
[SHK] Who inward search 'd have livers white as milk
[SHK] And these assume but valour 's excrement
[SHK] To render them redoubted Look on beauty
[SHK] And you shall see 't is purchased by the weight
[SHK] Which therein works a miracle in nature
[SHK] Making them lightest that wear most of it
[SHK] So are those crisped snaky golden locks
[SHK] Which make such wanton gambols with the wind
[SHK] Upon supposed fairness often known
[SHK] To be the dowry of a second head
[SHK] The skull that bred them in the sepulchre
[SHK] Thus ornament is but the guiled shore
[SHK] To a most dangerous sea the beauteous scarf
[SHK] Veiling an Indian beauty in a word
[SHK] The seeming truth which cunning times put on
[SHK] To entrap the wisest Therefore thou gaudy gold
[SHK] Hard food for Midas I will none of thee
[SHK] Nor none of thee thou pale and common drudge
[SHK] 'Tween man and man but thou thou meagre lead
[SHK] Which rather threatenest than dost promise aught
[SHK] Thy paleness moves me more than eloquence
[SHK] And here choose I joy be the consequence
[SHK] As doubtful thoughts and rash-embraced despair
[SHK] And shuddering fear and green-eyed jealousy O love
[SHK] Be moderate allay thy ecstasy
[SHK] In measure rein thy joy scant this excess
[SHK] I feel too much thy blessing make it less
[SHK] For fear I surfeit

[SHK] Hath come so near creation Move these eyes

[SHK] Seem they in motion Here are sever 'd lips
[SHK] Parted with sugar breath so sweet a bar
[SHK] Should sunder such sweet friends Here in her hairs
[SHK] The painter plays the spider and hath woven
[SHK] A golden mesh to entrap the hearts of men
[SHK] Faster than gnats in cobwebs but her eyes --
[SHK] How could he see to do them having made one
[SHK] Methinks it should have power to steal both his
[SHK] And leave itself unfurnish 'd Yet look how far
[SHK] The substance of my praise doth wrong this shadow
[SHK] In underprizing it so far this shadow
[SHK] Doth limp behind the substance Here 's the scroll
[SHK] The continent and summary of my fortune
[SHK] You that choose not by the view
[SHK] Chance as fair and choose as true
[SHK] Since this fortune falls to you
[SHK] Be content and seek no new
[SHK] If you be well pleased with this
[SHK] And hold your fortune for your bliss

[SHK] And claim her with a loving kiss
[SHK] A gentle scroll Fair lady by your leave
[SHK] I come by note to give and to receive
[SHK] Like one of two contending in a prize
[SHK] That thinks he hath done well in people 's eyes
[SHK] Hearing applause and universal shout
[SHK] Giddy in spirit still gazing in a doubt
[SHK] Whether these pearls of praise be his or no
[SHK] So thrice fair lady stand I even so
[SHK] As doubtful whether what I see be true
[SHK] Until confirm 'd sign 'd ratified by you
[SHK] You see me Lord Bassanio where I stand
[SHK] Such as I am though for myself alone
[SHK] I would not be ambitious in my wish
[SHK] To wish myself much better yet for you
[SHK] I would be trebled twenty times myself
[SHK] A thousand times more fair ten thousand times more rich
[SHK] That only to stand high in your account
[SHK] I might in virtue beauties livings friends

[SHK] Is sum of something which to term in gross
[SHK] Is an unlesson 'd girl unschool 'd unpractised
[SHK] Happy in this she is not yet so old
[SHK] But she may learn happier than this
[SHK] She is not bred so dull but she can learn

[SHK] Commits itself to yours to be directed
[SHK] As from her lord her governor her king

[SHK] And be my vantage to exclaim on you

[SHK] As after some oration fairly spoke
[SHK] By a beloved prince there doth appear
[SHK] Among the buzzing pleased multitude
[SHK] Where every something being blent together
[SHK] Turns to a wild of nothing save of joy

[SHK] O sweet Portia
[SHK] Here are a few of the unpleasant'st words
[SHK] That ever blotted paper Gentle lady
[SHK] When I did first impart my love to you
[SHK] I freely told you all the wealth I had
[SHK] Ran in my veins I was a gentleman
[SHK] And then I told you true and yet dear lady
[SHK] Rating myself at nothing you shall see
[SHK] How much I was a braggart When I told you
[SHK] My state was nothing I should then have told you
[SHK] That I was worse than nothing for indeed
