[SHK] Engaged my friend to his mere enemy
[SHK] To feed my means Here is a letter lady
[SHK] The paper as the body of my friend
[SHK] And every word in it a gaping wound
[SHK] Issuing life-blood But is it true Salerio
[SHK] Have all his ventures fail 'd What not one hit
[SHK] From Tripolis from Mexico and England
[SHK] From Lisbon Barbary and India
[SHK] And not one vessel 'scape the dreadful touch
[SHK] Of merchant-marring rocks
[SHK] Not one my lord
[SHK] Besides it should appear that if he had
[SHK] The present money to discharge the Jew
[SHK] He would not take it Never did I know
[SHK] A creature that did bear the shape of man
[SHK] So keen and greedy to confound a man
[SHK] He plies the duke at morning and at night
[SHK] And doth impeach the freedom of the state
[SHK] If they deny him justice twenty merchants
[SHK] The duke himself and the magnificoes
[SHK] Of greatest port have all persuaded with him
[SHK] But none can drive him from the envious plea
[SHK] Of forfeiture of justice and his bond
[SHK] When I was with him I have heard him swear
[SHK] To Tubal and to Chus his countrymen
[SHK] That he would rather have Antonio 's flesh
[SHK] Than twenty times the value of the sum
[SHK] That he did owe him and I know my lord
[SHK] If law authority and power deny not
[SHK] It will go hard with poor Antonio
[SHK] Is it your dear friend that is thus in trouble
[SHK] The dearest friend to me the kindest man
[SHK] The best-condition 'd and unwearied spirit
[SHK] In doing courtesies and one in whom
[SHK] The ancient Roman honour more appears
[SHK] Than any that draws breath in Italy
[SHK] What sum owes he the Jew
[SHK] For me three thousand ducats
[SHK] What no more
[SHK] Pay him six thousand and deface the bond
[SHK] Double six thousand and then treble that
[SHK] Before a friend of this description
[SHK] Shall lose a hair through Bassanio 's fault
[SHK] First go with me to church and call me wife
[SHK] And then away to Venice to your friend
[SHK] For never shall you lie by Portia 's side
[SHK] With an unquiet soul You shall have gold
[SHK] To pay the petty debt twenty times over
[SHK] When it is paid bring your true friend along
[SHK] My maid Nerissa and myself meantime
[SHK] Will live as maids and widows Come away
[SHK] For you shall hence upon your wedding-day
[SHK] Bid your friends welcome show a merry cheer
[SHK] Since you are dear bought I will love you dear
[SHK] But let me hear the letter of your friend
[SHK] miscarried my creditors grow cruel my estate is
[SHK] very low my bond to the Jew is forfeit and since
[SHK] in paying it it is impossible I should live all
[SHK] debts are cleared between you and I if I might but
[SHK] see you at my death Notwithstanding use your
[SHK] pleasure if your love do not persuade you to come
[SHK] let not my letter
[SHK] O love dispatch all business and be gone
[SHK] Since I have your good leave to go away
[SHK] I will make haste but till I come again
[SHK] No bed shall e'er be guilty of my stay
[SHK] No rest be interposer 'twixt us twain
[SHK] Gaoler look to him tell not me of mercy
[SHK] This is the fool that lent out money gratis
[SHK] Gaoler look to him
[SHK] Hear me yet good Shylock
[SHK] I 'll have my bond speak not against my bond
[SHK] I have sworn an oath that I will have my bond
[SHK] Thou call'dst me dog before thou hadst a cause
[SHK] But since I am a dog beware my fangs
[SHK] The duke shall grant me justice I do wonder
[SHK] Thou naughty gaoler that thou art so fond
[SHK] To come abroad with him at his request
[SHK] I pray thee hear me speak
[SHK] I 'll have my bond I will not hear thee speak
[SHK] I 'll have my bond and therefore speak no more
[SHK] I 'll not be made a soft and dull-eyed fool
[SHK] To shake the head relent and sigh and yield
[SHK] To Christian intercessors Follow not
[SHK] I 'll have no speaking I will have my bond
[SHK] It is the most impenetrable cur
[SHK] That ever kept with men
[SHK] Let him alone
[SHK] I 'll follow him no more with bootless prayers
[SHK] He seeks my life his reason well I know
[SHK] I oft deliver 'd from his forfeitures
[SHK] Many that have at times made moan to me
[SHK] Therefore he hates me
[SHK] I am sure the duke
[SHK] Will never grant this forfeiture to hold
[SHK] The duke can not deny the course of law
[SHK] For the commodity that strangers have
[SHK] With us in Venice if it be denied
[SHK] Will much impeach the justice of his state
[SHK] Since that the trade and profit of the city
[SHK] Consisteth of all nations Therefore go
[SHK] These griefs and losses have so bated me
[SHK] That I shall hardly spare a pound of flesh
[SHK] To-morrow to my bloody creditor
[SHK] Well gaoler on Pray God Bassanio come
[SHK] To see me pay his debt and then I care not
[SHK] Madam although I speak it in your presence
[SHK] You have a noble and a true conceit
[SHK] Of godlike amity which appears most strongly
[SHK] In bearing thus the absence of your lord
[SHK] But if you knew to whom you show this honour
[SHK] How true a gentleman you send relief
[SHK] How dear a lover of my lord your husband
[SHK] I know you would be prouder of the work
[SHK] Than customary bounty can enforce you
[SHK] I never did repent for doing good
[SHK] Nor shall not now for in companions
[SHK] That do converse and waste the time together
[SHK] Whose souls do bear an equal yoke Of love
[SHK] There must be needs a like proportion
[SHK] Of lineaments of manners and of spirit
[SHK] Which makes me think that this Antonio
[SHK] Being the bosom lover of my lord
[SHK] Must needs be like my lord If it be so
[SHK] How little is the cost I have bestow 'd
[SHK] In purchasing the semblance of my soul
[SHK] From out the state of hellish misery
[SHK] This comes too near the praising of myself
[SHK] Therefore no more of it hear other things
[SHK] Lorenzo I commit into your hands
[SHK] The husbandry and manage of my house
[SHK] Until my lord 's return for mine own part
[SHK] I have toward heaven breathed a secret vow
[SHK] To live in prayer and contemplation
[SHK] Only attended by Nerissa here
[SHK] Until her husband and my lord 's return
[SHK] There is a monastery two miles off
[SHK] And there will we abide I do desire you
[SHK] Not to deny this imposition
[SHK] The which my love and some necessity
[SHK] Now lays upon you
[SHK] Madam with all my heart
[SHK] I shall obey you in all fair commands
[SHK] My people do already know my mind
[SHK] And will acknowledge you and Jessica
[SHK] In place of Lord Bassanio and myself
[SHK] And so farewell till we shall meet again
[SHK] Fair thoughts and happy hours attend on you
[SHK] I wish your ladyship all heart 's content
[SHK] I thank you for your wish and am well pleased
[SHK] To wish it back on you fare you well Jessica
[SHK] Now Balthasar
[SHK] As I have ever found thee honest-true
[SHK] So let me find thee still Take this same letter
[SHK] And use thou all the endeavour of a man
[SHK] In speed to Padua see thou render this
[SHK] Into my cousin 's hand Doctor Bellario
[SHK] And look what notes and garments he doth give thee
[SHK] Bring them I pray thee with imagined speed
[SHK] Unto the tranect to the common ferry
[SHK] Which trades to Venice Waste no time in words
[SHK] But get thee gone I shall be there before thee
[SHK] Madam I go with all convenient speed
[SHK] Come on Nerissa I have work in hand
[SHK] That you yet know not of we 'll see our husbands
[SHK] Before they think of us
[SHK] Shall they see us
[SHK] They shall Nerissa but in such a habit
[SHK] That they shall think we are accomplished
[SHK] With that we lack I 'll hold thee any wager
[SHK] When we are both accoutred like young men
[SHK] I 'll prove the prettier fellow of the two
[SHK] And wear my dagger with the braver grace
[SHK] And speak between the change of man and boy
[SHK] With a reed voice and turn two mincing steps
[SHK] Into a manly stride and speak of frays
[SHK] Like a fine bragging youth and tell quaint lies
[SHK] How honourable ladies sought my love
[SHK] Which I denying they fell sick and died
[SHK] I could not do withal then I 'll repent
[SHK] And wish for all that that I had not killed them
[SHK] And twenty of these puny lies I 'll tell
[SHK] That men shall swear I have discontinued school
[SHK] Above a twelvemonth I have within my mind
[SHK] A thousand raw tricks of these bragging Jacks
[SHK] Which I will practise
[SHK] Why shall we turn to men
[SHK] Fie what a question 's that
[SHK] If thou wert near a lewd interpreter
[SHK] But come I 'll tell thee all my whole device
[SHK] When I am in my coach which stays for us
[SHK] At the park gate and therefore haste away
[SHK] For we must measure twenty miles to-day
[SHK] Yes truly for look you the sins of the father
[SHK] are to be laid upon the children therefore I
[SHK] promise ye I fear you I was always plain with
[SHK] you and so now I speak my agitation of the matter
[SHK] therefore be of good cheer for truly I think you
[SHK] are damned There is but one hope in it that can do
[SHK] you any good and that is but a kind of bastard
[SHK] hope neither
[SHK] And what hope is that I pray thee
[SHK] Marry you may partly hope that your father got you
[SHK] not that you are not the Jew 's daughter
[SHK] That were a kind of bastard hope indeed so the
[SHK] sins of my mother should be visited upon me
[SHK] Truly then I fear you are damned both by father and
[SHK] mother thus when I shun Scylla your father I
[SHK] fall into Charybdis your mother well you are
[SHK] gone both ways
[SHK] I shall be saved by my husband he hath made me a
[SHK] Christian
[SHK] Truly the more to blame he we were Christians
[SHK] enow before e'en as many as could well live one by
[SHK] another This making Christians will raise the
[SHK] price of hogs if we grow all to be pork-eaters we
[SHK] shall not shortly have a rasher on the coals for money
[SHK] I 'll tell my husband Launcelot what you say here he comes
[SHK] I shall grow jealous of you shortly Launcelot if
[SHK] you thus get my wife into corners
[SHK] Nay you need not fear us Lorenzo Launcelot and I
[SHK] are out He tells me flatly there is no mercy for
[SHK] me in heaven because I am a Jew 's daughter and he
[SHK] says you are no good member of the commonwealth
[SHK] for in converting Jews to Christians you raise the
[SHK] price of pork
[SHK] I shall answer that better to the commonwealth than
[SHK] you can the getting up of the negro 's belly the
[SHK] Moor is with child by you Launcelot
[SHK] It is much that the Moor should be more than reason
[SHK] but if she be less than an honest woman she is
[SHK] indeed more than I took her for
[SHK] How every fool can play upon the word I think the
[SHK] best grace of wit will shortly turn into silence
[SHK] and discourse grow commendable in none only but
[SHK] parrots Go in sirrah bid them prepare for dinner
[SHK] That is done sir they have all stomachs
[SHK] Goodly Lord what a wit-snapper are you then bid
[SHK] them prepare dinner
[SHK] That is done too sir only 'cover is the word
[SHK] Will you cover then sir
[SHK] Not so sir neither I know my duty
[SHK] Yet more quarrelling with occasion Wilt thou show
[SHK] the whole wealth of thy wit in an instant I pray
[SHK] tree understand a plain man in his plain meaning
[SHK] go to thy fellows bid them cover the table serve
[SHK] in the meat and we will come in to dinner
[SHK] For the table sir it shall be served in for the
[SHK] meat sir it shall be covered for your coming in
[SHK] to dinner sir why let it be as humours and
[SHK] conceits shall govern
[SHK] O dear discretion how his words are suited
[SHK] The fool hath planted in his memory
[SHK] An army of good words and I do know
[SHK] A many fools that stand in better place
[SHK] Garnish 'd like him that for a tricksy word
[SHK] Defy the matter How cheerest thou Jessica
[SHK] And now good sweet say thy opinion
[SHK] How dost thou like the Lord Bassanio 's wife
[SHK] Past all expressing It is very meet
[SHK] The Lord Bassanio live an upright life
[SHK] For having such a blessing in his lady
[SHK] He finds the joys of heaven here on earth
[SHK] And if on earth he do not mean it then
[SHK] In reason he should never come to heaven
[SHK] Why if two gods should play some heavenly match
[SHK] And on the wager lay two earthly women
[SHK] And Portia one there must be something else
[SHK] Pawn 'd with the other for the poor rude world
[SHK] Hath not her fellow
[SHK] Even such a husband
[SHK] Hast thou of me as she is for a wife
[SHK] Nay but ask my opinion too of that
[SHK] I will anon first let us go to dinner
[SHK] Nay let me praise you while I have a stomach
[SHK] No pray thee let it serve for table-talk
[SHK] Then howso'er thou speak'st 'mong other things
[SHK] I shall digest it
[SHK] Well I 'll set you forth
[SHK] What is Antonio here
[SHK] Ready so please your grace
[SHK] I am sorry for thee thou art come to answer
[SHK] A stony adversary an inhuman wretch
[SHK] uncapable of pity void and empty
[SHK] From any dram of mercy
[SHK] I have heard
[SHK] Your grace hath ta'en great pains to qualify
[SHK] His rigorous course but since he stands obdurate
[SHK] And that no lawful means can carry me
[SHK] Out of his envy 's reach I do oppose
[SHK] My patience to his fury and am arm 'd
[SHK] To suffer with a quietness of spirit
[SHK] The very tyranny and rage of his
[SHK] Go one and call the Jew into the court
[SHK] He is ready at the door he comes my lord
[SHK] Make room and let him stand before our face
[SHK] Shylock the world thinks and I think so too
[SHK] That thou but lead'st this fashion of thy malice
[SHK] To the last hour of act and then 't is thought
[SHK] Thou'lt show thy mercy and remorse more strange
[SHK] Than is thy strange apparent cruelty
[SHK] And where thou now exact'st the penalty
[SHK] Which is a pound of this poor merchant 's flesh
[SHK] Thou wilt not only loose the forfeiture
[SHK] But touch 'd with human gentleness and love
[SHK] Forgive a moiety of the principal
[SHK] Glancing an eye of pity on his losses
[SHK] That have of late so huddled on his back
[SHK] Enow to press a royal merchant down
[SHK] And pluck commiseration of his state
[SHK] From brassy bosoms and rough hearts of flint
[SHK] From stubborn Turks and Tartars never train 'd
[SHK] To offices of tender courtesy
[SHK] We all expect a gentle answer Jew
[SHK] I have possess 'd your grace of what I purpose
[SHK] And by our holy Sabbath have I sworn
[SHK] To have the due and forfeit of my bond
[SHK] If you deny it let the danger light
[SHK] Upon your charter and your city 's freedom
[SHK] You 'll ask me why I rather choose to have
[SHK] A weight of carrion flesh than to receive
[SHK] Three thousand ducats I 'll not answer that
[SHK] But say it is my humour is it answer 'd
[SHK] What if my house be troubled with a rat
[SHK] And I be pleased to give ten thousand ducats
[SHK] To have it baned What are you answer 'd yet
[SHK] Some men there are love not a gaping pig
[SHK] Some that are mad if they behold a cat
[SHK] And others when the bagpipe sings i the nose
[SHK] Can not contain their urine for affection
[SHK] Mistress of passion sways it to the mood
[SHK] Of what it likes or loathes Now for your answer
[SHK] As there is no firm reason to be render 'd
[SHK] Why he can not abide a gaping pig
[SHK] Why he a harmless necessary cat
[SHK] Why he a woollen bagpipe but of force
[SHK] Must yield to such inevitable shame
[SHK] As to offend himself being offended
[SHK] So can I give no reason nor I will not
[SHK] More than a lodged hate and a certain loathing
[SHK] I bear Antonio that I follow thus
[SHK] A losing suit against him Are you answer 'd
[SHK] This is no answer thou unfeeling man
[SHK] To excuse the current of thy cruelty
[SHK] I am not bound to please thee with my answers
[SHK] Do all men kill the things they do not love
[SHK] Hates any man the thing he would not kill
[SHK] Every offence is not a hate at first
[SHK] What wouldst thou have a serpent sting thee twice
[SHK] I pray you think you question with the Jew
[SHK] You may as well go stand upon the beach
[SHK] And bid the main flood bate his usual height
[SHK] You may as well use question with the wolf
[SHK] Why he hath made the ewe bleat for the lamb
[SHK] You may as well forbid the mountain pines
[SHK] To wag their high tops and to make no noise
[SHK] When they are fretten with the gusts of heaven
[SHK] You may as well do anything most hard
[SHK] As seek to soften that -- than which what 's harder --
[SHK] His Jewish heart therefore I do beseech you
[SHK] Make no more offers use no farther means
[SHK] But with all brief and plain conveniency
[SHK] Let me have judgment and the Jew his will
[SHK] For thy three thousand ducats here is six
[SHK] What judgment shall I dread doing
[SHK] Were in six parts and every part a ducat
[SHK] I would not draw them I would have my bond
[SHK] How shalt thou hope for mercy rendering none
[SHK] What judgment shall I dread doing no wrong
[SHK] You have among you many a purchased slave
[SHK] Which like your asses and your dogs and mules
[SHK] You use in abject and in slavish parts
[SHK] Because you bought them shall I say to you
[SHK] Let them be free marry them to your heirs
[SHK] Why sweat they under burthens let their beds
[SHK] Be made as soft as yours and let their palates
[SHK] Be season 'd with such viands You will answer
[SHK] 'The slaves are ours so do I answer you
[SHK] The pound of flesh which I demand of him
[SHK] Is dearly bought 't is mine and I will have it
[SHK] If you deny me fie upon your law
[SHK] There is no force in the decrees of Venice
[SHK] I stand for judgment answer shall I have it
[SHK] Upon my power I may dismiss this court
[SHK] Unless Bellario a learned doctor
[SHK] Whom I have sent for to determine this
[SHK] Come here to-day
[SHK] My lord here stays without
[SHK] A messenger with letters from the doctor
[SHK] New come from Padua
[SHK] Bring us the letter call the messenger
[SHK] Good cheer Antonio What man courage yet
[SHK] The Jew shall have my flesh blood bones and all
[SHK] Ere thou shalt lose for me one drop of blood
[SHK] I am a tainted wether of the flock
[SHK] Meetest for death the weakest kind of fruit
[SHK] Drops earliest to the ground and so let me
[SHK] You can not better be employ 'd Bassanio
[SHK] Than to live still and write mine epitaph
[SHK] Came you from Padua from Bellario
[SHK] From both my lord Bellario greets your grace
[SHK] Why dost thou whet thy knife so earnestly
[SHK] To cut the forfeiture from that bankrupt there
[SHK] Not on thy sole but on thy soul harsh Jew
[SHK] Thou makest thy knife keen but no metal can
[SHK] No not the hangman 's axe bear half the keenness
[SHK] Of thy sharp envy Can no prayers pierce thee
[SHK] No none that thou hast wit enough to make
[SHK] O be thou damn 'd inexecrable dog
[SHK] And for thy life let justice be accused
[SHK] Thou almost makest me waver in my faith
[SHK] To hold opinion with Pythagoras
[SHK] That souls of animals infuse themselves
[SHK] Into the trunks of men thy currish spirit
[SHK] Govern 'd a wolf who hang 'd for human slaughter
[SHK] Even from the gallows did his fell soul fleet
[SHK] And whilst thou lay'st in thy unhallow 'd dam
[SHK] Infused itself in thee for thy desires
[SHK] Are wolvish bloody starved and ravenous
[SHK] Till thou canst rail the seal from off my bond
[SHK] Thou but offend'st thy lungs to speak so loud
[SHK] Repair thy wit good youth or it will fall
[SHK] To cureless ruin I stand here for law
[SHK] This letter from Bellario doth commend
[SHK] A young and learned doctor to our court
[SHK] Where is he
[SHK] He attendeth here hard by
[SHK] To know your answer whether you 'll admit him
[SHK] With all my heart Some three or four of you
[SHK] Go give him courteous conduct to this place
[SHK] Meantime the court shall hear Bellario 's letter
[SHK] Your grace shall understand that at the receipt of
[SHK] your letter I am very sick but in the instant that
[SHK] your messenger came in loving visitation was with
[SHK] me a young doctor of Rome his name is Balthasar I
[SHK] acquainted him with the cause in controversy between
[SHK] the Jew and Antonio the merchant we turned o'er
[SHK] many books together he is furnished with my
[SHK] opinion which bettered with his own learning the
[SHK] greatness whereof I can not enough commend comes
[SHK] with him at my importunity to fill up your grace 's
[SHK] request in my stead I beseech you let his lack of
[SHK] years be no impediment to let him lack a reverend
[SHK] estimation for I never knew so young a body with so
[SHK] old a head I leave him to your gracious
[SHK] acceptance whose trial shall better publish his
[SHK] commendation
[SHK] You hear the learn 'd Bellario what he writes
[SHK] And here I take it is the doctor come
[SHK] Give me your hand Come you from old Bellario
[SHK] I did my lord
[SHK] You are welcome take your place
[SHK] Are you acquainted with the difference
[SHK] That holds this present question in the court
[SHK] I am informed thoroughly of the cause
[SHK] Which is the merchant here and which the Jew
[SHK] Antonio and old Shylock both stand forth
[SHK] Is your name Shylock
[SHK] Shylock is my name
[SHK] Of a strange nature is the suit you follow
[SHK] Yet in such rule that the Venetian law
[SHK] Can not impugn you as you do proceed
[SHK] You stand within his danger do you not
[SHK] Ay so he says
[SHK] Do you confess the bond
[SHK] I do
[SHK] Then must the Jew be merciful
[SHK] On what compulsion must I tell me that
[SHK] The quality of mercy is not strain 'd
[SHK] It droppeth as the gentle rain from heaven
[SHK] Upon the place beneath it is twice blest
[SHK] It blesseth him that gives and him that takes
[SHK] 'T is mightiest in the mightiest it becomes
[SHK] The throned monarch better than his crown
[SHK] His sceptre shows the force of temporal power
[SHK] The attribute to awe and majesty
[SHK] Wherein doth sit the dread and fear of kings
[SHK] But mercy is above this sceptred sway
[SHK] It is enthroned in the hearts of kings
[SHK] It is an attribute to God himself
[SHK] And earthly power doth then show likest God 's
[SHK] When mercy seasons justice Therefore Jew
[SHK] Though justice be thy plea consider this
[SHK] That in the course of justice none of us
[SHK] Should see salvation we do pray for mercy
[SHK] And that same prayer doth teach us all to render
[SHK] The deeds of mercy I have spoke thus much
[SHK] To mitigate the justice of thy plea
[SHK] Which if thou follow this strict court of Venice
[SHK] Must needs give sentence 'gainst the merchant there
[SHK] My deeds upon my head I crave the law
[SHK] The penalty and forfeit of my bond
[SHK] Is he not able to discharge the money
[SHK] Yes here I tender it for him in the court
[SHK] Yea twice the sum if that will not suffice
[SHK] I will be bound to pay it ten times o'er
[SHK] On forfeit of my hands my head my heart
[SHK] If this will not suffice it must appear
[SHK] That malice bears down truth And I beseech you
[SHK] Wrest once the law to your authority
[SHK] To do a great right do a little wrong
[SHK] And curb this cruel devil of his will
[SHK] It must not be there is no power in Venice
[SHK] Can alter a decree established
[SHK] 'Twill be recorded for a precedent
[SHK] And many an error by the same example
[SHK] Will rush into the state it can not be
[SHK] A Daniel come to judgment yea a Daniel
[SHK] O wise young judge how I do honour thee
[SHK] I pray you let me look upon the bond
[SHK] Here 't is most reverend doctor here it is
[SHK] Shylock there 's thrice thy money offer 'd thee
[SHK] An oath an oath I have an oath in heaven
[SHK] Shall I lay perjury upon my soul
[SHK] No not for Venice
[SHK] Why this bond is forfeit
[SHK] And lawfully by this the Jew may claim
[SHK] A pound of flesh to be by him cut off
[SHK] Nearest the merchant 's heart Be merciful
[SHK] Take thrice thy money bid me tear the bond
[SHK] When it is paid according to the tenor
[SHK] It doth appear you are a worthy judge
[SHK] You know the law your exposition
[SHK] Hath been most sound I charge you by the law
[SHK] Whereof you are a well-deserving pillar
[SHK] Proceed to judgment by my soul I swear
[SHK] There is no power in the tongue of man
[SHK] To alter me I stay here on my bond
[SHK] Most heartily I do beseech the court
[SHK] To give the judgment
[SHK] Why then thus it is
[SHK] You must prepare your bosom for his knife
[SHK] O noble judge O excellent young man
[SHK] For the intent and purpose of the law
[SHK] Hath full relation to the penalty
[SHK] Which here appeareth due upon the bond
[SHK] 'T is very true O wise and upright judge
[SHK] How much more elder art thou than thy looks
[SHK] Therefore lay bare your bosom
[SHK] Ay his breast
[SHK] So says the bond doth it not noble judge
[SHK] 'Nearest his heart those are the very words
[SHK] It is so Are there balance here to weigh
[SHK] The flesh
[SHK] I have them ready
[SHK] Have by some surgeon Shylock on your charge
[SHK] To stop his wounds lest he do bleed to death
[SHK] Is it so nominated in the bond
[SHK] It is not so express 'd but what of that
[SHK] 'Twere good you do so much for charity
[SHK] I can not find it 't is not in the bond
[SHK] You merchant have you any thing to say
[SHK] But little I am arm 'd and well prepared
[SHK] Give me your hand Bassanio fare you well
[SHK] Grieve not that I am fallen to this for you
[SHK] For herein Fortune shows herself more kind
[SHK] Than is her custom it is still her use
[SHK] To let the wretched man outlive his wealth
[SHK] To view with hollow eye and wrinkled brow
[SHK] An age of poverty from which lingering penance
[SHK] Of such misery doth she cut me off
[SHK] Commend me to your honourable wife
[SHK] Tell her the process of Antonio 's end
[SHK] Say how I loved you speak me fair in death
[SHK] And when the tale is told bid her be judge
[SHK] Whether Bassanio had not once a love
[SHK] Repent but you that you shall lose your friend
[SHK] And he repents not that he pays your debt
[SHK] For if the Jew do cut but deep enough
[SHK] I 'll pay it presently with all my heart
[SHK] Antonio I am married to a wife
[SHK] Which is as dear to me as life itself
[SHK] But life itself my wife and all the world
[SHK] Are not with me esteem 'd above thy life
[SHK] I would lose all ay sacrifice them all
[SHK] Here to this devil to deliver you
[SHK] Your wife would give you little thanks for that
[SHK] If she were by to hear you make the offer
[SHK] I have a wife whom I protest I love
[SHK] I would she were in heaven so she could
[SHK] Entreat some power to change this currish Jew
[SHK] 'T is well you offer it behind her back
[SHK] The wish would make else an unquiet house
[SHK] These be the Christian husbands I have a daughter
[SHK] Would any of the stock of Barrabas
[SHK] Had been her husband rather than a Christian
[SHK] We trifle time I pray thee pursue sentence
[SHK] A pound of that same merchant 's flesh is thine
[SHK] The court awards it and the law doth give it
[SHK] Most rightful judge
[SHK] And you must cut this flesh from off his breast
[SHK] The law allows it and the court awards it
[SHK] Most learned judge A sentence Come prepare
[SHK] Tarry a little there is something else
[SHK] This bond doth give thee here no jot of blood
[SHK] The words expressly are a pound of flesh
[SHK] Take then thy bond take thou thy pound of flesh
[SHK] But in the cutting it if thou dost shed
[SHK] One drop of Christian blood thy lands and goods
[SHK] Are by the laws of Venice confiscate
[SHK] Unto the state of Venice
[SHK] O upright judge Mark Jew O learned judge
[SHK] Is that the law
[SHK] Thyself shalt see the act
[SHK] For as thou urgest justice be assured
[SHK] Thou shalt have justice more than thou desirest
[SHK] O learned judge Mark Jew a learned judge
[SHK] I take this offer then pay the bond thrice
[SHK] And let the Christian go
[SHK] Here is the money
[SHK] Soft
[SHK] The Jew shall have all justice soft no haste
[SHK] He shall have nothing but the penalty
[SHK] O Jew an upright judge a learned judge
[SHK] Therefore prepare thee to cut off the flesh
[SHK] Shed thou no blood nor cut thou less nor more
[SHK] But just a pound of flesh if thou cut'st more
[SHK] Or less than a just pound be it but so much
[SHK] As makes it light or heavy in the substance
[SHK] Or the division of the twentieth part
[SHK] Of one poor scruple nay if the scale do turn
[SHK] But in the estimation of a hair
[SHK] Thou diest and all thy goods are confiscate
[SHK] A second Daniel a Daniel Jew
[SHK] Now infidel I have you on the hip
[SHK] Why doth the Jew pause take thy forfeiture
[SHK] Give me my principal and let me go
[SHK] I have it ready for thee here it is
[SHK] He hath refused it in the open court
[SHK] He shall have merely justice and his bond
[SHK] A Daniel still say I a second Daniel
[SHK] I thank thee Jew for teaching me that word
[SHK] Shall I not have barely my principal
[SHK] Thou shalt have nothing but the forfeiture
[SHK] To be so taken at thy peril Jew
[SHK] Why then the devil give him good of it
[SHK] I 'll stay no longer question
[SHK] Tarry Jew
[SHK] The law hath yet another hold on you
[SHK] It is enacted in the laws of Venice
[SHK] If it be proved against an alien
[SHK] That by direct or indirect attempts
[SHK] He seek the life of any citizen
[SHK] The party 'gainst the which he doth contrive
[SHK] Shall seize one half his goods the other half
[SHK] Comes to the privy coffer of the state
[SHK] And the offender 's life lies in the mercy
[SHK] Of the duke only 'gainst all other voice
[SHK] In which predicament I say thou stand'st
[SHK] For it appears by manifest proceeding
[SHK] That indirectly and directly too
[SHK] Thou hast contrived against the very life
[SHK] Of the defendant and thou hast incurr 'd
[SHK] The danger formerly by me rehearsed
[SHK] Down therefore and beg mercy of the duke
[SHK] Beg that thou mayst have leave to hang thyself
[SHK] And yet thy wealth being forfeit to the state
[SHK] Thou hast not left the value of a cord
[SHK] Therefore thou must be hang 'd at the state 's charge
[SHK] That thou shalt see the difference of our spirits
[SHK] I pardon thee thy life before thou ask it
[SHK] For half thy wealth it is Antonio 's
[SHK] The other half comes to the general state
[SHK] Which humbleness may drive unto a fine
[SHK] Ay for the state not for Antonio
[SHK] Nay take my life and all pardon not that
[SHK] You take my house when you do take the prop
[SHK] That doth sustain my house you take my life
[SHK] When you do take the means whereby I live
[SHK] What mercy can you render him Antonio
[SHK] A halter gratis nothing else for God 's sake
[SHK] So please my lord the duke and all the court
[SHK] To quit the fine for one half of his goods
[SHK] I am content so he will let me have
[SHK] The other half in use to render it
[SHK] Upon his death unto the gentleman
[SHK] That lately stole his daughter
[SHK] Two things provided more that for this favour
[SHK] He presently become a Christian
[SHK] The other that he do record a gift
[SHK] Here in the court of all he dies possess 'd
[SHK] Unto his son Lorenzo and his daughter
[SHK] He shall do this or else I do recant
[SHK] The pardon that I late pronounced here
[SHK] Art thou contented Jew what dost thou say
[SHK] I am content
[SHK] Clerk draw a deed of gift
[SHK] I pray you give me leave to go from hence
[SHK] I am not well send the deed after me
[SHK] And I will sign it
[SHK] Get thee gone but do it
[SHK] In christening shalt thou have two god-fathers
[SHK] Had I been judge thou shouldst have had ten more
[SHK] To bring thee to the gallows not the font
[SHK] Sir I entreat you home with me to dinner
[SHK] I humbly do desire your grace of pardon
[SHK] I must away this night toward Padua
[SHK] And it is meet I presently set forth
[SHK] I am sorry that your leisure serves you not
[SHK] Antonio gratify this gentleman
[SHK] For in my mind you are much bound to him
[SHK] Most worthy gentleman I and my friend
[SHK] Have by your wisdom been this day acquitted
[SHK] Of grievous penalties in lieu whereof
[SHK] Three thousand ducats due unto the Jew
[SHK] We freely cope your courteous pains withal
[SHK] And stand indebted over and above
[SHK] In love and service to you evermore
[SHK] He is well paid that is well satisfied
[SHK] And I delivering you am satisfied
[SHK] And therein do account myself well paid
[SHK] My mind was never yet more mercenary
[SHK] I pray you know me when we meet again
[SHK] I wish you well and so I take my leave
[SHK] Dear sir of force I must attempt you further
[SHK] Take some remembrance of us as a tribute
[SHK] Not as a fee grant me two things I pray you
[SHK] Not to deny me and to pardon me
[SHK] You press me far and therefore I will yield
[SHK] Give me your gloves I 'll wear them for your sake
[SHK] And for your love I 'll take this ring from you
[SHK] Do not draw back your hand I 'll take no more
[SHK] And you in love shall not deny me this
[SHK] This ring good sir alas it is a trifle
[SHK] I will not shame myself to give you this
[SHK] I will have nothing else but only this
[SHK] And now methinks I have a mind to it
[SHK] There 's more depends on this than on the value
[SHK] The dearest ring in Venice will I give you
[SHK] And find it out by proclamation
[SHK] Only for this I pray you pardon me
[SHK] I see sir you are liberal in offers
[SHK] You taught me first to beg and now methinks
[SHK] You teach me how a beggar should be answer 'd
[SHK] Good sir this ring was given me by my wife
[SHK] And when she put it on she made me vow
[SHK] That I should neither sell nor give nor lose it
[SHK] That 'scuse serves many men to save their gifts
[SHK] An if your wife be not a mad-woman
[SHK] And know how well I have deserved the ring
[SHK] She would not hold out enemy for ever
[SHK] For giving it to me Well peace be with you
[SHK] My Lord Bassanio let him have the ring
[SHK] Let his deservings and my love withal
[SHK] Be valued against your wife 's commandment
[SHK] Go Gratiano run and overtake him
[SHK] Give him the ring and bring him if thou canst
[SHK] Unto Antonio 's house away make haste
[SHK] Come you and I will thither presently
[SHK] And in the morning early will we both
[SHK] Fly toward Belmont come Antonio
[SHK] Inquire the Jew 's house out give him this deed
[SHK] And let him sign it we 'll away to-night
[SHK] And be a day before our husbands home
[SHK] This deed will be well welcome to Lorenzo
[SHK] Fair sir you are well o'erta'en
[SHK] My Lord Bassanio upon more advice
[SHK] Hath sent you here this ring and doth entreat
[SHK] Your company at dinner
[SHK] That can not be
[SHK] His ring I do accept most thankfully
[SHK] And so I pray you tell him furthermore
[SHK] I pray you show my youth old Shylock 's house
[SHK] That will I do
[SHK] Sir I would speak with you
[SHK] I 'll see if I can get my husband 's ring
[SHK] Which I did make him swear to keep for ever
[SHK] We shall have old swearing
[SHK] That they did give the rings away to men
[SHK] But we 'll outface them and outswear them too
[SHK] Away make haste thou knowist where I will tarry
[SHK] Come good sir will you show me to this house
[SHK] The moon shines bright in such a night as this
[SHK] When the sweet wind did gently kiss the trees
[SHK] And they did make no noise in such a night
[SHK] Troilus methinks mounted the Troyan walls
[SHK] And sigh 'd his soul toward the Grecian tents
[SHK] Where Cressid lay that night
[SHK] In such a night
[SHK] Did Thisbe fearfully o'ertrip the dew
[SHK] And saw the lion 's shadow ere himself
[SHK] And ran dismay 'd away
[SHK] In such a night
[SHK] Stood Dido with a willow in her hand
[SHK] Upon the wild sea banks and waft her love
[SHK] To come again to Carthage
[SHK] In such a night
[SHK] Medea gather 'd the enchanted herbs
[SHK] That did renew old AEson
[SHK] In such a night
[SHK] Did Jessica steal from the wealthy Jew
[SHK] And with an unthrift love did run from Venice
[SHK] As far as Belmont
[SHK] In such a night
[SHK] Did young Lorenzo swear he loved her well
[SHK] Stealing her soul with many vows of faith
[SHK] And ne'er a true one
[SHK] In such a night
[SHK] Did pretty Jessica like a little shrew
[SHK] Slander her love and he forgave it her
[SHK] I would out-night you did no body come
[SHK] But hark I hear the footing of a man
[SHK] Who comes so fast in silence of the night
[SHK] A friend
[SHK] A friend what friend your name I pray you friend
[SHK] Stephano is my name and I bring word
[SHK] My mistress will before the break of day
[SHK] Be here at Belmont she doth stray about
[SHK] By holy crosses where she kneels and prays
[SHK] For happy wedlock hours
[SHK] Who comes with her
[SHK] None but a holy hermit and her maid
[SHK] I pray you is my master yet return 'd
[SHK] He is not nor we have not heard from him
[SHK] But go we in I pray thee Jessica
[SHK] And ceremoniously let us prepare
[SHK] Some welcome for the mistress of the house
[SHK] Sola sola wo ha ho sola sola
[SHK] Who calls
[SHK] Sola did you see Master Lorenzo
[SHK] Master Lorenzo sola sola
[SHK] Leave hollaing man here
[SHK] Sola where where
[SHK] Here
[SHK] Tell him there 's a post come from my master with
[SHK] his horn full of good news my master will be here
[SHK] ere morning
[SHK] Sweet soul let 's in and there expect their coming
[SHK] And yet no matter why should we go in
[SHK] My friend Stephano signify I pray you
[SHK] Within the house your mistress is at hand
[SHK] And bring your music forth into the air
[SHK] How sweet the moonlight sleeps upon this bank
[SHK] Here will we sit and let the sounds of music
[SHK] Creep in our ears soft stillness and the night
[SHK] Become the touches of sweet harmony
[SHK] Sit Jessica Look how the floor of heaven
[SHK] Is thick inlaid with patines of bright gold
[SHK] There 's not the smallest orb which thou behold'st
[SHK] But in his motion like an angel sings
[SHK] Still quiring to the young-eyed cherubins
[SHK] Such harmony is in immortal souls
[SHK] But whilst this muddy vesture of decay
[SHK] Doth grossly close it in we can not hear it
[SHK] Come ho and wake Diana with a hymn
[SHK] With sweetest touches pierce your mistress ear
[SHK] And draw her home with music
[SHK] I am never merry when I hear sweet music
[SHK] The reason is your spirits are attentive
[SHK] For do but note a wild and wanton herd
[SHK] Or race of youthful and unhandled colts
[SHK] Fetching mad bounds bellowing and neighing loud
[SHK] Which is the hot condition of their blood
[SHK] If they but hear perchance a trumpet sound
[SHK] Or any air of music touch their ears
[SHK] You shall perceive them make a mutual stand
[SHK] Their savage eyes turn 'd to a modest gaze
[SHK] By the sweet power of music therefore the poet
[SHK] Did feign that Orpheus drew trees stones and floods
[SHK] Since nought so stockish hard and full of rage
[SHK] But music for the time doth change his nature
[SHK] The man that hath no music in himself
[SHK] Nor is not moved with concord of sweet sounds
[SHK] Is fit for treasons stratagems and spoils
[SHK] The motions of his spirit are dull as night
[SHK] And his affections dark as Erebus
[SHK] Let no such man be trusted Mark the music
[SHK] That light we see is burning in my hall
[SHK] How far that little candle throws his beams
[SHK] So shines a good deed in a naughty world
[SHK] When the moon shone we did not see the candle
[SHK] So doth the greater glory dim the less
[SHK] A substitute shines brightly as a king
[SHK] Unto the king be by and then his state
[SHK] Empties itself as doth an inland brook
[SHK] Into the main of waters Music hark
[SHK] It is your music madam of the house
[SHK] Nothing is good I see without respect
[SHK] Methinks it sounds much sweeter than by day
[SHK] Silence bestows that virtue on it madam
[SHK] The crow doth sing as sweetly as the lark
[SHK] When neither is attended and I think
[SHK] The nightingale if she should sing by day
[SHK] When every goose is cackling would be thought
[SHK] No better a musician than the wren
[SHK] How many things by season season 'd are
[SHK] To their right praise and true perfection
[SHK] Peace ho the moon sleeps with Endymion
[SHK] And would not be awaked
[SHK] That is the voice
[SHK] Or I am much deceived of Portia
[SHK] He knows me as the blind man knows the cuckoo
[SHK] By the bad voice
[SHK] Dear lady welcome home
[SHK] We have been praying for our husbands healths
[SHK] Which speed we hope the better for our words
[SHK] Are they return 'd
[SHK] Madam they are not yet
[SHK] But there is come a messenger before
[SHK] To signify their coming
[SHK] Go in Nerissa
[SHK] Give order to my servants that they take
[SHK] No note at all of our being absent hence
[SHK] Nor you Lorenzo Jessica nor you
[SHK] Your husband is at hand I hear his trumpet
[SHK] We are no tell-tales madam fear you not
[SHK] This night methinks is but the daylight sick
[SHK] It looks a little paler 't is a day
[SHK] Such as the day is when the sun is hid
[SHK] We should hold day with the Antipodes
[SHK] If you would walk in absence of the sun
[SHK] Let me give light but let me not be light
[SHK] For a light wife doth make a heavy husband
[SHK] And never be Bassanio so for me
[SHK] But God sort all You are welcome home my lord
[SHK] I thank you madam Give welcome to my friend
[SHK] This is the man this is Antonio
[SHK] To whom I am so infinitely bound
[SHK] You should in all sense be much bound to him
[SHK] For as I hear he was much bound for you
[SHK] No more than I am well acquitted of
[SHK] Sir you are very welcome to our house
[SHK] It must appear in other ways than words
[SHK] Therefore I scant this breathing courtesy
[SHK] In faith I gave it to the judge 's clerk
[SHK] Would he were gelt that had it for my part
[SHK] Since you do take it love so much at heart
[SHK] A quarrel ho already what 's the matter
[SHK] About a hoop of gold a paltry ring
[SHK] That she did give me whose posy was
[SHK] For all the world like cutler 's poetry
[SHK] Upon a knife 'Love me and leave me not
[SHK] What talk you of the posy or the value
[SHK] You swore to me when I did give it you
[SHK] That you would wear it till your hour of death
[SHK] And that it should lie with you in your grave
[SHK] Though not for me yet for your vehement oaths
[SHK] You should have been respective and have kept it
[SHK] Gave it a judge 's clerk no God 's my judge
[SHK] The clerk will ne'er wear hair on 's face that had it
[SHK] He will an if he live to be a man
[SHK] Ay if a woman live to be a man
[SHK] Now by this hand I gave it to a youth
[SHK] A kind of boy a little scrubbed boy
[SHK] No higher than thyself the judge 's clerk
[SHK] A prating boy that begg 'd it as a fee
[SHK] I could not for my heart deny it him
[SHK] You were to blame I must be plain with you
[SHK] To part so slightly with your wife 's first gift
[SHK] A thing stuck on with oaths upon your finger
[SHK] And so riveted with faith unto your flesh
[SHK] I gave my love a ring and made him swear
[SHK] Never to part with it and here he stands
[SHK] I dare be sworn for him he would not leave it
[SHK] Nor pluck it from his finger for the wealth
[SHK] That the world masters Now in faith Gratiano
[SHK] You give your wife too unkind a cause of grief
[SHK] An 'twere to me I should be mad at it
[SHK] And swear I lost the ring defending it
[SHK] My Lord Bassanio gave his ring away
[SHK] Unto the judge that begg 'd it and indeed
[SHK] Deserved it too and then the boy his clerk
[SHK] That took some pains in writing he begg 'd mine
[SHK] And neither man nor master would take aught
[SHK] But the two rings
[SHK] What ring gave you my lord
[SHK] Not that I hope which you received of me
[SHK] If I could add a lie unto a fault
[SHK] I would deny it but you see my finger
[SHK] Hath not the ring upon it it is gone
[SHK] Even so void is your false heart of truth
[SHK] By heaven I will ne'er come in your bed
[SHK] Until I see the ring
[SHK] Nor I in yours
[SHK] Till I again see mine
[SHK] Sweet Portia
[SHK] If you did know to whom I gave the ring
[SHK] If you did know for whom I gave the ring
[SHK] And would conceive for what I gave the ring
[SHK] And how unwillingly I left the ring
[SHK] When nought would be accepted but the ring
[SHK] You would abate the strength of your displeasure
[SHK] If you had known the virtue of the ring
[SHK] Or half her worthiness that gave the ring
[SHK] Or your own honour to contain the ring
[SHK] You would not then have parted with the ring
[SHK] What man is there so much unreasonable
[SHK] If you had pleased to have defended it
[SHK] With any terms of zeal wanted the modesty
[SHK] To urge the thing held as a ceremony
[SHK] Nerissa teaches me what to believe
[SHK] I 'll die for't but some woman had the ring
[SHK] No by my honour madam by my soul
[SHK] No woman had it but a civil doctor
[SHK] Which did refuse three thousand ducats of me
[SHK] And begg 'd the ring the which I did deny him
[SHK] And suffer 'd him to go displeased away
[SHK] Even he that did uphold the very life
[SHK] Of my dear friend What should I say sweet lady
[SHK] I was enforced to send it after him
[SHK] I was beset with shame and courtesy
[SHK] My honour would not let ingratitude
[SHK] So much besmear it Pardon me good lady
[SHK] For by these blessed candles of the night
[SHK] Had you been there I think you would have begg 'd
[SHK] The ring of me to give the worthy doctor
[SHK] Let not that doctor e'er come near my house
[SHK] Since he hath got the jewel that I loved
[SHK] And that which you did swear to keep for me
[SHK] I will become as liberal as you
[SHK] I 'll not deny him any thing I have
[SHK] No not my body nor my husband 's bed
[SHK] Know him I shall I am well sure of it
[SHK] Lie not a night from home watch me like Argus
[SHK] If you do not if I be left alone
[SHK] Now by mine honour which is yet mine own
[SHK] I 'll have that doctor for my bedfellow
[SHK] And I his clerk therefore be well advised
[SHK] How you do leave me to mine own protection
[SHK] Well do you so let not me take him then
[SHK] For if I do I 'll mar the young clerk 's pen
[SHK] I am the unhappy subject of these quarrels
[SHK] Sir grieve not you you are welcome notwithstanding
[SHK] Portia forgive me this enforced wrong
[SHK] And in the hearing of these many friends
[SHK] I swear to thee even by thine own fair eyes
[SHK] Wherein I see myself --
[SHK] Mark you but that
[SHK] In both my eyes he doubly sees himself
[SHK] In each eye one swear by your double self
[SHK] And there 's an oath of credit
[SHK] Nay but hear me
[SHK] Pardon this fault and by my soul I swear
[SHK] I never more will break an oath with thee
[SHK] I once did lend my body for his wealth
[SHK] Which but for him that had your husband 's ring
[SHK] Had quite miscarried I dare be bound again
[SHK] My soul upon the forfeit that your lord
[SHK] Will never more break faith advisedly
[SHK] Then you shall be his surety Give him this
[SHK] And bid him keep it better than the other
[SHK] Here Lord Bassanio swear to keep this ring
[SHK] By heaven it is the same I gave the doctor
[SHK] I had it of him pardon me Bassanio
[SHK] For by this ring the doctor lay with me
[SHK] And pardon me my gentle Gratiano
[SHK] For that same scrubbed boy the doctor 's clerk
[SHK] In lieu of this last night did lie with me
[SHK] Why this is like the mending of highways
[SHK] In summer where the ways are fair enough
[SHK] What are we cuckolds ere we have deserved it
[SHK] Speak not so grossly You are all amazed
[SHK] Here is a letter read it at your leisure
[SHK] It comes from Padua from Bellario
[SHK] There you shall find that Portia was the doctor
[SHK] Nerissa there her clerk Lorenzo here
[SHK] Shall witness I set forth as soon as you
[SHK] And even but now return 'd I have not yet
[SHK] Enter 'd my house Antonio you are welcome
[SHK] And I have better news in store for you
[SHK] Than you expect unseal this letter soon
[SHK] There you shall find three of your argosies
[SHK] Are richly come to harbour suddenly
[SHK] You shall not know by what strange accident
[SHK] I chanced on this letter
[SHK] I am dumb
[SHK] Were you the doctor and I knew you not
[SHK] Were you the clerk that is to make me cuckold
[SHK] Ay but the clerk that never means to do it
[SHK] Unless he live until he be a man
[SHK] Sweet doctor you shall be my bed-fellow
[SHK] When I am absent then lie with my wife
[SHK] Sweet lady you have given me life and living
[SHK] For here I read for certain that my ships
[SHK] Are safely come to road
[SHK] How now Lorenzo
[SHK] My clerk hath some good comforts too for you
[SHK] Ay and I 'll give them him without a fee
[SHK] There do I give to you and Jessica
[SHK] From the rich Jew a special deed of gift
[SHK] After his death of all he dies possess 'd of
[SHK] Fair ladies you drop manna in the way
[SHK] Of starved people
[SHK] It is almost morning
[SHK] And yet I am sure you are not satisfied
[SHK] Of these events at full Let us go in
[SHK] And charge us there upon inter'gatories
[SHK] And we will answer all things faithfully
[SHK] Let it be so the first inter'gatory
[SHK] That my Nerissa shall be sworn on is
[SHK] Whether till the next night she had rather stay
[SHK] Or go to bed now being two hours to day
[SHK] But were the day come I should wish it dark
[SHK] That I were couching with the doctor 's clerk
[SHK] Well while I live I 'll fear no other thing
[SHK] So sore as keeping safe Nerissa 's ring
[SHK] Tush never tell me I take it much unkindly
[SHK] That thou Iago who hast had my purse
[SHK] As if the strings were thine shouldst know of this
[SHK] 'Sblood but you will not hear me
[SHK] If ever I did dream of such a matter Abhor me
[SHK] Thou told'st me thou didst hold him in thy hate
[SHK] Despise me if I do not Three great ones of the city
[SHK] In personal suit to make me his lieutenant
[SHK] Off-capp 'd to him and by the faith of man
[SHK] I know my price I am worth no worse a place
[SHK] But he as loving his own pride and purposes
[SHK] Evades them with a bombast circumstance
[SHK] Horribly stuff 'd with epithets of war
[SHK] And in conclusion
[SHK] Nonsuits my mediators for 'Certes says he
[SHK] I have already chose my officer
[SHK] And what was he
[SHK] Forsooth a great arithmetician
[SHK] One Michael Cassio a Florentine
[SHK] A fellow almost damn 'd in a fair wife
[SHK] That never set a squadron in the field
[SHK] Nor the division of a battle knows
[SHK] More than a spinster unless the bookish theoric
[SHK] Wherein the toged consuls can propose
[SHK] As masterly as he mere prattle without practise
[SHK] Is all his soldiership But he sir had the election
[SHK] And I of whom his eyes had seen the proof
[SHK] At Rhodes at Cyprus and on other grounds
[SHK] Christian and heathen must be be-lee 'd and calm 'd
[SHK] By debitor and creditor this counter-caster
[SHK] He in good time must his lieutenant be
[SHK] And I -- God bless the mark -- his Moorship 's ancient
[SHK] By heaven I rather would have been his hangman
[SHK] Why there 's no remedy 't is the curse of service
[SHK] Preferment goes by letter and affection
[SHK] And not by old gradation where each second
[SHK] Stood heir to the first Now sir be judge yourself
[SHK] Whether I in any just term am affined
[SHK] To love the Moor
[SHK] I would not follow him then
[SHK] O sir content you
[SHK] I follow him to serve my turn upon him
[SHK] We can not all be masters nor all masters
[SHK] Can not be truly follow 'd You shall mark
[SHK] Many a duteous and knee-crooking knave
[SHK] That doting on his own obsequious bondage
[SHK] Wears out his time much like his master 's ass
[SHK] For nought but provender and when he 's old cashier 'd
[SHK] Whip me such honest knaves Others there are
[SHK] Who trimm 'd in forms and visages of duty
[SHK] Keep yet their hearts attending on themselves
[SHK] And throwing but shows of service on their lords
[SHK] Do well thrive by them and when they have lined
[SHK] their coats
[SHK] Do themselves homage these fellows have some soul
[SHK] And such a one do I profess myself For sir
[SHK] It is as sure as you are Roderigo
[SHK] Were I the Moor I would not be Iago
[SHK] In following him I follow but myself
[SHK] Heaven is my judge not I for love and duty
[SHK] But seeming so for my peculiar end
[SHK] For when my outward action doth demonstrate
[SHK] The native act and figure of my heart
[SHK] In compliment extern 't is not long after
[SHK] But I will wear my heart upon my sleeve
[SHK] For daws to peck at I am not what I am
[SHK] What a full fortune does the thicklips owe
[SHK] If he can carry't thus
[SHK] Call up her father
[SHK] Rouse him make after him poison his delight
[SHK] Proclaim him in the streets incense her kinsmen
[SHK] And though he in a fertile climate dwell
[SHK] Plague him with flies though that his joy be joy
[SHK] Yet throw such changes of vexation o n't
[SHK] As it may lose some colour
[SHK] Here is her father 's house I 'll call aloud
[SHK] Do with like timorous accent and dire yell
[SHK] As when by night and negligence the fire
[SHK] Is spied in populous cities
[SHK] What ho Brabantio Signior Brabantio ho
[SHK] Awake what ho Brabantio thieves thieves thieves
[SHK] Look to your house your daughter and your bags

[SHK] Signior is all your family within

[SHK] your gown
[SHK] Your heart is burst you have lost half your soul

[SHK] Is topping your white ewe Arise arise

[SHK] My name is Roderigo
[SHK] The worser welcome
[SHK] I have charged thee not to haunt about my doors
[SHK] In honest plainness thou hast heard me say
[SHK] My daughter is not for thee and now in madness

[SHK] Upon malicious bravery dost thou come
[SHK] To start my quiet
[SHK] Sir sir sir --
[SHK] But thou must needs be sure
[SHK] My spirit and my place have in them power
[SHK] To make this bitter to thee

[SHK] do you service and you think we are ruffians you 'll
[SHK] have your daughter covered with a Barbary horse
[SHK] you 'll have your nephews neigh to you you 'll have
[SHK] coursers for cousins and gennets for germans

[SHK] If't be your pleasure and most wise consent
[SHK] As partly I find it is that your fair daughter
[SHK] At this odd-even and dull watch o the night
[SHK] Transported with no worse nor better guard
[SHK] But with a knave of common hire a gondolier
[SHK] To the gross clasps of a lascivious Moor --
[SHK] If this be known to you and your allowance
[SHK] We then have done you bold and saucy wrongs
[SHK] But if you know not this my manners tell me
[SHK] We have your wrong rebuke Do not believe
[SHK] That from the sense of all civility
[SHK] I thus would play and trifle with your reverence
[SHK] Your daughter if you have not given her leave
[SHK] I say again hath made a gross revolt
[SHK] Tying her duty beauty wit and fortunes
[SHK] In an extravagant and wheeling stranger
[SHK] Of here and every where Straight satisfy yourself
[SHK] If she be in her chamber or your house

[SHK] It seems not meet nor wholesome to my place
[SHK] To be produced -- as if I stay I shall --

[SHK] With such loud reason to the Cyprus wars

[SHK] Another of his fathom they have none

[SHK] Though I do hate him as I do hell-pains

[SHK] Sometimes to do me service nine or ten times
[SHK] I had thought to have yerk 'd him here under the ribs
[SHK] 'T is better as it is

[SHK] If she in chains of magic were not bound
[SHK] Whether a maid so tender fair and happy
[SHK] So opposite to marriage that she shunned
[SHK] The wealthy curled darlings of our nation
[SHK] Would ever have to incur a general mock
[SHK] Run from her guardage to the sooty bosom

[SHK] Judge me the world if 't is not gross in sense
[SHK] That thou hast practised on her with foul charms
[SHK] Abused her delicate youth with drugs or minerals
[SHK] That weaken motion I 'll have't disputed on
[SHK] 'T is probable and palpable to thinking

[SHK] Of arts inhibited and out of warrant

[SHK] There is no composition in these news
[SHK] That gives them credit
[SHK] Indeed they are disproportion 'd

[SHK] A Turkish fleet and bearing up to Cyprus

[SHK] How say you by this change

[SHK] By no assay of reason 't is a pageant

[SHK] The importancy of Cyprus to the Turk
[SHK] And let ourselves again but understand
[SHK] That as it more concerns the Turk than Rhodes
[SHK] So may he with more facile question bear it
[SHK] For that it stands not in such warlike brace
[SHK] But altogether lacks the abilities
[SHK] That Rhodes is dress 'd in if we make thought of this
[SHK] We must not think the Turk is so unskilful
[SHK] To leave that latest which concerns him first
[SHK] Neglecting an attempt of ease and gain
[SHK] To wake and wage a danger profitless
[SHK] Nay in all confidence he 's not for Rhodes
[SHK] Here is more news
[SHK] The Ottomites reverend and gracious
[SHK] Steering with due course towards the isle of Rhodes
[SHK] Have there injointed them with an after fleet

[SHK] That it engluts and swallows other sorrows
[SHK] And it is still itself

[SHK] Dead

[SHK] It is most true true I have married her
[SHK] The very head and front of my offending
[SHK] Hath this extent no more Rude am I in my speech
[SHK] And little bless 'd with the soft phrase of peace
[SHK] For since these arms of mine had seven years pith
[SHK] Till now some nine moons wasted they have used
[SHK] Their dearest action in the tented field
[SHK] And little of this great world can I speak
[SHK] More than pertains to feats of broil and battle
[SHK] And therefore little shall I grace my cause
[SHK] In speaking for myself Yet by your gracious patience
[SHK] I will a round unvarnish 'd tale deliver
[SHK] Of my whole course of love what drugs what charms
[SHK] What conjuration and what mighty magic
[SHK] For such proceeding I am charged withal
[SHK] I won his daughter
[SHK] A maiden never bold
[SHK] Of spirit so still and quiet that her motion
[SHK] Blush 'd at herself and she in spite of nature
[SHK] Of years of country credit every thing
[SHK] To fall in love with what she fear 'd to look on
[SHK] It is a judgment maim 'd and most imperfect
[SHK] That will confess perfection so could err
[SHK] Against all rules of nature and must be driven
[SHK] To find out practises of cunning hell
[SHK] Why this should be I therefore vouch again
[SHK] That with some mixtures powerful o'er the blood
[SHK] Or with some dram conjured to this effect
[SHK] He wrought upon her
[SHK] To vouch this is no proof
[SHK] Without more wider and more overt test
[SHK] Than these thin habits and poor likelihoods
[SHK] Of modern seeming do prefer against him
[SHK] But Othello speak
[SHK] Did you by indirect and forced courses
[SHK] Subdue and poison this young maid 's affections
[SHK] Or came it by request and such fair question
[SHK] As soul to soul affordeth
[SHK] I do beseech you

[SHK] If you do find me foul in her report

[SHK] Not only take away but let your sentence
[SHK] Even fall upon my life
[SHK] Fetch Desdemona hither
[SHK] Ancient conduct them you best know the place
[SHK] And till she come as truly as to heaven
[SHK] I do confess the vices of my blood
[SHK] So justly to your grave ears I 'll present
[SHK] How I did thrive in this fair lady 's love
[SHK] And she in mine
[SHK] Say it Othello
[SHK] Her father loved me oft invited me
[SHK] Still question 'd me the story of my life
[SHK] From year to year the battles sieges fortunes
[SHK] That I have passed
[SHK] I ran it through even from my boyish days
[SHK] To the very moment that he bade me tell it
[SHK] Wherein I spake of most disastrous chances
[SHK] Of moving accidents by flood and field
[SHK] Of hair-breadth scapes i the imminent deadly breach
[SHK] Of being taken by the insolent foe
[SHK] And sold to slavery of my redemption thence
[SHK] And portance in my travels history
[SHK] Wherein of antres vast and deserts idle
[SHK] Rough quarries rocks and hills whose heads touch heaven
[SHK] It was my hint to speak -- such was the process
[SHK] And of the Cannibals that each other eat
[SHK] The Anthropophagi and men whose heads
[SHK] Do grow beneath their shoulders This to hear
[SHK] Would Desdemona seriously incline
[SHK] But still the house-affairs would draw her thence
[SHK] Which ever as she could with haste dispatch
[SHK] She'ld come again and with a greedy ear
[SHK] Devour up my discourse which I observing
[SHK] Took once a pliant hour and found good means
[SHK] To draw from her a prayer of earnest heart
[SHK] That I would all my pilgrimage dilate
[SHK] Whereof by parcels she had something heard
[SHK] But not intentively I did consent
[SHK] And often did beguile her of her tears
[SHK] When I did speak of some distressful stroke
[SHK] That my youth suffer 'd My story being done
[SHK] She gave me for my pains a world of sighs
[SHK] She swore in faith twas strange 't was passing strange
[SHK] 'T was pitiful 't was wondrous pitiful
[SHK] She wish 'd she had not heard it yet she wish 'd
[SHK] That heaven had made her such a man she thank 'd me
[SHK] And bade me if I had a friend that loved her
[SHK] I should but teach him how to tell my story
[SHK] And that would woo her Upon this hint I spake
[SHK] She loved me for the dangers I had pass 'd
[SHK] And I loved her that she did pity them
[SHK] This only is the witchcraft I have used
[SHK] Here comes the lady let her witness it
[SHK] I think this tale would win my daughter too

[SHK] Take up this mangled matter at the best

[SHK] Than their bare hands

[SHK] Come hither Moor
[SHK] I here do give thee that with all my heart
[SHK] Which but thou hast already with all my heart
[SHK] I would keep from thee For your sake jewel
[SHK] I am glad at soul I have no other child
[SHK] For thy escape would teach me tyranny
[SHK] To hang clogs on them I have done my lord
[SHK] Let me speak like yourself and lay a sentence
[SHK] Which as a grise or step may help these lovers
[SHK] Into your favour
[SHK] When remedies are past the griefs are ended
[SHK] By seeing the worst which late on hopes depended
[SHK] To mourn a mischief that is past and gone
[SHK] Is the next way to draw new mischief on
[SHK] What can not be preserved when fortune takes
[SHK] Patience her injury a mockery makes
[SHK] The robb 'd that smiles steals something from the thief
[SHK] He robs himself that spends a bootless grief
[SHK] So let the Turk of Cyprus us beguile
[SHK] We lose it not so long as we can smile
[SHK] He bears the sentence well that nothing bears
[SHK] But the free comfort which from thence he hears
[SHK] But he bears both the sentence and the sorrow
[SHK] That to pay grief must of poor patience borrow
[SHK] These sentences to sugar or to gall
[SHK] Being strong on both sides are equivocal
[SHK] But words are words I never yet did hear
[SHK] That the bruised heart was pierced through the ear
[SHK] I humbly beseech you proceed to the affairs of state
[SHK] The Turk with a most mighty preparation makes for
[SHK] Cyprus Othello the fortitude of the place is best
[SHK] known to you and though we have there a substitute
[SHK] of most allowed sufficiency yet opinion a
[SHK] sovereign mistress of effects throws a more safer
[SHK] voice on you you must therefore be content to
[SHK] slubber the gloss of your new fortunes with this
[SHK] more stubborn and boisterous expedition
[SHK] The tyrant custom most grave senators
[SHK] Hath made the flinty and steel couch of war
[SHK] My thrice-driven bed of down I do agnise
[SHK] A natural and prompt alacrity
[SHK] I find in hardness and do undertake
[SHK] These present wars against the Ottomites
[SHK] Most humbly therefore bending to your state
[SHK] I crave fit disposition for my wife
[SHK] Due reference of place and exhibition
[SHK] With such accommodation and besort
[SHK] As levels with her breeding
[SHK] If you please
[SHK] Be't at her father 's
[SHK] I 'll not have it so
[SHK] Nor I
[SHK] Nor I I would not there reside
[SHK] To put my father in impatient thoughts
[SHK] By being in his eye Most gracious duke
[SHK] To my unfolding lend your prosperous ear
[SHK] And let me find a charter in your voice
[SHK] To assist my simpleness
[SHK] What would You Desdemona
[SHK] That I did love the Moor to live with him
[SHK] My downright violence and storm of fortunes
[SHK] May trumpet to the world my heart 's subdued
[SHK] Even to the very quality of my lord
[SHK] I saw Othello 's visage in his mind
[SHK] And to his honour and his valiant parts
[SHK] Did I my soul and fortunes consecrate
[SHK] So that dear lords if I be left behind
[SHK] A moth of peace and he go to the war
[SHK] The rites for which I love him are bereft me
[SHK] And I a heavy interim shall support
[SHK] By his dear absence Let me go with him
[SHK] Let her have your voices
[SHK] Vouch with me heaven I therefore beg it not
[SHK] To please the palate of my appetite
[SHK] Nor to comply with heat -- the young affects
[SHK] In me defunct -- and proper satisfaction
[SHK] But to be free and bounteous to her mind
[SHK] And heaven defend your good souls that you think
[SHK] I will your serious and great business scant
[SHK] For she is with me no when light-wing 'd toys
[SHK] Of feather 'd Cupid seal with wanton dullness
[SHK] My speculative and officed instruments
[SHK] That my disports corrupt and taint my business
[SHK] Let housewives make a skillet of my helm
[SHK] And all indign and base adversities
[SHK] Make head against my estimation
[SHK] Be it as you shall privately determine
[SHK] Either for her stay or going the affair cries haste
[SHK] And speed must answer it
[SHK] You must away to-night
[SHK] With all my heart
[SHK] At nine i the morning here we 'll meet again
[SHK] Othello leave some officer behind
[SHK] And he shall our commission bring to you
[SHK] With such things else of quality and respect
[SHK] As doth import you
[SHK] So please your grace my ancient
[SHK] A man he is of honest and trust
[SHK] To his conveyance I assign my wife
[SHK] With what else needful your good grace shall think
[SHK] To be sent after me
[SHK] Let it be so
[SHK] Good night to every one
[SHK] And noble signior
[SHK] If virtue no delighted beauty lack
[SHK] Your son-in-law is far more fair than black
[SHK] Adieu brave Moor use Desdemona well
[SHK] Look to her Moor if thou hast eyes to see
[SHK] She has deceived her father and may thee
[SHK] My life upon her faith Honest Iago
[SHK] My Desdemona must I leave to thee
[SHK] I prithee let thy wife attend on her
[SHK] And bring them after in the best advantage
[SHK] Come Desdemona I have but an hour
[SHK] Of love of worldly matters and direction
[SHK] To spend with thee we must obey the time
[SHK] Iago --
[SHK] What say'st thou noble heart
[SHK] What will I do thinkest thou
[SHK] Why go to bed and sleep
[SHK] I will incontinently drown myself
[SHK] If thou dost I shall never love thee after Why
[SHK] thou silly gentleman
[SHK] It is silliness to live when to live is torment and
[SHK] then have we a prescription to die when death is our physician
[SHK] O villainous I have looked upon the world for four
[SHK] times seven years and since I could distinguish
[SHK] betwixt a benefit and an injury I never found man
[SHK] that knew how to love himself Ere I would say I
[SHK] would drown myself for the love of a guinea-hen I
[SHK] would change my humanity with a baboon
[SHK] What should I do I confess it is my shame to be so
[SHK] fond but it is not in my virtue to amend it
[SHK] Virtue a fig 't is in ourselves that we are thus
[SHK] or thus Our bodies are our gardens to the which
[SHK] our wills are gardeners so that if we will plant
[SHK] nettles or sow lettuce set hyssop and weed up
[SHK] thyme supply it with one gender of herbs or
[SHK] distract it with many either to have it sterile
[SHK] with idleness or manured with industry why the
[SHK] power and corrigible authority of this lies in our
[SHK] wills If the balance of our lives had not one
[SHK] scale of reason to poise another of sensuality the
[SHK] blood and baseness of our natures would conduct us
[SHK] to most preposterous conclusions but we have
[SHK] reason to cool our raging motions our carnal
[SHK] stings our unbitted lusts whereof I take this that
[SHK] you call love to be a sect or scion
[SHK] It can not be
[SHK] It is merely a lust of the blood and a permission of
[SHK] the will Come be a man Drown thyself drown
[SHK] cats and blind puppies I have professed me thy
[SHK] friend and I confess me knit to thy deserving with
[SHK] cables of perdurable toughness I could never
[SHK] better stead thee than now Put money in thy
[SHK] purse follow thou the wars defeat thy favour with
[SHK] an usurped beard I say put money in thy purse It
[SHK] can not be that Desdemona should long continue her
[SHK] love to the Moor -- put money in thy purse -- nor he
[SHK] his to her it was a violent commencement and thou
[SHK] shalt see an answerable sequestration -- put but
[SHK] money in thy purse These Moors are changeable in
[SHK] their wills fill thy purse with money -- the food
[SHK] that to him now is as luscious as locusts shall be
[SHK] to him shortly as bitter as coloquintida She must
[SHK] change for youth when she is sated with his body
[SHK] she will find the error of her choice she must
[SHK] have change she must therefore put money in thy
[SHK] purse If thou wilt needs damn thyself do it a
[SHK] more delicate way than drowning Make all the money
[SHK] thou canst if sanctimony and a frail vow betwixt
[SHK] an erring barbarian and a supersubtle Venetian not
[SHK] too hard for my wits and all the tribe of hell thou
[SHK] shalt enjoy her therefore make money A pox of
[SHK] drowning thyself it is clean out of the way seek
[SHK] thou rather to be hanged in compassing thy joy than
[SHK] to be drowned and go without her
[SHK] Wilt thou be fast to my hopes if I depend on
[SHK] the issue
[SHK] Thou art sure of me -- go make money -- I have told
[SHK] thee often and I re-tell thee again and again I
[SHK] hate the Moor my cause is hearted thine hath no
[SHK] less reason Let us be conjunctive in our revenge
[SHK] against him if thou canst cuckold him thou dost
[SHK] thyself a pleasure me a sport There are many
[SHK] events in the womb of time which will be delivered
[SHK] Traverse go provide thy money We will have more
[SHK] of this to-morrow Adieu
[SHK] Where shall we meet i the morning
[SHK] At my lodging
[SHK] I 'll be with thee betimes
[SHK] Go to farewell Do you hear Roderigo
[SHK] What say you
[SHK] No more of drowning do you hear
[SHK] I am changed I 'll go sell all my land
[SHK] Thus do I ever make my fool my purse
[SHK] For I mine own gain 'd knowledge should profane
[SHK] If I would time expend with such a snipe
[SHK] But for my sport and profit I hate the Moor
[SHK] And it is thought abroad that 'twixt my sheets
[SHK] He has done my office I know not if't be true
[SHK] But I for mere suspicion in that kind
[SHK] Will do as if for surety He holds me well
[SHK] The better shall my purpose work on him
[SHK] Cassio 's a proper man let me see now
[SHK] To get his place and to plume up my will
[SHK] In double knavery -- How how Let 's see --
[SHK] After some time to abuse Othello 's ear
[SHK] That he is too familiar with his wife
[SHK] He hath a person and a smooth dispose
[SHK] To be suspected framed to make women false
[SHK] The Moor is of a free and open nature
[SHK] That thinks men honest that but seem to be so
[SHK] And will as tenderly be led by the nose
[SHK] As asses are
[SHK] I have't It is engender 'd Hell and night
[SHK] Must bring this monstrous birth to the world 's light
[SHK] What from the cape can you discern at sea
[SHK] Nothing at all it is a highwrought flood
[SHK] I can not 'twixt the heaven and the main
[SHK] Descry a sail
[SHK] Methinks the wind hath spoke aloud at land
[SHK] A fuller blast ne'er shook our battlements
[SHK] If it hath ruffian 'd so upon the sea
[SHK] What ribs of oak when mountains melt on them
[SHK] Can hold the mortise What shall we hear of this
[SHK] A segregation of the Turkish fleet
[SHK] For do but stand upon the foaming shore
[SHK] The chidden billow seems to pelt the clouds
[SHK] The wind-shaked surge with high and monstrous mane
[SHK] seems to cast water on the burning bear
[SHK] And quench the guards of the ever-fixed pole
[SHK] I never did like molestation view
[SHK] On the enchafed flood
[SHK] If that the Turkish fleet
[SHK] Be not enshelter 'd and embay 'd they are drown 'd
[SHK] It is impossible they bear it out
[SHK] News lads our wars are done
[SHK] The desperate tempest hath so bang 'd the Turks
[SHK] That their designment halts a noble ship of Venice
[SHK] Hath seen a grievous wreck and sufferance
[SHK] On most part of their fleet
[SHK] How is this true
[SHK] The ship is here put in
[SHK] A Veronesa Michael Cassio
[SHK] Lieutenant to the warlike Moor Othello
[SHK] Is come on shore the Moor himself at sea
[SHK] And is in full commission here for Cyprus
[SHK] I am glad o n't 't is a worthy governor
[SHK] But this same Cassio though he speak of comfort
[SHK] Touching the Turkish loss yet he looks sadly
[SHK] And prays the Moor be safe for they were parted
[SHK] With foul and violent tempest
[SHK] Pray heavens he be
[SHK] For I have served him and the man commands
[SHK] Like a full soldier Let 's to the seaside ho
[SHK] As well to see the vessel that 's come in
[SHK] As to throw out our eyes for brave Othello
[SHK] Even till we make the main and the aerial blue
[SHK] An indistinct regard
[SHK] Come let 's do so
[SHK] For every minute is expectancy
[SHK] Of more arrivance
[SHK] Thanks you the valiant of this warlike isle
[SHK] That so approve the Moor O let the heavens
[SHK] Give him defence against the elements
[SHK] For I have lost us him on a dangerous sea
[SHK] Is he well shipp 'd
[SHK] His bark is stoutly timber 'd his pilot
[SHK] Of very expert and approved allowance
[SHK] Therefore my hopes not surfeited to death
[SHK] Stand in bold cure
[SHK] What noise
[SHK] The town is empty on the brow o the sea
[SHK] Stand ranks of people and they cry A sail
[SHK] My hopes do shape him for the governor
[SHK] They do discharge their shot of courtesy
[SHK] Our friends at least
[SHK] I pray you sir go forth
[SHK] And give us truth who 't is that is arrived
[SHK] I shall
[SHK] But good lieutenant is your general wived
[SHK] Most fortunately he hath achieved a maid
[SHK] That paragons description and wild fame
[SHK] One that excels the quirks of blazoning pens
[SHK] And in the essential vesture of creation
[SHK] Does tire the ingener
[SHK] How now who has put in
[SHK] 'T is one Iago ancient to the general
[SHK] Has had most favourable and happy speed
[SHK] Tempests themselves high seas and howling winds
[SHK] The gutter 'd rocks and congregated sands --
[SHK] Traitors ensteep 'd to clog the guiltless keel --
[SHK] As having sense of beauty do omit
[SHK] Their mortal natures letting go safely by
[SHK] The divine Desdemona
[SHK] What is she
[SHK] She that I spake of our great captain 's captain
[SHK] Left in the conduct of the bold Iago
[SHK] Whose footing here anticipates our thoughts
[SHK] A se'nnight 's speed Great Jove Othello guard
[SHK] And swell his sail with thine own powerful breath
[SHK] That he may bless this bay with his tall ship
[SHK] Make love 's quick pants in Desdemona 's arms
[SHK] Give renew 'd fire to our extincted spirits
[SHK] And bring all Cyprus comfort
[SHK] O behold
[SHK] The riches of the ship is come on shore
[SHK] Ye men of Cyprus let her have your knees
[SHK] Hail to thee lady and the grace of heaven
[SHK] Before behind thee and on every hand
[SHK] Enwheel thee round
[SHK] I thank you valiant Cassio
[SHK] What tidings can you tell me of my lord
[SHK] He is not yet arrived nor know I aught
[SHK] But that he 's well and will be shortly here
[SHK] O but I fear -- How lost you company
[SHK] The great contention of the sea and skies
[SHK] Parted our fellowship -- But hark a sail
[SHK] They give their greeting to the citadel
[SHK] This likewise is a friend
[SHK] See for the news
[SHK] Good ancient you are welcome
[SHK] Welcome mistress
[SHK] Let it not gall your patience good Iago
[SHK] That I extend my manners 't is my breeding
[SHK] That gives me this bold show of courtesy
[SHK] Sir would she give you so much of her lips
[SHK] As of her tongue she oft bestows on me
[SHK] You 'll have enough
[SHK] Alas she has no speech
[SHK] In faith too much
[SHK] I find it still when I have list to sleep
[SHK] Marry before your ladyship I grant
[SHK] She puts her tongue a little in her heart
[SHK] And chides with thinking
[SHK] You have little cause to say so
[SHK] Come on come on you are pictures out of doors
[SHK] Bells in your parlors wild-cats in your kitchens
[SHK] Saints m your injuries devils being offended
[SHK] Players in your housewifery and housewives in your beds
[SHK] O fie upon thee slanderer
[SHK] Nay it is true or else I am a Turk
[SHK] You rise to play and go to bed to work
[SHK] You shall not write my praise
[SHK] No let me not
[SHK] What wouldst thou write of me if thou shouldst
[SHK] praise me
[SHK] O gentle lady do not put me to't
[SHK] For I am nothing if not critical
[SHK] Come on assay There 's one gone to the harbour
[SHK] Ay madam
[SHK] I am not merry but I do beguile
[SHK] The thing I am by seeming otherwise
[SHK] Come how wouldst thou praise me
[SHK] I am about it but indeed my invention
[SHK] Comes from my pate as birdlime does from frize
[SHK] It plucks out brains and all but my Muse labours
[SHK] And thus she is deliver 'd
[SHK] If she be fair and wise fairness and wit
[SHK] The one 's for use the other useth it
[SHK] Well praised How if she be black and witty
[SHK] If she be black and thereto have a wit
[SHK] She 'll find a white that shall her blackness fit
[SHK] Worse and worse
[SHK] How if fair and foolish
[SHK] She never yet was foolish that was fair
[SHK] For even her folly help 'd her to an heir
[SHK] These are old fond paradoxes to make fools laugh i
[SHK] the alehouse What miserable praise hast thou for
[SHK] her that 's foul and foolish
[SHK] There 's none so foul and foolish thereunto
[SHK] But does foul pranks which fair and wise ones do
[SHK] O heavy ignorance thou praisest the worst best
[SHK] But what praise couldst thou bestow on a deserving
[SHK] woman indeed one that in the authority of her
[SHK] merit did justly put on the vouch of very malice itself
[SHK] She that was ever fair and never proud
[SHK] Had tongue at will and yet was never loud
[SHK] Never lack 'd gold and yet went never gay
[SHK] Fled from her wish and yet said 'Now I may
[SHK] She that being anger 'd her revenge being nigh
[SHK] Bade her wrong stay and her displeasure fly
[SHK] She that in wisdom never was so frail
[SHK] To change the cod 's head for the salmon 's tail
[SHK] She that could think and ne'er disclose her mind
[SHK] See suitors following and not look behind
[SHK] She was a wight if ever such wight were --
[SHK] To do what
[SHK] To suckle fools and chronicle small beer
[SHK] O most lame and impotent conclusion Do not learn
[SHK] of him Emilia though he be thy husband How say
[SHK] you Cassio is he not a most profane and liberal
[SHK] counsellor
[SHK] He speaks home madam You may relish him more in
[SHK] the soldier than in the scholar
[SHK] whisper with as little a web as this will I
[SHK] ensnare as great a fly as Cassio Ay smile upon
[SHK] her do I will gyve thee in thine own courtship
