[SHK] these strip you out of your lieutenantry it had
[SHK] been better you had not kissed your three fingers so
[SHK] oft which now again you are most apt to play the
[SHK] sir in Very good well kissed an excellent
[SHK] courtesy 't is so indeed Yet again your fingers
[SHK] to your lips would they were clyster-pipes for your sake
[SHK] The Moor I know his trumpet
[SHK] 'T is truly so
[SHK] Let 's meet him and receive him
[SHK] Lo where he comes
[SHK] O my fair warrior
[SHK] My dear Othello
[SHK] It gives me wonder great as my content
[SHK] To see you here before me O my soul 's joy
[SHK] If after every tempest come such calms
[SHK] May the winds blow till they have waken 'd death
[SHK] And let the labouring bark climb hills of seas
[SHK] Olympus-high and duck again as low
[SHK] As hell 's from heaven If it were now to die
[SHK] 'Twere now to be most happy for I fear
[SHK] My soul hath her content so absolute
[SHK] That not another comfort like to this
[SHK] Succeeds in unknown fate
[SHK] The heavens forbid
[SHK] But that our loves and comforts should increase
[SHK] Even as our days do grow
[SHK] Amen to that sweet powers
[SHK] I can not speak enough of this content
[SHK] It stops me here it is too much of joy
[SHK] And this and this the greatest discords be
[SHK] That e'er our hearts shall make
[SHK] But I 'll set down the pegs that make this music
[SHK] As honest as I am
[SHK] Come let us to the castle
[SHK] News friends our wars are done the Turks
[SHK] are drown 'd
[SHK] How does my old acquaintance of this isle
[SHK] Honey you shall be well desired in Cyprus
[SHK] I have found great love amongst them O my sweet
[SHK] I prattle out of fashion and I dote

[SHK] Go to the bay and disembark my coffers
[SHK] Bring thou the master to the citadel
[SHK] He is a good one and his worthiness
[SHK] Does challenge much respect Come Desdemona
[SHK] Once more well met at Cyprus

[SHK] hither If thou be'st valiant -- as they say base
[SHK] men being in love have then a nobility in their
[SHK] natures more than is native to them -- list me The
[SHK] lieutenant tonight watches on the court of
[SHK] guard -- first I must tell thee this -- Desdemona is
[SHK] directly in love with him
[SHK] With him why 't is not possible
[SHK] Lay thy finger thus and let thy soul be instructed
[SHK] Mark me with what violence she first loved the Moor
[SHK] but for bragging and telling her fantastical lies
[SHK] and will she love him still for prating let not
[SHK] thy discreet heart think it Her eye must be fed
[SHK] and what delight shall she have to look on the
[SHK] devil When the blood is made dull with the act of
[SHK] sport there should be again to inflame it and to
[SHK] give satiety a fresh appetite loveliness in favour
[SHK] sympathy in years manners and beauties all which
[SHK] the Moor is defective in now for want of these
[SHK] required conveniences her delicate tenderness will
[SHK] find itself abused begin to heave the gorge
[SHK] disrelish and abhor the Moor very nature will
[SHK] instruct her in it and compel her to some second
[SHK] choice Now sir this granted -- as it is a most
[SHK] pregnant and unforced position -- who stands so
[SHK] eminent in the degree of this fortune as Cassio
[SHK] does a knave very voluble no further
[SHK] conscionable than in putting on the mere form of
[SHK] civil and humane seeming for the better compassing
[SHK] of his salt and most hidden loose affection why
[SHK] none why none a slipper and subtle knave a
[SHK] finder of occasions that has an eye can stamp and
[SHK] counterfeit advantages though true advantage never
[SHK] present itself a devilish knave Besides the
[SHK] knave is handsome young and hath all those
[SHK] requisites in him that folly and green minds look
[SHK] after a pestilent complete knave and the woman
[SHK] hath found him already
[SHK] I can not believe that in her she 's full of
[SHK] most blessed condition
[SHK] Blessed fig's-end the wine she drinks is made of
[SHK] grapes if she had been blessed she would never
[SHK] have loved the Moor Blessed pudding Didst thou
[SHK] not see her paddle with the palm of his hand didst
[SHK] not mark that

[SHK] Lechery by this hand an index and obscure prologue
[SHK] to the history of lust and foul thoughts They met
[SHK] so near with their lips that their breaths embraced
[SHK] together Villanous thoughts Roderigo when these
[SHK] mutualities so marshal the way hard at hand comes
[SHK] the master and main exercise the incorporate

[SHK] favourably minister
[SHK] Well

[SHK] mutiny whose qualification shall come into no true
[SHK] taste again but by the displanting of Cassio So
[SHK] shall you have a shorter journey to your desires by
[SHK] the means I shall then have to prefer them and the
[SHK] impediment most profitably removed without the

[SHK] opportunity

[SHK] Adieu
[SHK] That Cassio loves her I do well believe it

[SHK] Is of a constant loving noble nature
[SHK] And I dare think he 'll prove to Desdemona
[SHK] A most dear husband Now I do love her too
[SHK] Not out of absolute lust though peradventure
[SHK] I stand accountant for as great a sin
[SHK] But partly led to diet my revenge
[SHK] For that I do suspect the lusty Moor
[SHK] Hath leap 'd into my seat the thought whereof
[SHK] Doth like a poisonous mineral gnaw my inwards
[SHK] And nothing can or shall content my soul
[SHK] Till I am even 'd with him wife for wife
[SHK] Or failing so yet that I put the Moor
[SHK] At least into a jealousy so strong
[SHK] That judgment can not cure Which thing to do
[SHK] If this poor trash of Venice whom I trash
[SHK] For his quick hunting stand the putting on
[SHK] I 'll have our Michael Cassio on the hip

[SHK] For I fear Cassio with my night-cap too --

[SHK] For making him egregiously an ass
[SHK] And practising upon his peace and quiet

[SHK] general that upon certain tidings now arrived
[SHK] importing the mere perdition of the Turkish fleet
[SHK] every man put himself into triumph some to dance
[SHK] some to make bonfires each man to what sport and
[SHK] revels his addiction leads him for besides these
[SHK] beneficial news it is the celebration of his
[SHK] nuptial So much was his pleasure should be
[SHK] proclaimed All offices are open and there is full
[SHK] liberty of feasting from this present hour of five
[SHK] till the bell have told eleven Heaven bless the
[SHK] isle of Cyprus and our noble general Othello

[SHK] Iago hath direction what to do

[SHK] Will I look to't
[SHK] Iago is most honest
[SHK] Michael good night to-morrow with your earliest

[SHK] clock Our general cast us thus early for the love
[SHK] of his Desdemona who let us not therefore blame

[SHK] she is sport for Jove
[SHK] She 's a most exquisite lady

[SHK] provocation
[SHK] An inviting eye and yet methinks right modest
[SHK] And when she speaks is it not an alarum to love
[SHK] She is indeed perfection
[SHK] Well happiness to their sheets Come lieutenant I
[SHK] have a stoup of wine and here without are a brace
[SHK] of Cyprus gallants that would fain have a measure to
[SHK] the health of black Othello
[SHK] Not to-night good Iago I have very poor and
[SHK] unhappy brains for drinking I could well wish
[SHK] courtesy would invent some other custom of
[SHK] entertainment
[SHK] O they are our friends but one cup I 'll drink for
[SHK] you
[SHK] I have drunk but one cup to-night and that was
[SHK] craftily qualified too and behold what innovation
[SHK] it makes here I am unfortunate in the infirmity
[SHK] and dare not task my weakness with any more
[SHK] What man 't is a night of revels the gallants
[SHK] desire it
[SHK] Where are they
[SHK] Here at the door I pray you call them in
[SHK] I 'll do't but it dislikes me
[SHK] If I can fasten but one cup upon him
[SHK] With that which he hath drunk to-night already
[SHK] He 'll be as full of quarrel and offence
[SHK] As my young mistress dog Now my sick fool Roderigo
[SHK] Whom love hath turn 'd almost the wrong side out
[SHK] To Desdemona hath to-night caroused
[SHK] Potations pottle-deep and he 's to watch
[SHK] Three lads of Cyprus noble swelling spirits
[SHK] That hold their honours in a wary distance
[SHK] The very elements of this warlike isle
[SHK] Have I to-night fluster 'd with flowing cups
[SHK] And they watch too Now 'mongst this flock of drunkards
[SHK] Am I to put our Cassio in some action
[SHK] That may offend the isle. -- But here they come
[SHK] If consequence do but approve my dream
[SHK] My boat sails freely both with wind and stream
[SHK] 'Fore God they have given me a rouse already
[SHK] Good faith a little one not past a pint as I am
[SHK] a soldier

[SHK] to your English

[SHK] They are close delations working from the heart
[SHK] That passion can not rule
[SHK] For Michael Cassio
[SHK] I dare be sworn I think that he is honest
[SHK] I think so too
[SHK] Men should be what they seem

[SHK] I prithee speak to me as to thy thinkings
[SHK] As thou dost ruminate and give thy worst of thoughts

[SHK] Good my lord pardon me
[SHK] Though I am bound to every act of duty
[SHK] I am not bound to that all slaves are free to
[SHK] Utter my thoughts Why say they are vile and false
[SHK] As where 's that palace whereinto foul things
[SHK] Sometimes intrude not who has a breast so pure
[SHK] But some uncleanly apprehensions
[SHK] Keep leets and law-days and in session sit
[SHK] With meditations lawful
[SHK] Thou dost conspire against thy friend Iago
[SHK] If thou but think'st him wrong 'd and makest his ear
[SHK] A stranger to thy thoughts
[SHK] I do beseech you --
[SHK] Though I perchance am vicious in my guess
[SHK] As I confess it is my nature 's plague
[SHK] To spy into abuses and oft my jealousy
[SHK] Shapes faults that are not -- that your wisdom yet
[SHK] From one that so imperfectly conceits
[SHK] Would take no notice nor build yourself a trouble
[SHK] Out of his scattering and unsure observance
[SHK] It were not for your quiet nor your good
[SHK] Nor for my manhood honesty or wisdom
[SHK] To let you know my thoughts
[SHK] What dost thou mean
[SHK] Good name in man and woman dear my lord
[SHK] Is the immediate jewel of their souls
[SHK] Who steals my purse steals trash 't is something nothing
[SHK] 'T was mine 't is his and has been slave to thousands
[SHK] But he that filches from me my good name
[SHK] Robs me of that which not enriches him
[SHK] And makes me poor indeed
[SHK] By heaven I 'll know thy thoughts
[SHK] You can not if my heart were in your hand
[SHK] Nor shall not whilst 't is in my custody
[SHK] Ha
[SHK] O beware my lord of jealousy
[SHK] It is the green-eyed monster which doth mock
[SHK] The meat it feeds on that cuckold lives in bliss
[SHK] Who certain of his fate loves not his wronger
[SHK] But O what damned minutes tells he o'er
[SHK] Who dotes yet doubts suspects yet strongly loves
[SHK] O misery
[SHK] Poor and content is rich and rich enough
[SHK] But riches fineless is as poor as winter
[SHK] To him that ever fears he shall be poor
[SHK] Good heaven the souls of all my tribe defend
[SHK] From jealousy
[SHK] Why why is this
[SHK] Think'st thou I'ld make a lie of jealousy
[SHK] To follow still the changes of the moon
[SHK] With fresh suspicions No to be once in doubt
[SHK] Is once to be resolved exchange me for a goat
[SHK] When I shall turn the business of my soul
[SHK] To such exsufflicate and blown surmises
[SHK] Matching thy inference 'T is not to make me jealous
[SHK] To say my wife is fair feeds well loves company
[SHK] Is free of speech sings plays and dances well
[SHK] Where virtue is these are more virtuous
[SHK] Nor from mine own weak merits will I draw
[SHK] The smallest fear or doubt of her revolt
[SHK] For she had eyes and chose me No Iago
[SHK] I 'll see before I doubt when I doubt prove
[SHK] And on the proof there is no more but this --
[SHK] Away at once with love or jealousy
[SHK] I am glad of it for now I shall have reason
[SHK] To show the love and duty that I bear you
[SHK] With franker spirit therefore as I am bound
[SHK] Receive it from me I speak not yet of proof
[SHK] Look to your wife observe her well with Cassio
[SHK] Wear your eye thus not jealous nor secure
[SHK] I would not have your free and noble nature
[SHK] Out of self-bounty be abused look to't
[SHK] I know our country disposition well
[SHK] In Venice they do let heaven see the pranks
[SHK] They dare not show their husbands their best conscience
[SHK] Is not to leave't undone but keep't unknown
[SHK] Dost thou say so
[SHK] She did deceive her father marrying you
[SHK] And when she seem 'd to shake and fear your looks
[SHK] She loved them most
[SHK] And so she did
[SHK] Why go to then

[SHK] To seal her father 's eyes up close as oak-
[SHK] He thought 't was witchcraft -- but I am much to blame
[SHK] I humbly do beseech you of your pardon
[SHK] For too much loving you
[SHK] I am bound to thee for ever
[SHK] I see this hath a little dash 'd your spirits
[SHK] Not a jot not a jot
[SHK] I faith I fear it has

[SHK] To grosser issues nor to larger reach
[SHK] Than to suspicion
[SHK] I will not
[SHK] Should you do so my lord

[SHK] My lord I see you 're moved
[SHK] No not much moved
[SHK] I do not think but Desdemona 's honest
[SHK] Long live she so and long live you to think so

[SHK] Ay there 's the point as -- to be bold with you --
[SHK] Not to affect many proposed matches

[SHK] Foh one may smell in such a will most rank

[SHK] This fellow 's of exceeding honesty
[SHK] And knows all qualities with a learned spirit
[SHK] Of human dealings If I do prove her haggard

[SHK] And have not those soft parts of conversation
[SHK] That chamberers have or for I am declined

[SHK] That we can call these delicate creatures ours
[SHK] And not their appetites I had rather be a toad
[SHK] And live upon the vapour of a dungeon

[SHK] Prerogatived are they less than the base

[SHK] Moor she was chaste she loved thee cruel Moor
[SHK] So come my soul to bliss as I speak true
[SHK] So speaking as I think I die I die
[SHK] I have another weapon in this chamber
[SHK] It is a sword of Spain the ice-brook 's temper --
[SHK] O here it is Uncle I must come forth
[SHK] Thou hast no weapon and perforce must suffer
[SHK] Look in upon me then and speak with me
[SHK] Or naked as I am I will assault thee
[SHK] What is the matter
[SHK] Behold I have a weapon
[SHK] A better never did itself sustain
[SHK] Upon a soldier 's thigh I have seen the day
[SHK] That with this little arm and this good sword
[SHK] I have made my way through more impediments
[SHK] Than twenty times your stop but O vain boast
[SHK] Who can control his fate 't is not so now
[SHK] Be not afraid though you do see me weapon 'd
[SHK] Here is my journey 's end here is my butt
[SHK] And very sea-mark of my utmost sail
[SHK] Do you go back dismay 'd 't is a lost fear
[SHK] Man but a rush against Othello 's breast
[SHK] And he retires Where should Othello go
[SHK] Now how dost thou look now O ill-starr 'd wench
[SHK] Pale as thy smock when we shall meet at compt
[SHK] This look of thine will hurl my soul from heaven
[SHK] And fiends will snatch at it Cold cold my girl
[SHK] Even like thy chastity O cursed slave
[SHK] Whip me ye devils
[SHK] From the possession of this heavenly sight
[SHK] Blow me about in winds roast me in sulphur
[SHK] Wash me in steep-down gulfs of liquid fire
[SHK] O Desdemona Desdemona dead
[SHK] Oh Oh Oh
[SHK] Where is this rash and most unfortunate man
[SHK] That 's he that was Othello here I am
[SHK] Where is that viper bring the villain forth
[SHK] I look down towards his feet but that 's a fable
[SHK] If that thou best a devil I can not kill thee
[SHK] Wrench his sword from him
[SHK] I bleed sir but not kill 'd
[SHK] I am not sorry neither I'ld have thee live
[SHK] For in my sense 't is happiness to die
[SHK] O thou Othello thou wert once so good
[SHK] Fall'n in the practise of a damned slave
[SHK] What shall be said to thee
[SHK] Why any thing
[SHK] An honourable murderer if you will
[SHK] For nought I did in hate but all in honour
[SHK] This wretch hath part confess 'd his villany
[SHK] Did you and he consent in Cassio 's death
[SHK] Ay
[SHK] Dear general I never gave you cause
[SHK] I do believe it and I ask your pardon
[SHK] Will you I pray demand that demi-devil
[SHK] Why he hath thus ensnared my soul and body
[SHK] Demand me nothing what you know you know
[SHK] From this time forth I never will speak word
[SHK] What not to pray
[SHK] Torments will ope your lips
[SHK] Well thou dost best
[SHK] Sir you shall understand what hath befall'n
[SHK] Which as I think you know not Here is a letter
[SHK] Found in the pocket of the slain Roderigo
[SHK] And here another the one of them imports
[SHK] The death of Cassio to be undertook
[SHK] By Roderigo
[SHK] O villain
[SHK] Most heathenish and most gross
[SHK] Now here 's another discontented paper
[SHK] Found in his pocket too and this it seems
[SHK] Roderigo meant to have sent this damned villain
[SHK] But that belike Iago in the interim
[SHK] Came in and satisfied him
[SHK] O the pernicious caitiff
[SHK] How came you Cassio by that handkerchief
[SHK] That was my wife 's
[SHK] I found it in my chamber
[SHK] And he himself confess 'd but even now
[SHK] That there he dropp 'd it for a special purpose
[SHK] Which wrought to his desire
[SHK] O fool fool fool
[SHK] There is besides in Roderigo 's letter
[SHK] How he upbraids Iago that he made him
[SHK] Brave me upon the watch whereon it came
[SHK] That I was cast and even but now he spake
[SHK] After long seeming dead Iago hurt him
[SHK] Iago set him on
[SHK] You must forsake this room and go with us
[SHK] Your power and your command is taken off
[SHK] And Cassio rules in Cyprus For this slave
[SHK] If there be any cunning cruelty
[SHK] That can torment him much and hold him long
[SHK] It shall be his You shall close prisoner rest
[SHK] Till that the nature of your fault be known
[SHK] To the Venetian state Come bring him away
[SHK] Soft you a word or two before you go
[SHK] I have done the state some service and they know't
[SHK] No more of that I pray you in your letters
[SHK] When you shall these unlucky deeds relate
[SHK] Speak of me as I am nothing extenuate
[SHK] Nor set down aught in malice then must you speak
[SHK] Of one that loved not wisely but too well
[SHK] Of one not easily jealous but being wrought
[SHK] Perplex 'd in the extreme of one whose hand
[SHK] Like the base Indian threw a pearl away
[SHK] Richer than all his tribe of one whose subdued eyes
[SHK] Albeit unused to the melting mood
[SHK] Drop tears as fast as the Arabian trees
[SHK] Their medicinal gum Set you down this
[SHK] And say besides that in Aleppo once
[SHK] Where a malignant and a turban 'd Turk
[SHK] Beat a Venetian and traduced the state
[SHK] I took by the throat the circumcised dog
[SHK] And smote him thus
[SHK] O bloody period
[SHK] All that 's spoke is marr 'd
[SHK] I kiss 'd thee ere I kill 'd thee no way but this
[SHK] Killing myself to die upon a kiss
[SHK] This did I fear but thought he had no weapon
[SHK] For he was great of heart
[SHK] More fell than anguish hunger or the sea
[SHK] Look on the tragic loading of this bed
[SHK] This is thy work the object poisons sight
[SHK] Let it be hid Gratiano keep the house
[SHK] And seize upon the fortunes of the Moor
[SHK] For they succeed on you To you lord governor
[SHK] Remains the censure of this hellish villain
[SHK] The time the place the torture O enforce it
[SHK] Myself will straight aboard and to the state
[SHK] This heavy act with heavy heart relate
[SHK] Two households both alike in dignity
[SHK] In fair Verona where we lay our scene
[SHK] From ancient grudge break to new mutiny
[SHK] Where civil blood makes civil hands unclean
[SHK] From forth the fatal loins of these two foes
[SHK] A pair of star-cross 'd lovers take their life
[SHK] Whole misadventured piteous overthrows
[SHK] Do with their death bury their parents strife
[SHK] The fearful passage of their death-mark 'd love
[SHK] And the continuance of their parents rage
[SHK] Which but their children 's end nought could remove
[SHK] Is now the two hours traffic of our stage
[SHK] The which if you with patient ears attend
[SHK] What here shall miss our toil shall strive to mend
[SHK] Gregory o my word we 'll not carry coals
[SHK] No for then we should be colliers
[SHK] I mean an we be in choler we 'll draw
[SHK] Ay while you live draw your neck out o the collar
[SHK] I strike quickly being moved
[SHK] But thou art not quickly moved to strike
[SHK] A dog of the house of Montague moves me
[SHK] To move is to stir and to be valiant is to stand
[SHK] therefore if thou art moved thou runn'st away
[SHK] A dog of that house shall move me to stand I will
[SHK] take the wall of any man or maid of Montague 's
[SHK] That shows thee a weak slave for the weakest goes
[SHK] to the wall
[SHK] True and therefore women being the weaker vessels
[SHK] are ever thrust to the wall therefore I will push
[SHK] Montague 's men from the wall and thrust his maids
[SHK] to the wall
[SHK] The quarrel is between our masters and us their men
[SHK] 'T is all one I will show myself a tyrant when I
[SHK] have fought with the men I will be cruel with the
[SHK] maids and cut off their heads
[SHK] The heads of the maids
[SHK] Ay the heads of the maids or their maidenheads
[SHK] take it in what sense thou wilt
[SHK] They must take it in sense that feel it
[SHK] Me they shall feel while I am able to stand and
[SHK] 't is known I am a pretty piece of flesh
[SHK] 'T is well thou art not fish if thou hadst thou
[SHK] hadst been poor John Draw thy tool here comes
[SHK] two of the house of the Montagues
[SHK] My naked weapon is out quarrel I will back thee
[SHK] How turn thy back and run
[SHK] Fear me not
[SHK] No marry I fear thee
[SHK] Let us take the law of our sides let them begin
[SHK] I will frown as I pass by and let them take it as
[SHK] they list
[SHK] Nay as they dare I will bite my thumb at them
[SHK] which is a disgrace to them if they bear it
[SHK] Do you bite your thumb at us sir
[SHK] I do bite my thumb sir
[SHK] Do you bite your thumb at us sir
[SHK] ay
[SHK] No
[SHK] No sir I do not bite my thumb at you sir but I
[SHK] bite my thumb sir
[SHK] Do you quarrel sir
[SHK] Quarrel sir no sir
[SHK] If you do sir I am for you I serve as good a man as you
[SHK] No better
[SHK] Well sir
[SHK] Say 'better here comes one of my master 's kinsmen
[SHK] Yes better sir
[SHK] You lie
[SHK] Draw if you be men Gregory remember thy swashing blow
[SHK] Part fools
[SHK] Put up your swords you know not what you do
[SHK] What art thou drawn among these heartless hinds
[SHK] Turn thee Benvolio look upon thy death
[SHK] I do but keep the peace put up thy sword
[SHK] Or manage it to part these men with me
[SHK] What drawn and talk of peace I hate the word
[SHK] As I hate hell all Montagues and thee
[SHK] Have at thee coward
[SHK] Clubs bills and partisans strike beat them down
[SHK] Down with the Capulets down with the Montagues
[SHK] What noise is this Give me my long sword ho
[SHK] A crutch a crutch why call you for a sword
[SHK] My sword I say Old Montague is come
[SHK] And flourishes his blade in spite of me
[SHK] Thou villain Capulet -- Hold me not let me go
[SHK] Thou shalt not stir a foot to seek a foe
[SHK] Rebellious subjects enemies to peace
[SHK] Profaners of this neighbour-stained steel --
[SHK] Will they not hear What ho you men you beasts
[SHK] That quench the fire of your pernicious rage
[SHK] With purple fountains issuing from your veins
[SHK] On pain of torture from those bloody hands
[SHK] Throw your mistemper 'd weapons to the ground
[SHK] And hear the sentence of your moved prince
[SHK] Three civil brawls bred of an airy word
[SHK] By thee old Capulet and Montague
[SHK] Have thrice disturb 'd the quiet of our streets
[SHK] And made Verona 's ancient citizens
[SHK] Cast by their grave beseeming ornaments
[SHK] To wield old partisans in hands as old
[SHK] Canker 'd with peace to part your canker 'd hate
[SHK] If ever you disturb our streets again
[SHK] Your lives shall pay the forfeit of the peace
[SHK] For this time all the rest depart away
[SHK] You Capulet shall go along with me
[SHK] And Montague come you this afternoon
[SHK] To know our further pleasure in this case
[SHK] To old Free-town our common judgment-place
[SHK] Once more on pain of death all men depart
[SHK] Who set this ancient quarrel new abroach
[SHK] Speak nephew were you by when it began
[SHK] Here were the servants of your adversary
[SHK] And yours close fighting ere I did approach
[SHK] I drew to part them in the instant came
[SHK] The fiery Tybalt with his sword prepared
[SHK] Which as he breathed defiance to my ears
[SHK] He swung about his head and cut the winds
[SHK] Who nothing hurt withal hiss 'd him in scorn
[SHK] While we were interchanging thrusts and blows
[SHK] Came more and more and fought on part and part
[SHK] Till the prince came who parted either part
[SHK] O where is Romeo saw you him to-day
[SHK] Right glad I am he was not at this fray
[SHK] Madam an hour before the worshipp 'd sun
[SHK] Peer 'd forth the golden window of the east
[SHK] A troubled mind drave me to walk abroad
[SHK] Where underneath the grove of sycamore
[SHK] That westward rooteth from the city 's side
[SHK] So early walking did I see your son
[SHK] Towards him I made but he was ware of me
[SHK] And stole into the covert of the wood
[SHK] I measuring his affections by my own
[SHK] That most are busied when they 're most alone
[SHK] Pursued my humour not pursuing his
[SHK] And gladly shunn 'd who gladly fled from me
[SHK] Many a morning hath he there been seen
[SHK] With tears augmenting the fresh morning dew
[SHK] Adding to clouds more clouds with his deep sighs
[SHK] But all so soon as the all-cheering sun
[SHK] Should in the furthest east begin to draw
[SHK] The shady curtains from Aurora 's bed
[SHK] Away from the light steals home my heavy son
[SHK] And private in his chamber pens himself
[SHK] Shuts up his windows locks far daylight out
[SHK] And makes himself an artificial night
[SHK] Black and portentous must this humour prove
[SHK] Unless good counsel may the cause remove
[SHK] My noble uncle do you know the cause
[SHK] I neither know it nor can learn of him
[SHK] Have you importuned him by any means
[SHK] Both by myself and many other friends
[SHK] But he his own affections counsellor
[SHK] Is to himself -- I will not say how true --
[SHK] But to himself so secret and so close
[SHK] So far from sounding and discovery
[SHK] As is the bud bit with an envious worm
[SHK] Ere he can spread his sweet leaves to the air
[SHK] Or dedicate his beauty to the sun
[SHK] Could we but learn from whence his sorrows grow
[SHK] We would as willingly give cure as know
[SHK] See where he comes so please you step aside
[SHK] I 'll know his grievance or be much denied
[SHK] I would thou wert so happy by thy stay
[SHK] To hear true shrift Come madam let 's away
[SHK] Good-morrow cousin
[SHK] Is the day so young
[SHK] But new struck nine
[SHK] Ay me sad hours seem long
[SHK] Was that my father that went hence so fast
[SHK] It was What sadness lengthens Romeo 's hours
[SHK] Not having that which having makes them short
[SHK] In love
[SHK] Out --
[SHK] Of love
[SHK] Out of her favour where I am in love
[SHK] Alas that love so gentle in his view
[SHK] Should be so tyrannous and rough in proof
[SHK] Alas that love whose view is muffled still
[SHK] Should without eyes see pathways to his will
[SHK] Where shall we dine O me What fray was here
[SHK] Yet tell me not for I have heard it all
[SHK] Here 's much to do with hate but more with love
[SHK] Why then O brawling love O loving hate
[SHK] O any thing of nothing first create
[SHK] O heavy lightness serious vanity
[SHK] Mis-shapen chaos of well-seeming forms
[SHK] Feather of lead bright smoke cold fire
[SHK] sick health
[SHK] Still-waking sleep that is not what it is
[SHK] This love feel I that feel no love in this
[SHK] Dost thou not laugh
[SHK] No coz I rather weep
[SHK] Good heart at what
[SHK] At thy good heart 's oppression
[SHK] Why such is love 's transgression
[SHK] Griefs of mine own lie heavy in my breast
[SHK] Which thou wilt propagate to have it prest
[SHK] With more of thine this love that thou hast shown
[SHK] Doth add more grief to too much of mine own
[SHK] Love is a smoke raised with the fume of sighs
[SHK] Being purged a fire sparkling in lovers eyes
[SHK] Being vex 'd a sea nourish 'd with lovers tears
[SHK] What is it else a madness most discreet
[SHK] A choking gall and a preserving sweet
[SHK] Farewell my coz
[SHK] Soft I will go along
[SHK] An if you leave me so you do me wrong
[SHK] Tut I have lost myself I am not here
[SHK] This is not Romeo he 's some other where
[SHK] Tell me in sadness who is that you love
[SHK] What shall I groan and tell thee
[SHK] Groan why no
[SHK] But sadly tell me who
[SHK] Bid a sick man in sadness make his will
[SHK] Ah word ill urged to one that is so ill
[SHK] In sadness cousin I do love a woman
[SHK] I aim 'd so near when I supposed you loved
[SHK] A right good mark-man And she 's fair I love
[SHK] A right fair mark fair coz is soonest hit
[SHK] Well in that hit you miss she 'll not be hit
[SHK] With Cupid 's arrow she hath Dian 's wit
[SHK] And in strong proof of chastity well arm 'd
[SHK] From love 's weak childish bow she lives unharm 'd
[SHK] She will not stay the siege of loving terms
[SHK] Nor bide the encounter of assailing eyes
[SHK] Nor ope her lap to saint-seducing gold
[SHK] O she is rich in beauty only poor
[SHK] That when she dies with beauty dies her store
[SHK] Then she hath sworn that she will still live chaste
[SHK] She hath and in that sparing makes huge waste
[SHK] For beauty starved with her severity
[SHK] Cuts beauty off from all posterity
[SHK] She is too fair too wise wisely too fair
[SHK] To merit bliss by making me despair
[SHK] She hath forsworn to love and in that vow
[SHK] Do I live dead that live to tell it now
[SHK] Be ruled by me forget to think of her
[SHK] O teach me how I should forget to think
[SHK] By giving liberty unto thine eyes
[SHK] Examine other beauties
[SHK] 'T is the way
[SHK] To call hers exquisite in question more
[SHK] These happy masks that kiss fair ladies brows
[SHK] Being black put us in mind they hide the fair
[SHK] He that is strucken blind can not forget
[SHK] The precious treasure of his eyesight lost
[SHK] Show me a mistress that is passing fair
[SHK] What doth her beauty serve but as a note
[SHK] Where I may read who pass 'd that passing fair
[SHK] Farewell thou canst not teach me to forget
[SHK] I 'll pay that doctrine or else die in debt
[SHK] But Montague is bound as well as I
[SHK] In penalty alike and 't is not hard I think
[SHK] For men so old as we to keep the peace
[SHK] Of honourable reckoning are you both
[SHK] And pity 't is you lived at odds so long
[SHK] But now my lord what say you to my suit
[SHK] But saying o'er what I have said before
[SHK] My child is yet a stranger in the world
[SHK] She hath not seen the change of fourteen years
[SHK] Let two more summers wither in their pride
[SHK] Ere we may think her ripe to be a bride
[SHK] Younger than she are happy mothers made
[SHK] And too soon marr 'd are those so early made
[SHK] The earth hath swallow 'd all my hopes but she
[SHK] She is the hopeful lady of my earth
[SHK] But woo her gentle Paris get her heart
[SHK] My will to her consent is but a part
[SHK] An she agree within her scope of choice
[SHK] Lies my consent and fair according voice
[SHK] This night I hold an old accustom 'd feast
[SHK] Whereto I have invited many a guest
[SHK] Such as I love and you among the store
[SHK] One more most welcome makes my number more
[SHK] At my poor house look to behold this night
[SHK] Earth-treading stars that make dark heaven light
[SHK] Such comfort as do lusty young men feel
[SHK] When well-apparell 'd April on the heel
[SHK] Of limping winter treads even such delight
[SHK] Among fresh female buds shall you this night
[SHK] Inherit at my house hear all all see
[SHK] And like her most whose merit most shall be
[SHK] Which on more view of many mine being one
[SHK] May stand in number though in reckoning none
[SHK] Come go with me
[SHK] Go sirrah trudge about
[SHK] Through fair Verona find those persons out
[SHK] Whose names are written there and to them say
[SHK] My house and welcome on their pleasure stay
[SHK] Find them out whose names are written here It is
[SHK] written that the shoemaker should meddle with his
[SHK] yard and the tailor with his last the fisher with
[SHK] his pencil and the painter with his nets but I am
[SHK] sent to find those persons whose names are here
[SHK] writ and can never find what names the writing
[SHK] person hath here writ I must to the learned. -- In good time
[SHK] Tut man one fire burns out another 's burning
[SHK] One pain is lessen 'd by another 's anguish
[SHK] Turn giddy and be holp by backward turning
[SHK] One desperate grief cures with another 's languish
[SHK] Take thou some new infection to thy eye
[SHK] And the rank poison of the old will die
[SHK] Your plaintain-leaf is excellent for that
[SHK] For what I pray thee
[SHK] For your broken shin
[SHK] Why Romeo art thou mad
[SHK] Not mad but bound more than a mad-man is
[SHK] Shut up in prison kept without my food
[SHK] Whipp 'd and tormented and -- God-den good fellow
[SHK] God gi god-den I pray sir can you read
[SHK] Ay mine own fortune in my misery
[SHK] Perhaps you have learned it without book but I
[SHK] pray can you read any thing you see
[SHK] Ay if I know the letters and the language
[SHK] Ye say honestly rest you merry
[SHK] Stay fellow I can read
[SHK] 'Signior Martino and his wife and daughters

[SHK] Sups the fair Rosaline whom thou so lovest
[SHK] With all the admired beauties of Verona
[SHK] Go thither and with unattainted eye

[SHK] And I will make thee think thy swan a crow
[SHK] When the devout religion of mine eye
[SHK] Maintains such falsehood then turn tears to fires
[SHK] And these who often drown 'd could never die
[SHK] Transparent heretics be burnt for liars
[SHK] One fairer than my love the all-seeing sun
[SHK] Ne'er saw her match since first the world begun
[SHK] Tut you saw her fair none else being by
[SHK] Herself poised with herself in either eye
[SHK] But in that crystal scales let there be weigh 'd
[SHK] Your lady 's love against some other maid
[SHK] That I will show you shining at this feast
[SHK] And she shall scant show well that now shows best
[SHK] I 'll go along no such sight to be shown
[SHK] But to rejoice in splendor of mine own
[SHK] Nurse where 's my daughter call her forth to me
[SHK] Now by my maidenhead at twelve year old
[SHK] I bade her come What lamb what ladybird
[SHK] God forbid Where 's this girl What Juliet
[SHK] How now who calls
[SHK] Your mother
[SHK] Madam I am here
[SHK] What is your will
[SHK] This is the matter -- Nurse give leave awhile
[SHK] We must talk in secret -- nurse come back again
[SHK] I have remember 'd me thou 's hear our counsel
[SHK] Thou know'st my daughter 's of a pretty age
[SHK] Faith I can tell her age unto an hour
[SHK] She 's not fourteen
[SHK] I 'll lay fourteen of my teeth --
[SHK] And yet to my teeth be it spoken I have but four --
[SHK] She is not fourteen How long is it now
[SHK] To Lammas-tide
[SHK] A fortnight and odd days
[SHK] Even or odd of all days in the year
[SHK] Come Lammas-eve at night shall she be fourteen
[SHK] Susan and she -- God rest all Christian souls --
[SHK] Were of an age well Susan is with God
[SHK] She was too good for me but as I said
[SHK] On Lammas-eve at night shall she be fourteen
[SHK] That shall she marry I remember it well
[SHK] 'T is since the earthquake now eleven years
[SHK] And she was wean 'd -- I never shall forget it --
[SHK] Of all the days of the year upon that day
[SHK] For I had then laid wormwood to my dug
[SHK] Sitting in the sun under the dove-house wall
[SHK] My lord and you were then at Mantua --
[SHK] Nay I do bear a brain -- but as I said
[SHK] When it did taste the wormwood on the nipple
[SHK] Of my dug and felt it bitter pretty fool
[SHK] To see it tetchy and fall out with the dug
[SHK] Shake quoth the dove-house 't was no need I trow
[SHK] To bid me trudge
[SHK] And since that time it is eleven years
[SHK] For then she could stand alone nay by the rood
[SHK] She could have run and waddled all about
[SHK] For even the day before she broke her brow
[SHK] And then my husband -- God be with his soul
[SHK] A was a merry man -- took up the child
[SHK] 'Yea quoth he 'dost thou fall upon thy face
[SHK] Thou wilt fall backward when thou hast more wit
[SHK] Wilt thou not Jule and by my holidame
[SHK] The pretty wretch left crying and said 'Ay
[SHK] To see now how a jest shall come about
[SHK] I warrant an I should live a thousand years
[SHK] I never should forget it 'Wilt thou not Jule quoth he
[SHK] And pretty fool it stinted and said 'Ay
[SHK] Enough of this I pray thee hold thy peace
[SHK] Yes madam yet I can not choose but laugh
[SHK] To think it should leave crying and say 'Ay
[SHK] And yet I warrant it had upon its brow
[SHK] A bump as big as a young cockerel 's stone
[SHK] A parlous knock and it cried bitterly
[SHK] 'Yea quoth my husband 'fall'st upon thy face
[SHK] Thou wilt fall backward when thou comest to age
[SHK] Wilt thou not Jule it stinted and said 'Ay
[SHK] And stint thou too I pray thee nurse say I
[SHK] Peace I have done God mark thee to his grace
[SHK] Thou wast the prettiest babe that e'er I nursed
[SHK] An I might live to see thee married once
[SHK] I have my wish
[SHK] Marry that 'marry is the very theme
[SHK] I came to talk of Tell me daughter Juliet
[SHK] How stands your disposition to be married
[SHK] It is an honour that I dream not of
[SHK] An honour were not I thine only nurse
[SHK] I would say thou hadst suck 'd wisdom from thy teat
[SHK] Well think of marriage now younger than you
[SHK] Here in Verona ladies of esteem
[SHK] Are made already mothers by my count
[SHK] I was your mother much upon these years
[SHK] That you are now a maid Thus then in brief
[SHK] The valiant Paris seeks you for his love
[SHK] A man young lady lady such a man
[SHK] As all the world -- why he 's a man of wax
[SHK] Verona 's summer hath not such a flower
[SHK] Nay he 's a flower in faith a very flower
[SHK] What say you can you love the gentleman
[SHK] This night you shall behold him at our feast
[SHK] Read o'er the volume of young Paris face
[SHK] And find delight writ there with beauty 's pen
[SHK] Examine every married lineament
[SHK] And see how one another lends content
[SHK] And what obscured in this fair volume lies
[SHK] Find written in the margent of his eyes
[SHK] This precious book of love this unbound lover
[SHK] To beautify him only lacks a cover
[SHK] The fish lives in the sea and 't is much pride
[SHK] For fair without the fair within to hide
[SHK] That book in many 's eyes doth share the glory
[SHK] That in gold clasps locks in the golden story
[SHK] So shall you share all that he doth possess
[SHK] By having him making yourself no less
[SHK] No less nay bigger women grow by men
[SHK] Speak briefly can you like of Paris love
[SHK] I 'll look to like if looking liking move
[SHK] But no more deep will I endart mine eye
[SHK] Than your consent gives strength to make it fly
[SHK] Madam the guests are come supper served up you
[SHK] called my young lady asked for the nurse cursed in
[SHK] the pantry and every thing in extremity I must
[SHK] hence to wait I beseech you follow straight
[SHK] We follow thee
[SHK] Juliet the county stays
[SHK] Go girl seek happy nights to happy days
[SHK] What shall this speech be spoke for our excuse
[SHK] Or shall we on without a apology
[SHK] The date is out of such prolixity
[SHK] We 'll have no Cupid hoodwink 'd with a scarf
[SHK] Bearing a Tartar 's painted bow of lath
[SHK] Scaring the ladies like a crow-keeper
[SHK] Nor no without-book prologue faintly spoke
[SHK] After the prompter for our entrance
[SHK] But let them measure us by what they will
[SHK] We 'll measure them a measure and be gone
[SHK] Give me a torch I am not for this ambling
[SHK] Being but heavy I will bear the light
[SHK] Nay gentle Romeo we must have you dance
[SHK] Not I believe me you have dancing shoes
[SHK] With nimble soles I have a soul of lead
[SHK] So stakes me to the ground I can not move
[SHK] You are a lover borrow Cupid 's wings
[SHK] And soar with them above a common bound
[SHK] I am too sore enpierced with his shaft
[SHK] To soar with his light feathers and so bound
[SHK] I can not bound a pitch above dull woe
[SHK] Under love 's heavy burden do I sink
[SHK] And to sink in it should you burden love
[SHK] Too great oppression for a tender thing
[SHK] Is love a tender thing it is too rough
[SHK] Too rude too boisterous and it pricks like thorn
[SHK] If love be rough with you be rough with love
[SHK] Prick love for pricking and you beat love down
[SHK] Give me a case to put my visage in
[SHK] A visor for a visor what care I
[SHK] What curious eye doth quote deformities
[SHK] Here are the beetle brows shall blush for me
[SHK] Come knock and enter and no sooner in
[SHK] But every man betake him to his legs
[SHK] A torch for me let wantons light of heart
[SHK] Tickle the senseless rushes with their heels
[SHK] For I am proverb 'd with a grandsire phrase
[SHK] I 'll be a candle-holder and look on
[SHK] The game was ne'er so fair and I am done
[SHK] Tut dun 's the mouse the constable 's own word
[SHK] If thou art dun we 'll draw thee from the mire
[SHK] Of this sir-reverence love wherein thou stick'st
[SHK] Up to the ears Come we burn daylight ho
[SHK] Nay that 's not so
[SHK] I mean sir in delay
[SHK] We waste our lights in vain like lamps by day
[SHK] Take our good meaning for our judgment sits
[SHK] Five times in that ere once in our five wits
[SHK] And we mean well in going to this mask
[SHK] But 't is no wit to go
[SHK] Why may one ask
[SHK] I dream 'd a dream to-night
[SHK] And so did I
[SHK] Well what was yours
[SHK] That dreamers often lie
[SHK] In bed asleep while they do dream things true
[SHK] O then I see Queen Mab hath been with you
[SHK] She is the fairies midwife and she comes
[SHK] In shape no bigger than an agate-stone
[SHK] On the fore-finger of an alderman
[SHK] Drawn with a team of little atomies
[SHK] Athwart men 's noses as they lie asleep
[SHK] Her wagon-spokes made of long spiders legs
[SHK] The cover of the wings of grasshoppers
[SHK] The traces of the smallest spider 's web
[SHK] The collars of the moonshine 's watery beams
[SHK] Her whip of cricket 's bone the lash of film
[SHK] Her wagoner a small grey-coated gnat
[SHK] Not so big as a round little worm
[SHK] Prick 'd from the lazy finger of a maid
[SHK] Her chariot is an empty hazel-nut
[SHK] Made by the joiner squirrel or old grub
[SHK] Time out o mind the fairies coachmakers
[SHK] And in this state she gallops night by night
[SHK] Through lovers brains and then they dream of love
[SHK] O'er courtiers knees that dream on court'sies straight
[SHK] O'er lawyers fingers who straight dream on fees
[SHK] O'er ladies lips who straight on kisses dream
[SHK] Which oft the angry Mab with blisters plagues
[SHK] Because their breaths with sweetmeats tainted are
[SHK] Sometime she gallops o'er a courtier 's nose
[SHK] And then dreams he of smelling out a suit
[SHK] And sometime comes she with a tithe-pig 's tail
[SHK] Tickling a parson 's nose as a lies asleep
[SHK] Then dreams he of another benefice
[SHK] Sometime she driveth o'er a soldier 's neck
[SHK] And then dreams he of cutting foreign throats
[SHK] Of breaches ambuscadoes Spanish blades
[SHK] Of healths five-fathom deep and then anon
[SHK] Drums in his ear at which he starts and wakes
[SHK] And being thus frighted swears a prayer or two
[SHK] And sleeps again This is that very Mab
[SHK] That plats the manes of horses in the night
[SHK] And bakes the elflocks in foul sluttish hairs
[SHK] Which once untangled much misfortune bodes
[SHK] This is the hag when maids lie on their backs
[SHK] That presses them and learns them first to bear
[SHK] Making them women of good carriage
[SHK] This is she --
[SHK] Peace peace Mercutio peace
[SHK] Thou talk'st of nothing
[SHK] True I talk of dreams
[SHK] Which are the children of an idle brain
[SHK] Begot of nothing but vain fantasy
[SHK] Which is as thin of substance as the air
[SHK] And more inconstant than the wind who wooes
[SHK] Even now the frozen bosom of the north
[SHK] And being anger 'd puffs away from thence
[SHK] Turning his face to the dew-dropping south
[SHK] This wind you talk of blows us from ourselves
[SHK] Supper is done and we shall come too late
[SHK] I fear too early for my mind misgives
[SHK] Some consequence yet hanging in the stars
[SHK] Shall bitterly begin his fearful date
[SHK] With this night 's revels and expire the term
[SHK] Of a despised life closed in my breast
[SHK] By some vile forfeit of untimely death
[SHK] But He that hath the steerage of my course
[SHK] Direct my sail On lusty gentlemen
[SHK] Strike drum
[SHK] Where 's Potpan that he helps not to take away He
[SHK] shift a trencher he scrape a trencher
[SHK] When good manners shall lie all in one or two men 's
[SHK] hands and they unwashed too 't is a foul thing
[SHK] Away with the joint-stools remove the
[SHK] court-cupboard look to the plate Good thou save
[SHK] me a piece of marchpane and as thou lovest me let
[SHK] the porter let in Susan Grindstone and Nell
[SHK] Antony and Potpan
[SHK] Ay boy ready
[SHK] You are looked for and called for asked for and
[SHK] sought for in the great chamber
[SHK] We can not be here and there too Cheerly boys be
[SHK] brisk awhile and the longer liver take all
[SHK] Welcome gentlemen ladies that have their toes
[SHK] Unplagued with corns will have a bout with you
[SHK] Ah ha my mistresses which of you all
[SHK] Will now deny to dance she that makes dainty
[SHK] She I 'll swear hath corns am I come near ye now
[SHK] Welcome gentlemen I have seen the day
[SHK] That I have worn a visor and could tell
[SHK] A whispering tale in a fair lady 's ear
[SHK] Such as would please 't is gone 't is gone 't is gone
[SHK] You are welcome gentlemen come musicians play
[SHK] A hall a hall give room and foot it girls
[SHK] More light you knaves and turn the tables up
[SHK] And quench the fire the room is grown too hot
[SHK] Ah sirrah this unlook'd-for sport comes well
[SHK] Nay sit nay sit good cousin Capulet
[SHK] For you and I are past our dancing days
[SHK] How long is't now since last yourself and I
[SHK] Were in a mask
[SHK] By r lady thirty years
[SHK] What man 't is not so much 't is not so much
[SHK] 'T is since the nuptials of Lucentio
[SHK] Come pentecost as quickly as it will
[SHK] Some five and twenty years and then we mask 'd
[SHK] 'T is more 't is more his son is elder sir
[SHK] His son is thirty
[SHK] Will you tell me that
[SHK] His son was but a ward two years ago
[SHK] enrich the hand
[SHK] Of yonder knight
[SHK] I know not sir
[SHK] O she doth teach the torches to burn bright
[SHK] It seems she hangs upon the cheek of night
[SHK] Like a rich jewel in an Ethiope 's ear
[SHK] Beauty too rich for use for earth too dear
[SHK] So shows a snowy dove trooping with crows
[SHK] As yonder lady o'er her fellows shows
[SHK] The measure done I 'll watch her place of stand
[SHK] And touching hers make blessed my rude hand
[SHK] Did my heart love till now forswear it sight
[SHK] For I ne'er saw true beauty till this night
[SHK] This by his voice should be a Montague
[SHK] Fetch me my rapier boy What dares the slave
[SHK] Come hither cover 'd with an antic face
[SHK] To fleer and scorn at our solemnity
[SHK] Now by the stock and honour of my kin
[SHK] To strike him dead I hold it not a sin
[SHK] Why how now kinsman wherefore storm you so
[SHK] Uncle this is a Montague our foe
[SHK] A villain that is hither come in spite
[SHK] To scorn at our solemnity this night
[SHK] Young Romeo is it
[SHK] 'T is he that villain Romeo
[SHK] Content thee gentle coz let him alone
[SHK] He bears him like a portly gentleman
[SHK] And to say truth Verona brags of him
[SHK] To be a virtuous and well-govern 'd youth
[SHK] I would not for the wealth of all the town
[SHK] Here in my house do him disparagement
[SHK] Therefore be patient take no note of him
[SHK] It is my will the which if thou respect
[SHK] Show a fair presence and put off these frowns
[SHK] And ill-beseeming semblance for a feast
[SHK] It fits when such a villain is a guest
[SHK] I 'll not endure him
[SHK] He shall be endured
[SHK] What goodman boy I say he shall go to
[SHK] Am I the master here or you go to
[SHK] You 'll not endure him God shall mend my soul
[SHK] You 'll make a mutiny among my guests
[SHK] You will set cock-a-hoop you 'll be the man
[SHK] Why uncle 't is a shame
[SHK] Go to go to
[SHK] You are a saucy boy is't so indeed
[SHK] This trick may chance to scathe you I know what
[SHK] You must contrary me marry 't is time
[SHK] Well said my hearts You are a princox go
[SHK] Be quiet or -- More light more light For shame
[SHK] I 'll make you quiet What cheerly my hearts
[SHK] Patience perforce with wilful choler meeting
[SHK] Makes my flesh tremble in their different greeting
[SHK] I will withdraw but this intrusion shall
[SHK] Now seeming sweet convert to bitter gall
[SHK] This holy shrine the gentle fine is this
[SHK] My lips two blushing pilgrims ready stand
[SHK] To smooth that rough touch with a tender kiss
[SHK] Good pilgrim you do wrong your hand too much
[SHK] Which mannerly devotion shows in this
[SHK] For saints have hands that pilgrims hands do touch
[SHK] And palm to palm is holy palmers kiss
[SHK] Have not saints lips and holy palmers too
[SHK] Ay pilgrim lips that they must use in prayer
[SHK] O then dear saint let lips do what hands do
[SHK] They pray grant thou lest faith turn to despair
[SHK] Saints do not move though grant for prayers sake
[SHK] Then move not while my prayer 's effect I take
[SHK] Thus from my lips by yours my sin is purged
[SHK] Then have my lips the sin that they have took
[SHK] Sin from thy lips O trespass sweetly urged
[SHK] Give me my sin again
[SHK] You kiss by the book
[SHK] Madam your mother craves a word with you
[SHK] What is her mother
[SHK] Marry bachelor
[SHK] Her mother is the lady of the house
[SHK] And a good lady and a wise and virtuous
[SHK] I nursed her daughter that you talk 'd withal
[SHK] I tell you he that can lay hold of her
[SHK] Shall have the chinks
[SHK] Is she a Capulet
[SHK] O dear account my life is my foe 's debt
[SHK] Away begone the sport is at the best
[SHK] Ay so I fear the more is my unrest
[SHK] Nay gentlemen prepare not to be gone

[SHK] Is it e'en so why then I thank you all

[SHK] I 'll to my rest

[SHK] Marry that I think be young Petrucio
[SHK] What 's he that follows there that would not dance
[SHK] I know not
[SHK] Go ask his name if he be married
[SHK] My grave is like to be my wedding bed
[SHK] His name is Romeo and a Montague
[SHK] The only son of your great enemy
[SHK] My only love sprung from my only hate
[SHK] Too early seen unknown and known too late
[SHK] Prodigious birth of love it is to me
[SHK] That I must love a loathed enemy
[SHK] What 's this what 's this
[SHK] A rhyme I learn 'd even now
[SHK] Of one I danced withal
[SHK] Anon anon
[SHK] Come let 's away the strangers all are gone
[SHK] Now old desire doth in his death-bed lie
[SHK] And young affection gapes to be his heir
[SHK] That fair for which love groan 'd for and would die
[SHK] With tender Juliet match 'd is now not fair
[SHK] Now Romeo is beloved and loves again
[SHK] Alike betwitched by the charm of looks
[SHK] But to his foe supposed he must complain
[SHK] And she steal love 's sweet bait from fearful hooks
[SHK] Being held a foe he may not have access
[SHK] To breathe such vows as lovers use to swear
[SHK] And she as much in love her means much less
[SHK] To meet her new-beloved any where
[SHK] But passion lends them power time means to meet
[SHK] Tempering extremities with extreme sweet
[SHK] Can I go forward when my heart is here
[SHK] Turn back dull earth and find thy centre out
[SHK] Romeo my cousin Romeo
[SHK] He is wise
[SHK] And on my lie hath stol'n him home to bed
[SHK] He ran this way and leap 'd this orchard wall
[SHK] Call good Mercutio
[SHK] Nay I 'll conjure too
[SHK] Romeo humours madman passion lover
[SHK] Appear thou in the likeness of a sigh
[SHK] Speak but one rhyme and I am satisfied
[SHK] Cry but 'Ay me pronounce but 'love and 'dove
[SHK] Speak to my gossip Venus one fair word
[SHK] One nick-name for her purblind son and heir
[SHK] Young Adam Cupid he that shot so trim
[SHK] When King Cophetua loved the beggar-maid
[SHK] He heareth not he stirreth not he moveth not
[SHK] The ape is dead and I must conjure him
[SHK] I conjure thee by Rosaline 's bright eyes
[SHK] By her high forehead and her scarlet lip
[SHK] By her fine foot straight leg and quivering thigh
[SHK] And the demesnes that there adjacent lie
[SHK] That in thy likeness thou appear to us
[SHK] And if he hear thee thou wilt anger him
[SHK] This can not anger him 'twould anger him
[SHK] To raise a spirit in his mistress circle
[SHK] Of some strange nature letting it there stand
[SHK] Till she had laid it and conjured it down
[SHK] That were some spite my invocation
[SHK] Is fair and honest and in his mistress name
[SHK] I conjure only but to raise up him
[SHK] Come he hath hid himself among these trees
[SHK] To be consorted with the humorous night
[SHK] Blind is his love and best befits the dark
[SHK] If love be blind love can not hit the mark
[SHK] Now will he sit under a medlar tree
[SHK] And wish his mistress were that kind of fruit
[SHK] As maids call medlars when they laugh alone
[SHK] Romeo that she were O that she were
[SHK] An open et caetera thou a poperin pear
[SHK] Romeo good night I 'll to my truckle-bed
[SHK] This field-bed is too cold for me to sleep
[SHK] Come shall we go
[SHK] Go then for 't is in vain
[SHK] To seek him here that means not to be found
[SHK] He jests at scars that never felt a wound
[SHK] But soft what light through yonder window breaks
[SHK] It is the east and Juliet is the sun
[SHK] Arise fair sun and kill the envious moon
[SHK] Who is already sick and pale with grief
[SHK] That thou her maid art far more fair than she
[SHK] Be not her maid since she is envious
[SHK] Her vestal livery is but sick and green
[SHK] And none but fools do wear it cast it off
[SHK] It is my lady O it is my love
[SHK] O that she knew she were
[SHK] She speaks yet she says nothing what of that
[SHK] Her eye discourses I will answer it
[SHK] I am too bold 't is not to me she speaks
[SHK] Two of the fairest stars in all the heaven
[SHK] Having some business do entreat her eyes
[SHK] To twinkle in their spheres till they return
[SHK] What if her eyes were there they in her head
[SHK] The brightness of her cheek would shame those stars
[SHK] As daylight doth a lamp her eyes in heaven
[SHK] Would through the airy region stream so bright
[SHK] That birds would sing and think it were not night
[SHK] See how she leans her cheek upon her hand
[SHK] O that I were a glove upon that hand
[SHK] That I might touch that cheek
[SHK] Ay me
[SHK] She speaks
[SHK] O speak again bright angel for thou art
[SHK] As glorious to this night being o'er my head
[SHK] As is a winged messenger of heaven
[SHK] Unto the white-upturned wondering eyes
[SHK] Of mortals that fall back to gaze on him
[SHK] When he bestrides the lazy-pacing clouds
[SHK] And sails upon the bosom of the air
[SHK] O Romeo Romeo wherefore art thou Romeo
[SHK] Deny thy father and refuse thy name
[SHK] Or if thou wilt not be but sworn my love
[SHK] And I 'll no longer be a Capulet
[SHK] 'T is but thy name that is my enemy
[SHK] Thou art thyself though not a Montague
[SHK] What 's Montague it is nor hand nor foot
[SHK] Nor arm nor face nor any other part
[SHK] Belonging to a man O be some other name
[SHK] What 's in a name that which we call a rose
[SHK] By any other name would smell as sweet
[SHK] So Romeo would were he not Romeo call 'd
[SHK] Retain that dear perfection which he owes
[SHK] Without that title Romeo doff thy name
[SHK] And for that name which is no part of thee
[SHK] Take all myself
[SHK] I take thee at thy word
[SHK] Call me but love and I 'll be new baptized
[SHK] Henceforth I never will be Romeo
[SHK] What man art thou that thus bescreen 'd in night
[SHK] So stumblest on my counsel
[SHK] By a name
[SHK] I know not how to tell thee who I am
[SHK] My name dear saint is hateful to myself
[SHK] Because it is an enemy to thee
[SHK] Had I it written I would tear the word
[SHK] My ears have not yet drunk a hundred words
[SHK] Of that tongue 's utterance yet I know the sound
[SHK] Art thou not Romeo and a Montague
[SHK] Neither fair saint if either thee dislike
[SHK] How camest thou hither tell me and wherefore
[SHK] The orchard walls are high and hard to climb
[SHK] And the place death considering who thou art
[SHK] If any of my kinsmen find thee here
[SHK] With love 's light wings did I o'er-perch these walls
[SHK] For stony limits can not hold love out
[SHK] And what love can do that dares love attempt
[SHK] Therefore thy kinsmen are no let to me
[SHK] If they do see thee they will murder thee
[SHK] Alack there lies more peril in thine eye
[SHK] Than twenty of their swords look thou but sweet
[SHK] And I am proof against their enmity
[SHK] I would not for the world they saw thee here
[SHK] I have night 's cloak to hide me from their sight
[SHK] And but thou love me let them find me here
[SHK] My life were better ended by their hate
[SHK] Than death prorogued wanting of thy love
[SHK] By whose direction found'st thou out this place
[SHK] By love who first did prompt me to inquire
[SHK] He lent me counsel and I lent him eyes
[SHK] I am no pilot yet wert thou as far
[SHK] As that vast shore wash 'd with the farthest sea
[SHK] I would adventure for such merchandise
[SHK] Thou know'st the mask of night is on my face
[SHK] Else would a maiden blush bepaint my cheek
[SHK] For that which thou hast heard me speak to-night
[SHK] Fain would I dwell on form fain fain deny
[SHK] What I have spoke but farewell compliment
[SHK] Dost thou love me I know thou wilt say 'Ay
[SHK] And I will take thy word yet if thou swear'st
[SHK] Thou mayst prove false at lovers perjuries
[SHK] Then say Jove laughs O gentle Romeo
[SHK] If thou dost love pronounce it faithfully
[SHK] Or if thou think'st I am too quickly won
[SHK] I 'll frown and be perverse an say thee nay
[SHK] So thou wilt woo but else not for the world
[SHK] In truth fair Montague I am too fond
[SHK] And therefore thou mayst think my 'havior light
[SHK] But trust me gentleman I 'll prove more true
[SHK] Than those that have more cunning to be strange
[SHK] I should have been more strange I must confess
[SHK] But that thou overheard'st ere I was ware
[SHK] My true love 's passion therefore pardon me
[SHK] And not impute this yielding to light love
[SHK] Which the dark night hath so discovered
[SHK] Lady by yonder blessed moon I swear
[SHK] That tips with silver all these fruit-tree tops --
[SHK] O swear not by the moon the inconstant moon
[SHK] That monthly changes in her circled orb
[SHK] Lest that thy love prove likewise variable
[SHK] What shall I swear by
[SHK] Do not swear at all
[SHK] Or if thou wilt swear by thy gracious self
[SHK] Which is the god of my idolatry
[SHK] And I 'll believe thee
[SHK] If my heart 's dear love --
[SHK] Well do not swear although I joy in thee
[SHK] I have no joy of this contract to-night
[SHK] It is too rash too unadvised too sudden
[SHK] Too like the lightning which doth cease to be
[SHK] Ere one can say 'It lightens Sweet good night
[SHK] This bud of love by summer 's ripening breath
[SHK] May prove a beauteous flower when next we meet
[SHK] Good night good night as sweet repose and rest
[SHK] Come to thy heart as that within my breast
[SHK] O wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied
[SHK] What satisfaction canst thou have to-night
[SHK] The exchange of thy love 's faithful vow for mine
[SHK] I gave thee mine before thou didst request it
[SHK] And yet I would it were to give again
[SHK] Wouldst thou withdraw it for what purpose love
[SHK] But to be frank and give it thee again
[SHK] And yet I wish but for the thing I have
[SHK] My bounty is as boundless as the sea
[SHK] My love as deep the more I give to thee
[SHK] The more I have for both are infinite
[SHK] I hear some noise within dear love adieu
[SHK] Anon good nurse Sweet Montague be true
[SHK] Stay but a little I will come again
[SHK] O blessed blessed night I am afeard
[SHK] Being in night all this is but a dream
[SHK] Too flattering-sweet to be substantial
[SHK] Three words dear Romeo and good night indeed
[SHK] If that thy bent of love be honourable
[SHK] Thy purpose marriage send me word to-morrow
[SHK] By one that I 'll procure to come to thee
[SHK] Where and what time thou wilt perform the rite
[SHK] And all my fortunes at thy foot I 'll lay
[SHK] And follow thee my lord throughout the world
[SHK] I come anon. -- But if thou mean'st not well
[SHK] I do beseech thee --
[SHK] By and by I come --
[SHK] To cease thy suit and leave me to my grief
[SHK] To-morrow will I send
[SHK] So thrive my soul --
[SHK] A thousand times good night
[SHK] A thousand times the worse to want thy light
[SHK] Love goes toward love as schoolboys from
[SHK] their books
[SHK] But love from love toward school with heavy looks
[SHK] Hist Romeo hist O for a falconer 's voice
[SHK] To lure this tassel-gentle back again
[SHK] Bondage is hoarse and may not speak aloud
[SHK] Else would I tear the cave where Echo lies
[SHK] And make her airy tongue more hoarse than mine
[SHK] With repetition of my Romeo 's name
[SHK] It is my soul that calls upon my name
[SHK] How silver-sweet sound lovers tongues by night
[SHK] Like softest music to attending ears
[SHK] Romeo
[SHK] My dear
[SHK] At what o'clock to-morrow
[SHK] Shall I send to thee
[SHK] At the hour of nine
[SHK] I will not fail 't is twenty years till then
[SHK] I have forgot why I did call thee back
[SHK] Let me stand here till thou remember it
[SHK] I shall forget to have thee still stand there
[SHK] Remembering how I love thy company
[SHK] And I 'll still stay to have thee still forget
[SHK] Forgetting any other home but this
[SHK] 'T is almost morning I would have thee gone
[SHK] And yet no further than a wanton 's bird
[SHK] Who lets it hop a little from her hand
[SHK] Like a poor prisoner in his twisted gyves
[SHK] And with a silk thread plucks it back again
[SHK] So loving-jealous of his liberty
[SHK] I would I were thy bird
[SHK] Sweet so would I
[SHK] Yet I should kill thee with much cherishing
[SHK] Good night good night parting is such
[SHK] sweet sorrow
[SHK] That I shall say good night till it be morrow
[SHK] Sleep dwell upon thine eyes peace in thy breast
[SHK] Would I were sleep and peace so sweet to rest
[SHK] Hence will I to my ghostly father 's cell
[SHK] His help to crave and my dear hap to tell
[SHK] The grey-eyed morn smiles on the frowning night
[SHK] Chequering the eastern clouds with streaks of light
[SHK] And flecked darkness like a drunkard reels
[SHK] From forth day 's path and Titan 's fiery wheels
[SHK] Now ere the sun advance his burning eye
[SHK] The day to cheer and night 's dank dew to dry
[SHK] I must up-fill this osier cage of ours
[SHK] With baleful weeds and precious-juiced flowers
[SHK] The earth that 's nature 's mother is her tomb
[SHK] What is her burying grave that is her womb
[SHK] And from her womb children of divers kind
[SHK] We sucking on her natural bosom find
[SHK] Many for many virtues excellent
[SHK] None but for some and yet all different
[SHK] O mickle is the powerful grace that lies
[SHK] In herbs plants stones and their true qualities
[SHK] For nought so vile that on the earth doth live
[SHK] But to the earth some special good doth give
[SHK] Nor aught so good but strain 'd from that fair use
[SHK] Revolts from true birth stumbling on abuse
[SHK] Virtue itself turns vice being misapplied
[SHK] And vice sometimes by action dignified
[SHK] Within the infant rind of this small flower
[SHK] Poison hath residence and medicine power
[SHK] For this being smelt with that part cheers each part
[SHK] Being tasted slays all senses with the heart
[SHK] Two such opposed kings encamp them still
[SHK] In man as well as herbs grace and rude will
[SHK] And where the worser is predominant
[SHK] Full soon the canker death eats up that plant
[SHK] Good morrow father
[SHK] Benedicite
[SHK] What early tongue so sweet saluteth me
[SHK] Young son it argues a distemper 'd head
[SHK] So soon to bid good morrow to thy bed
[SHK] Care keeps his watch in every old man 's eye
[SHK] And where care lodges sleep will never lie
[SHK] But where unbruised youth with unstuff 'd brain
[SHK] Doth couch his limbs there golden sleep doth reign
[SHK] Therefore thy earliness doth me assure
[SHK] Thou art up-roused by some distemperature
[SHK] Or if not so then here I hit it right
[SHK] Our Romeo hath not been in bed to-night
[SHK] That last is true the sweeter rest was mine

[SHK] How much salt water thrown away in waste

[SHK] wakened thy dog that hath lain asleep in the sun

[SHK] Cold death aside and with the other sends

[SHK] Retorts it Romeo he cries aloud
[SHK] 'Hold friends friends part and swifter than
[SHK] his tongue

[SHK] Bear hence this body and attend our will
[SHK] Mercy but murders pardoning those that kill

[SHK] As Phaethon would whip you to the west
[SHK] And bring in cloudy night immediately

[SHK] That runaway 's eyes may wink and Romeo
[SHK] Leap to these arms untalk 'd of and unseen

[SHK] By their own beauties or if love be blind

[SHK] It was the lark the herald of the morn
